reviews.review: So much to do in Cusco you need a few days. There are so many places to visit in Cusco you probably need at least 4 days to see them all.Highlights are the Cathedral, the Koricancha and Sacsayhuaman

Nice arquitecture!. It's important to choose an hotel not too far from the historic center of Cusco since everything is gathered there. The place is really beautiful and free of cars, so it's nice to have a walk there to admire the buildings!

Cusco. Extremely beutifful,ancient and impressive
As you open a door to the past.Lovely people and service.

So much to see....... The centre of Cusco has so much to see and do that you really need 3 or 4 days to do it justice. We had a guide who explained a lot of the history but I still felt that we had barely scratched the surface. Slightly irritating are the number of people giving you the hard sell on a wide variety of tourist Bric a brac which of course they assure you are the genuine article made with their own hands. Note that the altitude can be a problem for some people but we were ok.

Great Place to see the history in Cusco. We visited here as part of a group tour. With the help of our guide, we learned a lot about the history of Cusco and Peru in general. There are also LOTs of beautiful photo opportunities here.

Nicest city in Peru so far. Contrary to other cities in Peru we visited so far, Cuzco has a clean look and a pleasant vibe. Clearly city that does its very best to cater for all the needs of the visitors. There are numerous vendors but they are not at all agressive and so even contribute to the look and feel. The historic center is worth spending dome time.

Busy at all hours of the day. This square is a central gathering place for people, particularly if they are searching for a cell tower for a signal. It is also an important gathering place for many traditional events. I saw traditional dancing, a religious procession, and a parade there.

Beautiful square with very interesting history. To see how crever the Inka are and how Spanish believe they are devil...but still had created one of the most beautiful square.join the free walking tour that starts right at the fountain of the plaza for insights

Old Historic Cathedral and Plaza. An interesting place to see locals and get some history of the influences of the invasions that took place from many years ago. A good place to hang out, good hotels and restuaants close by.
Most beautiful part. The city center is the best part of Cusco, especially going up the stairs to the San Blas neighborhood. Beautiful!

Excellent place to walk and discover colonial buildings. You will see all the history and the spanish colonial architecture in this amazing city. I really loved it, its charm and different places that i discovered walking.
The catedral!. You have to go to the catedral (church at main square or plaza de armas) listen to cusco's history, the incas and the colonial times!

Ambience and Atmosphere!. Be sure to stay close to Cusco's center because this is where all the action is. The cathedral and the adjacent churches are beautiful and an excellent introduction to the region's colonial architecture (i.e. baroque). And only a short walk away is the pre-Columbian art museum which is one of the best in the country. You can also walk to Koricancha, the Inca temple, now church, to savor the past. It really makes no sense to stay in places like Urubamba, Ollantaytambo or Chinceros when you have Cusco with its many attractions and incredible ambience. Make it your base and visit the small towns in the Sacred Valley during the course of a day trip. They only have so much to offer and are for the most part dull and bland. But Cusco is always interesting.
Precioso. BeautifulGet lots in Cusco for a few days and walk it's little streets and surroundings. It's a magic colonial and beautiful town

Beautiful Cusco!. Beautiful city and wonderful people! Really could have stayed a couple of more days. Enjoyed everything about the city especially since a religious holiday was going on and there were many parades and celebrations!

Hang around long enough and there's sureto be a parade!. We had three days in Cusco and saw two big parades: one was a church event with wonderful costumes and dancing and the other a big commercial celebration with everyone from obstetricians to electricians parading past in their Sunday Best. Very entertaining to watch - and free!The city is very hilly and some of the paths and walkways treacherous, so take sturdy shoes and try not to drink too many Pisco Sours...

Daily parades, always something to celebrate. Enjoyed sitting on the steps in front of the cathedral and watching the world go by - The square hosts daily parades, there is always a reason to celebrate. Beautiful, not too crowded, and the beat goes on -
Only history. Here we have to say that only to walk around and see the churches you will learn all the history of the area.We will learn for the Spanish Conquest and many other things.
Beautiful. Beautiful architecture and a lot prettier than Lima or even Arequipa. A must visit if you're in Peru.

Lovely Place to Acclimatize. Cusco is a very pretty city full of Spanish and Inca history and beautiful buildings. the Spanish replaced traditional Inca sites with churches so they are numerous. Also the usual elaborate statues and gardens along with a smattering of street art some of which tells the history of Cusco. Clean and safe, the locals seem to have embraced tourism and if you are inclined you can have your photo taken with women in traditional dress holding a lamb that is also dresses for the occasion. Great food and entertainment in the square. The locals seem to delight in parades and having fun.
Beautiful city.. Everything about Cusco was awesome, the city is amazing, very organized, clean, beautiful, safe... Good food and great parties! Totally worth it.

Simply beautiful. We were in the Plaza de Armas in Cusco on a Sunday - every Sunday the plaza is closed to cars and there's parades, bands playing, dancing, etc. It was amazing. The Cathedral is also very interesting - the South American spin on European art.Note about the altitude - Cusco is at about 11K feet. I did not do well with the altitude. Cusco was the first stop, but even after 5 days at the elevated altitudes, I did not acclimate - shortness of breath with any kind of exertion, insomnia, etc. Just be aware.

Beautiful!. The historical centre of Cusco, around the Plaza de Armas and the several streets leading from it is a rare and beautiful sight. To us it felt a bit like Florence, in Latin American style, very charming. The lovely cathedral of the virgin basilico and various other churches together with the restaurants, shops, pubs etc make for a very interesting, walkable city. We were recommended to stay two nights and we are glad we did, one night would have been too hurried for this gem of a town.
beautiful historic plaza. The best time to enjoy the Centro Historico is late in the evening, when the sun is not as hot and the lights of the town illuminate the place beautifully.
Perfect For People Watching. Square is very large and attracts alot of locals as well as tourists. Grab a seat and enjoy the show.

The historical centre is beautiful!. Devote half a day if you can to just strolling around the main and back streets of the historical centre. Not just the Plaza de Armas, but Plaza de San Francisco. Cusco is also one of the rare places in Peru where car drivers seem to be courteous to pedestrians! The cathedral is well worth visiting, as well as many museums such as the Inca Museum (which is just as fascinating after Machu Picchu as it would be before!)

Most cleanest city center in Peru. The most cleanest city center of visited Peru cities. Nice to walk in the early morning, during the day and in the evening. Recommend Free walking tour in order to know better the history of the city. Trafic in historical center is not too big compared with other My visited Peru cities.
nice town. Its a touristic place but thats also the reason there are a lot of nice restaurants and other places to go to. nice for a couple of days to visit.

Most beautiful Peru town. Although the outskirts of Cusco are not very appealing, this town was the most pretty and beautiful spot in Peru. Enjoyed seeing the centre and breathing cleaner air than in Lima and Arequipa. Lovely town square.

Busier than 30 years ago but sti?l a blast!. Nowadays there appear to be very large Mercado's everywhere.The main Plaza is still as it was 30 years ago. Even my favourite little Italian restaurant t was still there, El Partition,
Beautiful. Great city centre and worth the UNESCO Cultural Heritage designation. Cobble stone streets red tiled roofs and bustling squares.

very nice city in Peru. we enjoyed this city very much, lots of restaurant and very walkable city. During our stay the had a religiuos parade and traffic was kind of caotic but enjoyed the cultural expirience.

Lovely place, great shopping and sights. The center of Cusco is a lovely place to visit. There's lots and lots of shops, spectacular churches and great restaurant options. It's worth spending a day or at least part of a day in Cusco.

Spanish legacy. This place is more about the Spanish legacy then the Incas but often you'll find small festivals passing by, dances and other celebrations NOT MADE FOR TOURISTS but rather just regular celebrations of the Cusco people. I think that's better than organized activities. You get to see the actual people from Cusco enjoying themselves, speaking their language. It's westernized so you can find North America style stores, burgers, etc. Also, you can take pictures with sheep and locals. Remember, you are a guest, and they (the locals) deserve respect so don't patronize them. I've seen lots of people disrespecting them. Please don't.

Plan plenty of time here!. The Central district surrounds several large plazas dominated by huge historic churches. The central market is amazing with food, crafts, flowers..you can spend hours walking around. Cathedral is as impressive as anything in Rome, and hundreds of shops and restaurants in the area.Great fun!
Awesome!. Very very very nice city! Must have time to visit and see all of it from the bottom to the top.Very recommended.
Cathedral a Must. Definitely spend the money and time to tour the main cathedral on Plaze de Armes (they have audio headsets in many languages).
mixture of cultures. The heart of the city, dominated by the cathedral, with a lot of small shops and restaurants, cross-point for all visitors, crowded from time to time

Stunning place, annoying street vendors. This place is beautiful if you walk through it early enough in the mornings or manage to avoid the crowds and street vendors but at any other time it's packed full of tourists and those damn street vendors constantly harassing people!

Vivid.. The church is beautiful with lots of historical significance and lots of paintings from 17th century Peruvian artist. Three churches in one. The streets are cobbled and reflect the colonial Spanish heritage meshed in with the Incan influence

The best area to visit in Cusco . The Centro Historico De Cusco is the best place to get started in your exploration and experience in Cusco. The people and the views of the Cathedral are not to be missed. While we were there we enjoyed the music and dancing by the locals.

A 5-minute walk to Plaza de Armas. On Sundays one can view bands and marching participants who gather at the Plaza.. If you are there on a Sunday this event is worthwhile to take in. Surrounding the Plaza there are numerous restaurants offering pleasant views of the Plaza from their 2nd story balconies.

beautiful city. I love this city, I was 7 days in Cusco and all places are very amazing!!!
I visited Saqsayhuaman, moray and salt mines of the sacred valley, and Machupicchu.
Great Place. In general, Cusco is not a very beautiful city, but the Centro Historico is really beautiful and nice to a walk. For tourism, is the most important part of Cusco.

Cute plaza. A must-see in Cusco. The streets around the plaza are really cute. If you go to a restaurant in this plaza, first talk to the "jaladores" (restaurant representatives outside the restaurant) and get a cheaper deal.

Attractive, nice place to have a drink. The center is a heart of Cusco, the Cathedral, churches, musuems and lots of shops and cafes, etc. The musuem of MP is right a ronud the corner and a great place to visit.

CUSCO: a MUST visit place. Located at high altitude once the Inca capital Cusco has so much history to offer. Suggest you hire a guide for at least half a day, and discover by yourself after. I felt very safe all along, Peruvians are so friendly and helpful

Beautiful city. A city built in the hills that remind me on Europe. The main plaza like most of these cities is a great starting point with the cathedrale, restaurants, vendors, etc. The streets are hard to walk as they are very narrow with lots of traffic. Quite a few street vendors offering everything from masssages, local arts, shoeshines, etc. to the point where it affects the charm of the city. It is still a memorable place to visit. The number of restaurants offering different types of cuisines is incredible!

Centre is very attractive - new outskirts not so much!. The Cathedral with the Last Supper painting with the roasted guinea pig was very interesting. The main square is very attractive and full of cafes and shops.

Center of Cusco. I'm in total agreement with the initial impressions of Cusco, poor impression. It is very run down except for this square and maybe 3-4 surrounding blocks. Yes you have the ladies dressed in typical peruvian clothing holding baby goats and llamas asking for Sol to take a picture, which we did :/The cathedral is here and a must see (sorry couldn't take pictures inside). It is beautiful. Most of the good restaurants are located in this area. It is very walkable from most hotels and felt much safer here than Lima. We saw festivals here every weekend. People dressed in costume etc. Very festive town. Locals are very friendly and clearly use to tourists. Unfortunately Cusco has a stray dog issue. They seem well fed and are not a threat but it is sad to see.

Cusco is awesome. We were lucky to be in Cusco when it was decorated for the Sun Festival which was celebrated on the Thursday following their Winter Solstice. This is such a sweet little city. Be sure to take a city tour of the sites (1/2 day) and eat lots of great food!

A beautiful end up.. This is a fantastic square in which you will invariably end up while you roam Cusco. And that's not bad thing. Restaurant hustlers and pushy vendors line the square, but let's face it, they're everywhere. Enjoy the cultural events and historical feel and yeah, get a Starbucks if you want. Latin America is not stuck in some "days gone by fantasy", let's not pretend it should be.Tip: Grab a beer or snack on one of the surrounding restaurant's balconies and just watch the world go by. If you want a balcony and are dragged into a restaurant that doesn't have one available, leave and go to another. Don't settle, get what you want.

Best part of the city. My initial impression of Cusco weren't great - taxi from airport to hotel only went through run down areas, but when I discovered the historical centre I was very impressed. Some greats site to look at and visit, and plenty of inexpensive restaurants and cafe

Tourists Beware. When in Cusco you will end up here. While the square is beautiful and located across the Cathedral there are too many hustlers trying to sell you stuff. You can also find McDonalds and Starbucks here so you get the gist.

Very nice city and historical sites. While visiting Peru, we took a half-day private tour of Cusco. Our guide, Maria Yabar was excellent. We visited several sites, including Koricancha, Quengo, Puca Pucara, Tambomachay and the cathedral and plaza. There is plenty to see and do here, with a great variety of Inca, Spanish and local history. Also, many food options. It’s worth taking the time and arranging a guide to get the most out of your visit. The construction, craftsmanship and detail of many of the buildings is stunning. The amount of artwork, gold and silver in the churches is breathtaking. We really enjoyed our visit here.

Beautiful old city center, complete with marching school children and flag corps. Any trip to Cusco will include a visit here, its the center of life. Have drinks and appetizers from the balcony of any restaurant overlooking the plaza. Sunsets are especially amazing.

Historic Cusco. Beautiful historic city in the Andes, plenty of old churches, ruins, narrow stone streets, restaurants and shops.Perfect for the adventurous traveler before visiting Macchu Picchu.Very safe and lots of hotels for all budgets.

Beautiful city - with a depth of Inca history. We spent 4 days in Cusco, acclimatising to the altitude, prior to embarking on the 5 day Inca Trail trek. Was definitely worth the visit. A small city , with the ability to see most sites by walking. Recommend the free city tour which runs for 1.5 hrs hosted by an informative guide (who happens to take you to favoured merchants who offer discounts on tourist goods !) Thee main square in front of the Cathedral is alive in the mid/late afternoon with locals and tourists enjoying the outdoors.
Sunday stroll through Cusco.. The main square, the churches, the museums were all charming and interesting. We really felt the altitude as we climbed up the hills! The city is beautiful!!
Beautiful Area of Cusco!. Must see in Cusco!! There is a lot to do in the square - restaurants, shopping, museums, more!! You can go in the church and get a great view as well!
Lots of places to visit. Plenty of restaurants and shops, museauns, churchs. Excllent place to be near during your stay. Love it.
Full of atmosphere. Great place for a wander, sit and admire the view, people watch and try and forget about your altitude headache!

Great stroll through town. This town of course is full of tourists but full of history. The churches while beautiful are a delicate reminder of the Spanish conquest of the unique Inca culture. A must for anyone visiting this region headed off the Machu Picchu.

A wealth of history. At every turn for blocks and blocks one feels the weight of history and the intermingling of cultures, now with the addition of thousands of tourists. There a dozens of museums, churches, plazas, historical buildings, markets, restaurants and art galleries to visit in the historical heart of Cusco. One need only take care not to try to do too much at this high altitude.

Meeting place for spectacular festivals. A wide open central plaza with only foot traffic, used on weekends for local events including school bands, and dancing - check it our on Saturday or Sunday for some surprising entertainments
Amazing. Have to go see when in cusco. They have audio and tour guides too. A must see when in cusco. Very friendly
Very historic. Cool square. Very historical. Lots of people walking around, soaking up the sun, taking in all the attractions, and shopping.

Breathtaking. Cusco has to be the gem of South America, what a town, you can easily lose yourself sightseeing all the church's and monuments, they're stunning, the locals are helpful without being too pushy as can be the case at other tourist spots.
City tour. We had a great day out with lots to see and fantastic weather!! Bring a sweater tho as it's very cool in the shade.
Beautiful. Beautiful place. Full of Hystory and magic. By the time we were there they were celebrating with some traditional parades. Colorful and filled with dance and music

great place, but toursist are under souvenir attack. The center of Cusco is wonderful world heritage, The Plaza des Armas has a few benches where you can admire the wonderful cathedral, and Jesuit church, and just absorb the atmosphere.However to appreciate this place at full, it's best at 4 AM, when nobody is trying to sell you a massage, offer you a taxi somewhere, sell you a tour, or a piece of art :-)
Inca capitol. Gateway to Machu picchu. At one Cusco was the capitol of the Inca nation.So there is lots of history here.
A delightful downtown area!. Fantastic downtown area filled with shops and awesome restaurants. Be sure to try Pancho's for the buyers and to visit the Inca museum located right off the main square.

One of the nicest cities in South America.. Cusco is beautiful! I spent a full week there, just walking the streets and making new discoveries every day, be it ancient architecture, contemporary art, or great cafes. One of my favorites in Peru!
Most beautiful plaza. The main plaza in Cuzco, is the place to go waking. The catedral, beautiful surrounding. You should not miss it

Cute Town Square. We passed this by quite a bit as our hotel was right around the corner from this location. It gets a bit crowded from the mid-morning on. We especially enjoyed seeing this in the early morning as I could get photos without throngs of people in the background.

1 week vacation in Cusco . This is the center of everything good in Cusco. .. The Plaza del Armas, surrounded by wonderful restaurants and boutiques is the social hub of Cusco. From Pokemon Go ..to Parades and good conversation .. this is the place to be. Stroll around the Plaza and take in the history and positive energy of Cusco
Cusco. A great place to adjust to the altitude. Lots of cool little shops and places to eat in the area although the vendors walking around can be a tad annoying.

I found the Inca gold!. The basilica was unbelievable - especially how the Spanish incorporated the mirrors with all the silver and gold. (It was to bring in the local people's religion as well). I was awestruck to see the wealth poured into this (and later, about an hour south of Cusco, the Sistine Chapel of the Andes), when there does seem to be so many and better uses for it. It is beautiful albeit sometimes gaudy replica of the basilicas found elsewhere. Makes me unproud to have been raised Catholic, at times. However, a must see. If you go to the church during the daytime there is a charge and off-hours is no charge. One really needs to see it. I wonder...what were they thinking? God truly would want the people to benefit a bit more. (One hears there is a bit of corruption involved as well.)
beautiful. the most beautiful place in peru, safe and complete, restaurants bars everything you need.just take your camera and enjoy

The centre of it all. Great people watching. Nice to see in both daylight and night. Near unlimited restaurants very close by. You can't visit Cusco without stopping here.
There are quite a few merchants selling things, but they aren't terribly pushy.
So much to see, so little time. Cusco is a beautiful city full of things to see and food to enjoy. Just wandering around the historic district makes for an enjoyable day.

Beautiful. A city centre full of things to do and see. Whilst it is a little more touristy than other cities in Peru, there is a nice mix of locals and tourists and it is easy to find authentic/local feel restaurants, cafes, streets and markets just by exploring.I would also definitely recommend a walking tour.We spent just over a week in Cusco and wish we had longer!
Beautiful and full of with history. Its worth to visit and spend more time here, it is rich in history and culture. Also great for long walks.

Cusco is magical. Cusco is a beautiful stop, staying in the Historical part of town is a must, there is nothing like looking across the roofscapes or being down in the colonial buildings moving about. Its a very special energy that these old high andean historical centers have.

City of Cusco. Beautiful City, beautiful people. The locals and tourists were great! We went out to walk around at night and were safe with no worries. The sites were amazing and the food was excellent. Lots of market places and haggling is a must!
Great Places. Plaza de Armas, San Blas Church, small stores and crafts. Within walking distance. Nice weather and places to go
Great walking city. Hotel, Belmond Monasterio, is in easy walking distance of the Plaza de Armas and surrounding neighborhoods.
Nice Place. Do not miss to walk around the historical center of cusco, is amazing, local people are selling their product at san pedro market .

Vacation. From museums to amazing restaurants to an experience of a lifetime, if you're in Peru - this is not to be missed. Easily walkable, you can spend days in this section of the city and continually be enlightened, rain or shine.
Magnifique. A place that you can easily spend half to an entire day, so many historic buildings and shops and restaurants.
Wonderful City!. Cusco is a wonderful city to recover from a long flight to Peru and to prepare for Machu Picchu. The people are incredibly friendly, the history is wonderful, and the food delicious!
Plaza with the "classic" view of Cusco. Plaza de Armas is a mandatory stop on any trip to Cusco. Nice views inside the cathedrals and many good restaurants in this plaza or nearby.

Walkable Quaint Town (though quite touristy). The centre of Cusco is gorgeous, clean, and a nice mix of locals and tourists. There are plenty of beautiful sites to see along with great restaurants overlooking the square.
Really Nice. Visited twice while we were there and it was really nice. Very lively area and you can really feel the heartbeat of the square.
a beautiful city high in the Andes. Cusco really is a beautiful city high in the Andes but with a very friendly character. All the people I met were very friendly and welcoming.

Nice place difficult to adjust.... Cusco is a very nice place but make sure you rest very well when you get there, you eat light at night, because the altitude plays a very important part in your stay. If you feel sick, like most of the visitors, dont hesitate to ask for oxygen at the hotel.

Simply fantastic area to visit in Cusco.. My daughter and I were there for some trekking the the upper highlands (Lares Trek), and to see Machu Picchu. We stayed in Cusco at the beginning and end of the trip, and were greatly overwhelmed (in a good way) with the beauty of Cusco, and this plaza.Very many historic structures and museums that you do not want to miss. You can buy a multi day ticket for many of them. This area was so good, I am planning a return trip in the future.
Fun atmosphere. Lots to do here. Many restaurants and shops. Lots of places to exchange money for a good rate. There was an awesome concert there when we were there that was neat to see.

Cusco city. Cusco is an amazing city with an interesting history. It has a long Inca history with many Inca remnants within the city. If you are interested in Inca history, archeology and architecture you find Cusco to be a city of fascination. The streets such as Triunfo angulos which runs from the main plaza (Plaza de Armas) up one of the surrounding hills is typical of many streets within Cusco. They are largely narrow streets made of cobble stones or pavers which are extremely narrow with an even narrower footpaths. If you drive, which I would not recommend unless you are a local, there is a lot of honking of horns at intersections and reversing at times on streets which are too narrow for two way traffic. The footpaths are extremely narrow and many times you will be required to stop and let people pass or breathe in when a car passes (watch out for side mirrors). The stone footpaths are very slippery so make sure you have good shoes with grip. Everywhere you go within the old district surrounding the Plaza de Armas will have Inca stonework walls. Remember that Cusco is at 3,400 metres and it is a good idea to take altitude tablets in preparation for the height as explained by our physician prior to arrival. We are both recently retired and experienced some mild conditions of altitude sickness.You will be fascinated by the markets everywhere which have superb textiles, jewellery and art work made from brass, bronze and stone.There are some close Inca structures which are extremely interesting from a historical and architectural viewpoint for a day excursion. These can be walked to if you have a reasonable level of fitness. Saqsayhuaman is about 1.5 km from the Plaza via a steep walk or 15 Sol by taxi. You will need a pass to access the historical site which is an amateur photographers dream. We acquired a 70 Sol pass which gave us access to a limlted number of sites. The pass was a day pass and available at the entrance to Saqsayhuaman. You can then catch a taxi from site to site to visit all the sites on your day pass or you can buy a dearer pass for about 120 Sol which gives you access to more sites depending on budget and time.Overall Cusco was amazing and is a good base to explore Inca history and culture. The prices for food and art were reasonable and the people very pleasant. Peru has been a great experience.
Safe, fun, fascinating. Lots of good restaurants in the area, fun to watch all the locals and tourists gather each night to play Pokemon GO. Ha ha!
Amazing. What's to say, when in Cusco go to the Central Historical district. Part of the package. How many more characters?

Central Cusco. This square is visited by both the locals and the tourists. We wandered around it during the day, and then decided we definitely needed to come back at night to see the night activities and lights. We got to see the black Jesus inside the cathedral and heard the story of the cathedral from Saul, our guide with Alpaca Expeditions.

Amazing in the heart of Cusco.. Must see Cathedral and the Church of the Society of Jesus. This incredible church is a marvel with so much spirituality. Unfortunately no photographs could be taken, It is splendid. The centre is a walking distance from San Blas Church and market. The market is very friendly with all eats and local drinks with fresh fruit and vegetable available
First view of Cusco. Beautiful quiet and clean city... Such a mix of architecture... Felt like I had traveled back in time. I could spend all day just sitting in the square. 💕
Many fantastic sites to see here. A fantastic public space, with abundant activities taking place. This is a district, with many sites, not really a single site that could be properly reviewed.
Beautiful plaza. The plaza has a beautiful European old town feel to it. We happened to see a few processions with bands on Monday (I believe it happens every monday). We picturesque/post-cardish.

Very Interesting Incan and Spainish History. The downtown is worth a stroll. The churches, Incan museum, and interesting shops make it worthwhile. The city is bigger (and uglier) than you might expect, but this area is worth visiting.

Favourite City in Peru. This centre area of Cusco is beautiful, vibrant and one of the best areas we have seen in South America. With the beautiful churches, great choices of restaurants and bars you won't get much better. It feels safe to walk around too, no matter what time of day or night.The area has many lively parades during the weekend, making it an interesting place to visit.There are also plenty souvenir shops, ATMs etc.If you can it's worth getting a guest house/ hotel here as many tours start from the main square.

Make sure to explore the Inka alleyways. Wonderful city centre just to browse around walking between the different churches and sites. A huge amount of Inka walls, usually to a height of 5-6 feet but some stretches of up to 0 feet high still exist.

Beautiful square, great meeting point with lots of food options. This is really the nicest spot we ran across in Cusco. The square is beautiful and very nice to photograph. It's a great meeting point before moving on to anywhere else. Lots of restaurants and some bars though they're a bit more expensive because you're on the square. Most of the tours in the area launch from nearby so you'll go through here pretty often.

Beautiful city. Just a fantastic area to walk around. The old historic buildings and churches are fabulous. The cobblestone streets leading up tiny roads to international cuisine and craftsmanship. Markets and stores. Llama and alpaca!! It seems that there is always some festival with music and dancing! The Best!!

Fun place to watch the world go by. Lots of shops & restaurants of all price points surround the central square. Was in Cusco two days and enjoyed local religious costumed parade & celebration on both days. Plenty of folks pitching their restaurants, massages, jewelry, local goods and pictures with baby alpacas but all harmless and all part of the fun!

Can easily spend a day here, so much to see. We only spent a couple of half days here but there's room to spend more time in the historical part of Cusco. The combination of old Inca architecture and colonial structures is a unique and beautiful sight. One can also take breaks and eat well in one of the many places around there. There are convents, monastery, a cathedral, a number of churches and several good museums to visit.

Travelling in time. It was a really good experience visiting and hanging around Centro historico de Cuzco. Verty friendly people, nice cafes and restaurants and interesting historic buildings and museums. We loved it.

Pretty average central square. With cathedral, fountain, stores, bars, restaurants, youth,mops and several types of "taxis". Main feature to me is the level,if chill in everyone in every place we've been

Great to see everything . It's very nice to sit down and watch the city around and the structures that were destroyed and built over by the Spaniards hundreds of years ago. Be aware a lot of people will try to come sell you something
Something to See. It's a part of the city square area and worth seeing while you are there. If there was a cost, it was nominal.

Cusco the city that never sleeps. Historically Cusco is steeped at every corner. Buildings that are Peruvian alongside Spanish architecture. Streets with stones from both periods side-by-side. Like I have suggested elsewhere, Cusco should not just be a stop-over on the way to....It deserves a few days to adsorb the historical and cultural delights it has to offer. Buy a Tourist Ticket for the 10 days and it is cheaper overall. Many sites are free..some are not but the ticket takes the hassle out of waiting and queuing.
Magical.. Cusco is a magical place, and once you get used to the altitude you'll feel at home. I feel really safe and the people are incredibly accommodating and nice.
Nice place. Day and night there's activity in this place, a central hub of the city, go there for money exchange, information, restaurants or any of the traveller's needs.
good. the main square was a good place to visit if you stay in cusco. it offers differnt kind of places to visit around there

Nice place to hang out for a little while. They had a parade through town with all the school kids that ended in the square, so it was nice to hang out and people watch. Lots of shops and overpriced restaurants nearby too.

Lovely main square of the City. Lovely main square and a great gathering place with pretty views of the cathedral, churches and the mountains beyond. The square is mostly surrounded by tourist shops and restaurants but they are under arcade and don't mar the scene.

Intersting but a tourist trap. Very beautiful part of the city. Kept up in really great condition.
Worth a visit.
Beware that you will stuck in a tourist trap and everyone will try and sell you the same "original, one of a kind" pieces of artwork every 10 feet.
Colors and places. It's a beautiful place. at dusk, the colors of the sky make a strong contrast with the buildings and the mountains, excellent time for photo shooting sesions.

Nice area in Cusco to visit. Dropped by this landmark and walked through but services were being held and had to shorten the visit. It is the point that we used to navigate the city. NIce plaza and very historic.

Quick visit . I sure wish I had more days to explore. Safe and very interesting capital of the inca empire Very high altitude. Please read about the effects to prepare but we had no issues. Very nice people and great food.

Center of the action in Cusco. Three or four cathedrals/churches line the square and many shops to buy souvenirs. None of the churches allow pictures, which does not provide all the great photos to go along with the memories.
Gorgeous City. Cusco is absolutely lovely and this is the best portion of the city! Give yourself a couple of hours to wander through. You will love the architecture and the friendly people!

Centuries of culture crammed into a square mile. Often the springboard for the trip to Machu Pichu, Cusco qualifies in its own right as a great cultural attraction. The architecture, visible history fascinating people (and animals) make it a great place to spend a day or two acclimatising to the altitude. The choice of restaurants and quality of cuisine is improving constantly as are the number of quality places to stay. Love it.

Adventures in Peru- Centro Historico. Centro Historico de Cusco is a vibrant location with plenty of activities and people (mostly visitors) mingling throughout the square. Lots of solid restaurants, but you will pay a higher price due to the "tourism factor". Recommend to see it both in the day, as well as night due to the local vendors and scenery as different times.

Great place for a wander. Full of little alleys and whitewashed walls over a variety of inca and other stonework, cute little shops and restaurants (great for window shopping) on a sunny day its fun to wander around the streets of Cusco. Even though they are narrow, many have cars hurtling down them that you need to jump out of the way of. The square is also bustling at night (though you need to watch out to avoid tripping over the legions of zombies playing Pokemon go).

Fascinating place. The dual squares of Cusco contain interesting museums and cathedrals, and represent central places for parades and religious gatherings. We were in town for 3 days and experienced 2 parades and a major protest.
PLAZA DE LAS ARMAS AND SURROUNDING AREA. There are so many interesting points of history in the area. However you will be besieged by vendors and beggars. This is a must see area.

A beautiful spot to visit and stay. It is lively- all narrow cobblestone streets, with historic architecture everywhere. Clean streets, friendly people, plentiful shops, sightseeing. Don't miss the local markets to experience Peruvian culture.

really nice. best historic center in south america. its so nice and spacious that make it so comfortable. They have cafes and restaurants all around it. its nice to spend some hours just hanging around
One of the most beautiful squares I have ever seen....and I am from Italy.... I have a detailed plan of where to go and where to stay according to your budget...drop me a line and I will help you!!!

Cusco city center is beautiful. We visited Cusco last year and Cusco city center is beautifulHave your breakfast and the local market where you can eat sandwiches with avocado, eggs,.... so cheapand have a huge cup of coffee or quinoa teal
Atmosphere. Children from local schools were practising their dances for a forthcoming festival. It is a tourist favourite but holds a happy and welcoming atmosphere.

Small with a good collection. This little museum is located in a very central location in Cusco and right beside the contemporary museum as well. has a good collection of artifacts depicting the history of Peru and the Spanish colonization. I am always surprised when an entire civilization is reminded of the colonization and how their traditional culture was wiped out in a violent way by the colonizers, but still continue to follow the faith and culture of the colonizers. I could not even read or watch the violent way the Incas and other natives were killed and obliterated by the Spanish Conquistadors and there were present day Peruvians happily chatting away or not being too concerned, I guess history does not evoke strong feelings in everyone.

Beautiful pictures. Enjoyed my visit to Cusco .Other than the altitude sickness .Picturesque town lovely .The main piazza with the cathedral amd all the locals people watching .Many local shops selling all sorts of traditional souvenir and alpaca products .

Small Beautiful City. We were in Cusco for about 3 days and the city is very colorful, beautiful, and welcoming. We had a guided tour through Gate 1 and learned so much about its history. The inside of the cathedrals are just amazing, bug, and beautiful! I believe there are 3 in the historic center. The little park in the middle is a great place to hang out and there are a couple of places to go eat something as well. There are also women selling goods at a very good price and are very humble and approachable. We got to talk to a lady selling sweaters and she was just lovely.

Well Worth a Visit. Well worth doing an organised tour to get the best out of this attractive square and its adjacent buildings of interest.Make sure you visit the Museum it was well laid out and fascinating.
Beautiful central square. Make sure to visit this beautiful square. Walk around and enjoy the views and history, definitely worth the trip.

Having been here 15 years ago, I can see the changes. Having been here over 15 years ago, I can see the differences. The place is still amazing and the best way to get around and absorb the information and get to know the history, is through a local guide. Long time ago, there was no Starbucks or KFC and now the place look more like anywhere else. Still worth it!

Amazing, book a private tour for the rich history and depth of knowledge of what to do.. Ask for Angel at Viajes Pacifico tours (booked through viatours). He will show you the full history of Peru and Cusco captured in the buildings, Cathedrals, and monuments. So much rich history, and I.m not just talking about the amazing architecture.

worth the visit. I would recommend a tour guide or some information what you are seeing. different spaces/small rooms from Inca times but need to know what you are looking at just incredible contrast between Spaniards and Incas techniques in building.

Charming. Cusco is an amazing town, and the historic centre is the main part of it. Very interesting with the buildings built of top of inca buildings and the mix of cultures and architecture. we were also lucky that in June they have the Inti Raymi (Festival of the Sun), which filled the streets with dancers - groups from each school, uni, suburb etc all compete, performing for judges in the main plaza - it was very colourful and interesting to see some of that.

Cusco - centre of inca empire and of our holiday!. Cusco is busy, but when you get used to it, the city is magnificent. I recommend taking Walking (free tours on foot) tours to un-niche interesting facts and places as well as a solid history. Shopping is great and fresh juice from the main market is divine.
Beautiful square !. A lot of work was done to make this place nice. At night it is even more beautiful in my opinion. Worth a detour.

Amazing. This cathedral is stunning. The square is lovely too. Full of locals. They were erecting scaffolding when we were there for a concert that evening. Great for people watching too and real pretty at night!

Picture opportunities everywhere. The Historical District of Cusco is extremely picturesque. The carved balconies harking back to the influence of Seville, Spain and the Spanish Conquerors, the cobblestone, narrow, winding streets, the shops, the restaurants ––a must for visitors.
A beautfiul place. A place not to be missed! Its a central part of Cusco offering great restaurants, historical sights and often fun festivals/performances.

Energetic city. I LOVED Cusco! But the energy here can feel intense! Take care walking in the streets as pedestrians do not have the right of way... : /
But a wonderful city that I miss dearly!
A great time. A must see when in the city. Always something going on day or night. Plenty of security so we always felt safe. Teenagers enjoyed it very much.

Unique. Not only its history is fascinating, with colonial buildings with sculpted wooden balconies upon inca stones, but it is safe to walk around night and day on its squares and stone streets, with many great restaurants for all tastes and pockets.Traffic can be confuse, but it might be worth spending a couple of dollars to go uphill on the way in or out of your hotel, and walk only downhill, because the altitude can be punishing and you should save your legs and your breath for Machu Picchu and the other Sacred Valley sites.Speaking of them, most visitors use Cusco as a base to visit the Inca Ruins, but the City is a fantastic attraction on its own right, to the point that I liked it more than Machu Picchu, which was one of the most beautiful places I've ever been to.
Love it!. Beautiful churches, diversity of great restaurants and shops, a lot to do around, safe place to stroll around. Definetely a must to visit.

Beautiful Center. Cusco center is one of the amazing city centers in South America. With Incan and Spanish Buildings. Amazing squares and Plazas, you could easily base yourself here for 2 weeks and not see half of it.I recommend getting the Church pass allowing access to 7 amazing buildings in the city. There are also many good restaurants worth checking out. I recommend San Blas, if you are not a party person!

Wonderful City. Historic, charming, inexpensive, friendly and lots of vegetarian food! Add handicrafts, alpaca's and llamas, baby goats and its perfect! There are tons of museums if you feel the need! We loved it. But, BEWARE, the air is quite thin!

Beautiful colonial centre. Cusco is just beautiful, in fact the most beautiful place we stayed in Peru. It also provides easy access to the local Inka ruins (Sacsaywaman) and plenty of museums and architecture to visit in the town. Highly recommended.

Lots of things to do.. Beautiful Colonial architecture. From here you can go everywhere, you can experience local festivals, go to the cathedral and other churches, lots of places to eat, drink and shop.

Soak up the atmosh. Although we had a half day tour with a guide the best part of our stay was wandering around the small city soaking up the atmosphere. Wonderful weather in July with blue sky. Chilly in the evening.

Beautiful and bustling. A vibrant, exotic town center that looks and feels pretty safe. The exhaust fumes from the traffic are noticeable, but the beautiful mix of colonial architecture and remnants of Inca palaces and temples is captivating.

Beautiful architecture . This is one of several very old cathedrals in the city. Yesterday was Independence Day so flags were flying and the square was full. It's worth taking the city tour as you'll need to rest on the day of arrival, but it's so tempting to go. But DONT! Take a city tour the next day and you'll see more and feel better. Eat Cusco cocoa candy or tea will help with altitude sickness. Don't miss this church and enjoy the scenes. Wear a comfortable pair of shoes. Most streets are made from river rock carefully tumbled but not smooth. Very unique

MOST BEAUTIFUL I'VE SEEN THUS FAR. i want to move to cusco! thats how amazing it is. A friend actually moved there. theres so much beauty and culture! and llamas!! llamas!! and alpacas!!! must go, put it on your bucket list....
Loved the Old Town. Really lovely here. Loved it and wish I could have spend a couple more days/nights there. It was very charming and safe.
Beautiful. Right in the centre of town. Beautiful and amazing if you are into history. Never get tired of looking at it.

Great city. Did a great 1/2 day tour - walking and driving - so much culture. The central square is where it all happens. Lots of restaurants shops etc.Then fabulous cooking class at Marcelo Batata culinary school.Belmond Monasterio hotel was a splurge but worth it!
So beautiful !. You have to go, is the best city in Peru and one of the best of South america! With many young people and a lot a parties to enjoy.

Beautiful city, but hectic!. I felt that Cusco is not a relaxing city. It has a ton of amazing history, but it is definitely not a place where you leave your cares at home and forget where you are. It is very crowded and you have to keep your guard up. Just travel with a bag you can keep at the front of your body.

Great area. . I do photography and I love cusco, I love the old streets and the old town feel, the Spanish buildings and the incan temples. I love the sights and sounds and you can easily spend a few days taking pics and enjoying it.

The centre of town, where tradition meets tourism.. This is the place where the whole town meets. It is the historic centre of Cusco and is surrounded by the narrow streets of the old own. If you miss your hamburgers, there is a very discreet McDonalds in one of the colonial Spanish buildings fronting the square. The more traditional restaurants offer better food. It is a long way from the sea but we ate an excellant seafood ceviche, washed down with a Pisco sour in the restaurant above McDonalds near where 'Gringo Alley' meets the square. The cathedral and the accompanying church are nice to see but there are admission charges to see the Baroque religious art. Locals still gather in the square in the evenings, play with their children and young lovers walk together. School kids dance and old people sit and watch the people passing by. One corner of the square leads to the central markets and the other main streets of the city. It is the town centre.

Vibrant Historic Center. I absolutely loved Cusco.The beautiful Plaza de Armas and its magnificent churches.Very lively plaza. Nice pedestrian area full of activity.We were lucky enough to experience the Historic Center both on a cold and rainy day and an absolutely breathtakingly beautiful sunny day.The weather does not stop the locals. There was plenty of activity on both days.We enjoyed snapping photos and just taking it all in! We were able to walk from our hotel on Calle San Agustin. We felt entirely safe and were able to cover the historic center fairly easily.
What a nice surprise!. Beautiful, relaxed, safe at night for a female traveler. You can buy all your tours in this corner. Will be back.
Favorite place. We loved visiting Cusco!!! Had I known how incredible Cusco is, I would have sppent 3 extra days here.
Every Day is Saturday in Cusco Center . It's true. Any Day you can dance you can get drunk or Just enjoy yourself with this marvelous energy coming from this city . Para volver siempre .

Beautiful. The Plaza is well worth a long visit. The churches, art work, children selling post cards, artisan wares including hand woven murals etc, cobble stone streets are a treasure trove of history,art and culture. I watched women dying yarn in various colors and setting it out to dry. They were weaving murals as guinea pigs ran around the floors and children laughed at their feet. Take the time and walk the streets and go into the displays of art and history. Wandering the plaza is free but there are fees for attractions with in the plaza.

Wish we had had more time in Cusco!. Cusco is a delicious little city with lots, and I mean LOTS to see. The historical center is beautiful, well organized and charming. Make sure you allow enough time to discover the beauties and history of Cusco

Really nice !!! Spend an extra day !!. The entire area was fun an s interesting and we always felt safe and secure. Many shops , really good restaurants. There was always something going on. We spent 2 days , had a great time !!!

Cute and sweet . A nice looking colonial-ish, Spanish, Inka, town. With sweet cobble stone streets, nice cafes and restaurants. Lots of pretty and cute things to look at.
However it gets very cold in winter. Beware

Big beautiful heart of Cusco. The square is huge and surrounded by lovely buildings. It's a vibrant place full of locals and tourists so it's a great people-watching place. As in most places, the restaurants on the square will be pricier and touristy-er but there's a lot of choice so you should be able to find something to your liking if you don't feel like going off the beaten path. When we were there at the beginning of June, there was a religious parade which was fascinating to watch as there were more locals than tourists. Well worth spending at least a couple of hours here, even just to sit and take a load off your feet while people-watching.

Nice experience. We decided to stay 4 nights at Cuzco, since it is a lovely town to have relaxing and culture time an it was worthwhile! With its lovely mood, its architecture and its wonderful cuisine, it is a wonderful place to enjoy vacation.

History. This is a must because it is Cusco it is in the middle of the city no cars drive around same until 10pm there time .beautiful place for pictures only thing everywhere is people trying for you to buy stuff if you buy from one you will be crowded by more a lot of street dogs.But the city is clean. Make sure and visit at night wonderful place to watch the locals.Safe location a lot of eating places near by including KFC but this is a lot of local food around.Enjoy same to the max.Tourist police all around they where white collar shirts and speak English if you need any help.
Don't miss it. A walk in the center of Cusco will undoubtedly take you past the most impressive historical buildings. Take some time to walk around and enjoy the sights.

Visit the cathedral . A fascinating site. Over 100 years to complete it using stones that the Spanish salvaged from demolishing Incan buildings and temples and using Incan labour to build it. Beautiful inside as you would expect from an old Catholic Church.
Cusco center by foot.. Cusco Centro is enchantingly beautiful.This city never sleeps.Dominating place is Plaza de Armas,most enjoyably explored on foot.

You can feel the history. A beautiful town square in a beautiful and historic city. The atmosphere here is so exciting, with everyone soon to embark on their adventures. Lots of sights within a easy walk from he Plaza De Armas.

Good cultural experience . We've been to many town squares and quite a few are set up with tourists specifically in mind. This was an area where we were definitely mixed in with locals and a great place to find street food. Plenty of tourists, but local culture on display.

Culture current and ancient in a multicultural fusiom. Cusco is the multicultural fusion of colonial Spain, Incas and world wide tourism. An enriching place of llamas, shopping, walls, cathedrals, food, crazy driving and a world apart from yours, mine and other cities in peru
Spanish flair. Downtown is a very pleasant experience in July! The importend plazas are all very close, lots of bars and restaurants and its amazing to shop.

Lovely area of Cusco. The Centre of Cusco is lovely. The buildings are beautiful and the square is well maintained. Good place for people watching and you also get to see the surrounding hillsides and views of Cusco. Lots of restaurants and shops to visit also

Very cool place to explore on a short visit!. Went here with my friend, we only had 2 and a half days in Cusco. They had a festival, so luckily we got to see dancing and lots of hustle and bustle! Very cool! The churches were great, and there is lots to see. The market is also nearby!

Beautiful place. It's a beautiful place, with a lot of commerce, people.
You have, from there, a nice view from the city

Charming. Take a slow walk around town whilst you try and get used to the altitude. Taken some small coins with as you will meet some locals on the way for pictures it's sometimes the only money they make. Also try the side streets for a coffee and treat. I would avoid coffee on the squares as they are expensive. Everything is beautiful and charming. We loved it. Enjoy
After living in cusco. The center is really lovely! It is also, of course, a tourist trap, with many locals offering tours, products and services. A nice place to grab some icecream and people watch.

Beautiful square. This area was bustling and filled with people that were selling their wares. I was able to negotiate some good deals for jewelry. The people were gracious, the buildings were vibrant and the atmosphere was marvelous.

Crowded and full of street vendors. This is the place to go as a tourist in Cusco.....unfortunately. The restaurants are overpriced but adequate, and the street vendors are overly aggressive at times.
Cathedral at Cusco. A Spanish cathedral, gold coatings and silver articles are there. Nice place to see, one of the tourist attraction in Cusco
Historical Cusco. Enjoyed watching the preparation for Festival of the Sun. Good places to eat, shop and just watch the parade.

A Step Back in Time. All the major historical sites were located just minutes, walking, from each other. It is an easy city to navigate on foot. Taxis were plentiful and inexpensive for those needing transportation. We purchased the package of 5 religious monuments for about $10 USD and it was well worth it. Free headsets were available at each site for a self-guided tour. A wonderful city to explore.
nice place to walk and see the shops and the parade. good restaurants and shops for alpaca sweaters. nice to walk and people watch and see some of the local flavor
Busy plaza. Lots of restaurants, vendors and historic sites. Pleasant for walking around and getting a feel for authentic Peruvian culture and history.

Fabulous city. Wonderful buildings. Compact city, really convenient to walk round, lots of interesting squares. Cathedral definitely worth visiting as is the Inca museum. Main festival is 24th June but celebrations start much earlier. We were there between 810th and 16th and lots of processions with children and students dancing in the streets to traditional Peruvian music.

Dense Concentration Of Exhibits, Restaurants And Shopping. This safe and bustling area is rife with shopping and restaurants surrounding wonderful attractions. Between the cathedral, the monastery and the Museum of the Incas, there is so much to see, you should plan at least a two days to saver the immediate attractions, more to take in Sacsayaman and the other meaningful attractions.Staying in the area of the artisans may be a little out of the way but it will save you a little bit of money and give you a different taste of the core historical district. Take a guide or a detailed guidebook for the cathedral and monastery, there is so much to see and appreciate.No problems for mobility challenged persons. Young kids would be mildly interested in the cathedral and monastery. Favorite museum in the area: Museo de las incas.

Beautiful, historical city center.. Explore on your own, hire Urban Adventures for a city tour or Action Peru Treks for a trip to the Sacred Valley, visit the local markets, drink coca tea and Inca Kola, eat ceviche, you'll love it.
Beautiful cathedral, nice area to sit and "people-watch". Be sure to save time to go into the Cathedral. It is lovely. Grab lunch and sit on one of the benches by the fountain.

historic and quaint. I did tours of several churches including the Catedral which includes several churches within the building and Comania de Jesus church on the next side of the square. There were women dressed in brightly colored native clothing with baby alpacas. For 1 Sol you can have your photo taken, I recommend it! Everyone at home wanted me to bring one back.

Dancers. We arrived around 3 pm to Cusco, and by 7:00 pm were walking the streets. We were lucky enough to be during the Inty Raimy celebrations. We were greatly surprise to see kids and adults dancing and enjoying ourselves!!
Lovely atmosphere and safe. Its a great area to walk around, have a pisco and buy some souvenirs and to top it up with some culture.

Beautiful for lovers of historic architecture. With most everything very close together, it is ideal for exploring on foot to most appreciate the architecture (not just of the highlights, but of the traditional balconies, etc.) and street life, little shops, etc. Moreover, even for destinations a little further removed from the main square, the taxis are super cheap to easily visit them as well.

Historical, busy and yet so cosy. From all the cities we visited in Peru this is our favourite. Full of history, historical monuments from all periods (pre-Inca, Inca, colonial) and still very much alive. The people are ever so charming and very friendly. The atmosphere somehow relaxed, extremely colourful. If you are looking for authentic crafts and really beautiful gifts - Cusco is the place to be. Roam the streets and especially the small alleyways (the ones without cars and lots of steps are the best!), there are hidden jewels, craft-shops and workplaces around nearly every corner. Don't be afraid to enter open doors, you will be welcome. Have a look, chat, share a cup of coca tea. If you are looking for nice restaurants, again, Cusco is the place to be. If you want to chill, if you are looking for a candle light dinner, or if you simply want to enjoy the local dishes, Cusco has it all. If you are planning a visit to Cusco, it is so much more than only the gateway to Machu Picchu! Take some time and explore this beautiful place!

To get started in Cusco. You must go to the main square to feel the energy from the people that are visiting Cusco. In this place you can see people from all of the world crowded everyday to see the most important square of the Inca Empire and their church.
Quaint. Quaint and interesting historic city center with narrow streets. Itwas pleasant to walk around but be sure to wear thick soled shoes as the paving stones are quite uneven.

A tourist-laden must see. This place is gorgeous. It has so much history and so much to see, shop, eat, and do. I went during Inti Raymi (Quechua for sun festival) so it was extra crowded with parades, vendors, and tourists; of course, I doubt this place is ever lacking in people trying to sell stuff to tourists, but I digress. It's very much a touristy area, but it is such for a reason - it's amazing.
Beautiful City. Great Atmosphere. The square hosts many events. A must place to see. Square was charming with a great atmosphere......

Beautiful area to visit . Wonderful architecture, and many great restaurants and markets, cathedrals and historical sites. I enjoyed watching the light change while sitting at a restaurant balcony. Great spot for people watching.
Tourist . Beautiful historic district worth the visit. Many interesting buildings, churches and squares to see.

Beautiful historic square in center of Cusco.. Tour the two Catholic churches on the square. They are testaments to the reverence shown to God by the early colonists. The square hosts many events, concerts, dancing and parades on a daily basis while we were there. Events are hosted day and evening. High end shopping and some of the best restaurants in Cusco surround the square. You also,find cheap eats with McDonalds and KFC.

Great Place to sight see while enjoying a cup of Joe. This is a beautiful place. I had the honor of visiting Cusco during its 'Inti Raymi' celebration. It is a lively hub and filled with wonderful restaurants and shops. A must for anyone visiting this city.
Nice place to visit. Were there on a national holiday and even got to see a local parade. The square was charming with a family atmosphere .
Very pretty, historic center. A very nice part of Cusco with great Spanish architecture. If you go to Cusco for hiking, make sure you allocate a few days to check Cusco as well.
Very Historic!!!. The history and the architecture of this area was so incredibly amazing. A must place to see. Take the double Bus tour of the City and get off here!!
Pleasent experience. The place is beutiful, historical, clean. There are lot's of delicious spots to eat and drink and the photos are amazing.
Fascinating place. Very interesting museum. Lots of information about the Incas and their history, culture, beliefs, traditions.

Fantastic historic centre only too many tourists and too many Peruvian people who want to sell you any stuff!. good destination and lots of things and interesting places in the surrounding!! Don't take the citu tour bus because you can arrnage may things in a better and cheaper way. For example ride a horse and go to Sacsayhuamain, very nice and cgheap and small groups!!
Travel back in time. Travel back in time and in Cusco's present. Come in June preferably the weekend before June 21 to experience the vibrance of Cusco as they usher in the Inti Raymi or sun festival
Neat place. The spanish architecture is always interesting to me, especially the copious amounts of gold in the cathedrals, the plaza was well kept, neat to pass through.
Just soak it up. Fascinating city. We were there for the sun festival so loads going on. Allow lots of time but acclimatise first
Parade. Ran into a Cusco celebration that encompassed 12 hours of festival and parades. The next day they celebrated Inti Raymi (Quechua for "sun festival").
THE BEST OPTION. Travel to cusco was my best desicion, i did the famous free walking tour and the experience was faboulous

center of the city. We stayed in Plaza de Armas because it was close to all the restaurants, banks, stores, and it was really convenient. We were in walking distance of everything, and every day there was a festival or procession in the middle of the plaza.

Crazy. The winter solstice celebrations are going on and the place is wild. Dancers everywhere each with their own band. Plaza is pax
Caked with both tourists and locals. Everyone is having a great time.
Lovely place to visit . It's a very beautiful part of the city with the cathedral there. We were also there when a festival was being held so we loved to see all the traditional dancing

A great place to relax and get a feel for the area. We spent two days before and after our trek to Machu Picchu in the Historical District of Cusco and loved it. Shopping is a blast and the food options are endless. We toured the Cathedrals and got a great lesson on the Spanish influence on the locals. Check out the Museo Inka for the Pre-Spanish history. It's just a block uphill from Plaza de Armas.
Interesting old town. Lovely to wander thru the old town- the main market is a block away and has a wonderful array of food and other products. Worth the walk!

Loving our time in Cusco . There is so to see! We are loving exploring through all the nooks and crannies of Cusco. The Inkan walls are just amazing. We spent one day so far exploring Cusco and seems like we've barely scratched the surface.
Must see!. Great time shopping and taking photographs of the beautiful architecture. There are a lot of hidden markets on the side streets and tucked in alleys! Explore! Explore! Explore!
Tour. A lot of shopping there with great old and new cultures and street performers. Rest restaurants and shops. We spent s lot of time there shopping and walking around.

Not to be missed. We found the best of Cusco to be the historical center and few sites close to the town.The Plaza Del Armes holds some beautiful churches, an outstending Cathedral, the Koricancha Temple or the picturesque colonial houses around.

quite crowdy. very nice spot buit we spend there jst few minutes was crowdy and almost everybody wants to sale you any kind of tours and services, bus fore to be for a while and see the architecture was great
If you have to. Maybe it was our guide, maybe we were jet lagged...but we spent way too much time at this site. My mother left tour half way through and so did two other people.
Wonderfull. a great experience the wonder of the Andes and a very memorable holiday. Thank you very much for all the people of the city of Cusco
So enjoyed strolling this historical area. I only wish that we had more time to explore the city and the historic sites. So interesting, great restaurants and great vibe

Loved the historic central district. Fantastic experience and beautiful cathedrals. People are friendly, excellent dining and shopping. The Corpus Christi event was a wonderful bonus we hadn't planned to see. Wish we could have stayed longer.

Coolest City I've been to. Cusco is rich with history and I wish I could've stayed longer to see it all. The clash of architecture between Inca and Spanish Colonial buildings is like nowhere else in the world.
Amazing city. Cusco city is amazing you will find a lot of plsces to visit evn in the city, take your time to explore the city
always love the square in Cusco. we really enjoy sitting in the square and watching the people go by. there are many great shops and places to eat as well

Great city. Loved the place , we were there in a festival and enjoyed the dancing .
Historic sites and lots of shops in the old city .
Worth the time. Enjoyed wandering around the square. The cathedral is beautiful. Lots of shops, restaurants. Kids dancing in the streets, part of festival.

Charming Plaza. The central plaza is a charming place of Spanish colonial architecture. Visit cathedrals. People watch. Shop quaint shops. Buy expensive alapaca apparel (buyer beware - much better prices at artesian markets). Lots of cafes and restaurants - even an Irish pub and Starbucks.

One of the best cities in SA. Just a lovely place. Lovely people, good food, culture and history at every turn. I loved Cusco. Get lost in the local market, browse the tourist markets and get all your souvineers here - theyre some of the best in SA and very well priced. Try your first whole guinea pig here! Watch the local festivals and dances in these squares. Enjoy!
History comes alive. Fascinating archeological site! I was impressed with engineering skills of the Inca and glad to know this site is being protected

The Centre of Cusco is full of history but is not stuffy. Cusco displays its history in almost every building. There are Inca walls everywhere, some were incorporated long ago into Spanish religious buildings and some more recently into business and commercial properties. Therefore, it is not unusual to find an Inca wall within a modern restaurant. Being an old Inca settlement, Cusco attracted, Spanish settlers and so is full of churches, cathedrals and abbeys etc. Today it is the ideal base for exploring the Sacred Valley and so has developed into a modern city. However, the centre retains an a lovely feel with large open squares surrounded by stunning buildings.
Worth to spend time. We loved in particular the religious arts cabinet next to the cathedral. Great display of works of art of outstanding Quality.

Just beautiful. What a spectacular area to visit and stay! We were so in awe of this beautiful part of Cusco, close proximity to restaurants, markets and bars. Our only criticism is that we wished we had known how lovely our stay would be as we would have planned a longer visit.
The place you want to be. This is where the action is. Lots of restaurants, families enjoying the park and local activities. We saw parades and dancing in the streets

Layers of beauty. A super fun and safe place to walk around, people watch, eat and shop. Beautiful. The only small downside is constantly being approached to buy something or take a picture with a local. My advise is (that I mastered by day two): don't look at them, shake your head, say no, and continue doing whatever it was you were doing. Seems rude but trust me, it is super annoying and unless you want to buy a lot of little crappy paintings or whatever, you don't want to engage every 3 minutes.

A truly lovely plaza. This was a wonderful place to sit, people watch and just taken in the colonial ambience. We had the additional to good fortune to be there for Corpus Christi and watch the procession of saints around the plaza.

Great Area to Stay in Cusco. Great proximity to Plaza de Armas, lots of great restaurants and markets and activities during the stay in Cusco. There are many churches and museums in the area. Many hostels or hotels to choose from and pretty much any of the top attractions are within walking distance.

Pitoresc town. Great and colorful town. You can rest on a bench in central square, or walk through the beautiful streets, or eat a pizza or something local, like "chichiarone". But don't forget that the town is located at 3.300 m above sea level.

Taking in the sites. This was one place that our tour guide lead us on our walk around Cusco. It was a bustling city and many interesting shops and outdoor stands to view. Truly enjoyed the architecture, numerous churches, and other sites.

Loved Cusco. At first I was not sure what to expect from Cusco or any other big city in Peru. Luckily we stayed very central and we could walk to all the main attractions. There was a cultural festival on the days we stayed in Cusco and is was very colourful with lots of people dancing in their beautiful traditional clothing. I felt safe the whole time but I have to say that we didn't go out in the dark. Cusco is very beautiful city and I loved it.
History. Culture and relaxation. Nice to walk around day and night. Beautiful scenery. Locals very friendly and patient.
many thigns to do. the plaza and churches are very nice and there are plenty of dining/drinking and shopping places closeby

Watch your pockets here. We asked a policeman how to walk there from a few blocks away and he advised us to watch our pockets. It us a dry beautiful and picturesque place with lots of free entertainment and absolutely swarming with military and police on every corner.we felt safe but we come from major metropolitan areas. Our guide told us there is no organized crime in Cusco and we asked why. He said they had all moved to Lima. I see his point.

Plaza Armas is a nice place to walk around. in Plaza Armas there are lots of restaurants to choose from and other stores/tour operators. Watch out for the solicitation from all the sellers in the plaza!
Wonderful experience. Nice place to start city tour. Very colorful and vibrating during city celebrations and holidays. With lot of shops, money exchange offices and touristic offices.

Great for an afternoon stroll. Centre Historico de Cusco is not to be missed for its buildings, shops and restaurants around the periphery of the main square.It is also a good starting point and focus for exploring the hinterland and usually, viewing the exhibitions and events that take place there.

An eclectic mix of new and old. I never expexted Cusco to be as it was, I was amazed by all the colonial sites and possibilities of visiting. An interesting town full of stories, must see, don't miss out on your visit to Peru.

It's more for tourists but I love how they cleaned up this place and make it looks nice. This area is the central plaza of Cusco city. They obviously more police here and the floor are very clean. Compare with other parts of the city, this is more westernized. Different bars surround the plaza. One more thing I noticed the place is they make McDonald really cool! I barely noticed that's McDonald! So does Starbucks. If you spend one or two night here, you can stroll around the plaza and enjoy some tourist playing music, if you are luck!
Lots to do. There is lots to do around the central square in Cusco. Lots of museums, churches, restaurants and shops. We came back a few times to enjoy the scene.

Lively plaza in the center of Cusco. The historic center of Cusco was originally designed for Inca royalty, though there is little to remind us today of that pre-Columbian history. What we find today is a Spanish-style plaza with two Catholic churches dominating the scene and a quadrangle of shops and restaurants all around the plaza.

Awesome place to watch the time pass. A beautiful spot in Cusco where you can easily spend a couple of hours, just watching people going by. Sometimes, there will be some annoying street sellers, but not a big problem. The sorrounding old buildings are great photo spots as well.
Great area to visit. Beautiful and clean area. Always lots going on there for tourists. Very safe as there are regular Police as well as Tourist Police patrolling

Wonderful. Having spent time in Spain and then the last few weeks focused on the inca civilisation it was fascinating to see a Spanish colonial city. Beautiful setting against the landscape, a good feel and marvellous buildings. We were fortunate to strike the Corpus Christi parade. each Saint was carried out from the cathedral and processed around the plaza with accompanying brass bands. One of the most amazing festivals I have ever seen.
Lively centre with interesting history. Spent an interesting day looking at the historical buildings, colourful market and watching the locals play volleyball.

Everything happens here. You will visit or at least see this place almost every day. Many tour agencies, hotels, restaurants are near this place. Also, there are a lot of different activities can be seen, such as parade of indigenous people. Typical photo can be taken too. Especially beautiful at night too.

nice to have been visiting here. this place again make us remember the first time i was here without my family...it all has been changed a lot for a commercial purpose but at the same time more adapted to mass tourism with infraestructure.

Music, high energy, during Corpus Christi celebration.. We happened to be staying in Cusco for the two day celebration of Corpus Christi, when there were thousands in and around the square, with continuous music, food, and people out and about in traditional clothing. Very exciting mix of Catholic and Incan traditions.

We walked here from Economy Inn. Wonderful Cathedrals, Churches, Convents, Art from 14th to 16th century magnificently preserved, Peruvian Culture showplace, excellent Peruvian craft and textile market, don't miss it

True center of the city!. We stayed in Cusco for 2 days before our maiden adventure..Saklantay trek. This is the heart of the city. Lots of restaurant around the area including evening farmers market.

Beautiful but Touristy . Though this main center is stunning and jaw dropping it is extremely touristy and people selling tours, massages and various souvenirs are aggressive. They hit you at every corner and it gets a little frustrating. Besides that it is worth seeing. Think of it as the Paris or Venice of Peru.
beautiful city. YES YES YES!! its all well worth it as long as you don't get antitude sickness... beautiful city centre
Great location to sit. I just love sitting here in the Plaza and watching everyone go by. if you are not in a hurry - just have a seat and enjoy the view of how beautiful this city is

Awesome. I had the most wonderful experience here in Peru, all the service was incredible, my tour guide was pretty friendly. I really loved the experience that I had with this travel agency KARIKUY TOURS PERU. It was AWESOME!
Very Interesting. As in most South American cities, the historical center is the place to be to get a feel for the area and enjoy people watching. This is also true in Cusco.

Just a great place to chill. We walked around here many times and enjoyed sitting on a bench and watching everything and everyone. This is a nice place to hang out. There are tour vendors who will take "no" for an answer, you may also be approached by shoe polishers and other vendors but they are polite.
