Pass through it for a look . You won't avoid the central square if you are in Cusco. It is somewhat pretty. Nice enough to get a coffee and people watch for a while. It's pretty much a tourist trap, with street vendors, restaurants, travel companies, 'masseuses' etc. all vying for your dollars. Be careful of the erratic traffic on one side of the square - it isn't all pedestrianised. It has the quirky feature of two cathedral type buildings in close proximity. Has a number of good eateries and coffee shops close by.

Lovely old city centre, full of character. Interesting architecture and just a nice city to walk around in general. Felt very safe too, even at night (as a solo travelling female speaking). Loved all the small craft shops and the winding alleys.

This IS Cuzco - you must be here to appreciate it. This is the zocolo, or main square, of the town. Nonstop nightlife, lots of shops and restaurants, souvenir sellers, and a small park-like area in the center make this a charming place to visit and one that is not to be missed. Plenty of nice police officers patrol the area, and fellows, most of them are gorgeous women. There is a lot of selection here, and it is an excellent opportunity to experience a vital part of the most-visited city on the entire continent of South America. You will see women and girls in traditional Andean garb, some carrying a small lamb or leading an alpaca. Be warned that they expect you to PAY them to take a photo, and are persistent about this.
Lively main square. Great place to sit in a bar up high and watch the world go by. We saw 3 parades in 2 days. There is something to see or do at each side of the square.

Prepare to be accosted . Beautiful and picturesque, full of historical information. Churches have odd hours for visitation, make sure to inform yourself.Kids with baby Llamas, cute yes... until they force you to take a picture with them and charge you 2 soles per kid. Don't bother sitting on a bench to try and enjoy the atmosphere, you will be bombarded by street vendors.
Comfortable Place!. Very nice place, amazing restaurants, old construction to visit and a very nice museums around. Don´t miss your coca tea as soon as you arrive!

Must see for any visitor to sense the beauty of this city. Spent less time in the city than in the sacred valley, but the churches and colonial structures are marvelous whether original with restoration or preserved

It's central - to everything!. Walking through this plaza is like taking a step back in time. Life continues here much as it has over the centuries. With the cathedral being the primary anchor and the focus of visual attention, everything else is built up to surround the main square.All sorts of shops and restaurants occupy the old buildings around the plaza, with balconies overlooking all of the happenings there. For an extra adventure, explore some of the narrow side streets or back alley markets. You never know where they may lead or what you may discover.The square itself attracts all sorts of life. Tourists, locals, students, street vendors and others all collect in this beautiful space. It just buzzes with energy….and more than a handful of stray, but friendly, dogs.The street vendors are everywhere and are very persistent. I heard a lot of people complain about them but, from my perspective, these folks are just trying to make a living. If you go with the flow and are open to the experience (and like to haggle a bit), you can really enjoy the experience.
cusco. thanks Mountain Expeditions Peru for the great experience, in my heart is Cusco.everything was perfect, the guide, transport ...etc.etc... perfect
Talk About Drama. To think of the Inca capital leveled and reconceived as three squares surrounded by Spanish colonial buildings. Especially the cathedral. I have never seen so much silver!
Beautiful!!. Walking down Centro Historico is a wonderful experience, artistic buildings, welcoming locals and beautiful weather, if you go at the right time
Great Plaza and all of the action.. Great historical plaza with two historic churches and original restaurants. Ensure that you come back at night as the lights, music, and energy are great.
Is worth it. Is nice safe and so many things to do and see around don't be afraid to do it and also many stores to buy souvenirs
Pretty city with pretty buildings. Nice city in Peru to visit, apart from it being a sort of transportation hub to go to Machu Pichu. Ya esta!
discovering Cusco. Wondeful historical buildings, bu t the better is by walking discover small peaceful places, wonderful views and original stores
A modern stone age city. One of the best and most walkable cities in the world, just remember you are at a very high altitude!
Beautiful . Beautiful view, a great place to just sit and do some people watching! There are plenty of restaurants around and you can pay with credit cards! It's beautiful both day and night.

A must for any trip to Cusco. It's a superb place, with lots to do in the area. The cathedrals are beautiful with an interesting mix of different cultures. Be aware, you can't enter during mass and men need to wear long pants. Get ready to be harassed though, by the many street vendors. That was my only negative comment. The area is also in a great location for various restaurants. Including many that are rated as the top restaurants on trip advisor. Definitely a must.

Nice but.... The centre itself is pretty nice but many others in South America are nicer. What takes away from the enjoyment of the place is the constant (and I mean contant) pestering of people offering massages, paintings, a picture with their llama, various tours, something to eat, jewellery or my favourite a timber owl. It just gets a bit much after a few days.

Beautiful city with lovely architecture.. Cusco has a stunning central area with the cathedrals in the main square really standing out. The entrance fees to these cathedrals is pretty pricey though so we didn't bother going in as churches tend to look quite a like anyway. The centre is full of cute little shops selling typical souvenirs targeted at tourists as well as many lovely little restaurants and cafes.Paddys Irish bar just off the main square is good for food and a drink to possibly celebrate the end of the inca trail or Jacks restaurant is lovely for food also but this isn't on the square.Cusco lacks things to do within the city however and really just serves as a cute base for exploring the ruins etc outside.

Amazing small language barrier. This town is historic, beautiful, stunning and friendly. However I found learning about things tough and finding my way around a struggle to purely because of the language barrier. How ever I would return in a heart beat beautiful place

lovely town. Prepare for high altitude. A very important town in Peru. Historically, the center of Inca Civilization. Perfect IPAD recorded interactive tour on site of the main church. Safe for public.
Interesting 1 hour walking tour. No worries here with interesting things to look at and photograph.Pretty little town with heaps of really interesting Inca history.

A nice main square but Cusco is not great compared with rest of the world and Peru. We were there for the end of school year festivities with thousands crowding the main square -- looked like they would parade, but not much happened. We observed for quite a while from the second floor window of a café facing the square and then moved on. In general, Cusco is a base, but there are much better places in the Sacred Valley and in Peru to visit

Nice with lots to do.. We stayed in the area for two nights and walked through the square many time, I don’t think you can get in the cathedral but it has an impressive outlook. The square its self has plenty of shops and restaurants. Well work a visit.
Love the square!. very festive and fun...always bustling with positive energy...lots of souvenir sellers and food places

Gorgeous with a lot to see and do!. We walked down from our hostel (on Choquechaca) and were not expecting such an amazing square right in the center. Coming from La Paz and Rio, we were blown away by what we saw. Quaint yet very charismatic when we visited. Really gorgeous and a lot to see. We felt safe and it is very touristy. The area itself has a lot of shops and tiny markets and restaurants for you to walk around. We had fun walking around for half a day shopping and getting food and snacks for our trip up Machu Picchu.

Very nice and it has a nice atmosphere! . It's very nice. You feel like you walking in a modern " ruin" Perfectly safe also. Lots to see and to do. Nice shops and restaurants. Actually it is very touristy. You see more tourist than locals.
😁
Nice central square. The central square is dominated by two large churches and many souvenir shops and restaurants. There are a few good coffee shops where you can watch the world go by.
Cusco Travels. The streets were very clean and the scenery was gorgeous. I felt safe as there was a police presence in the area for safety. Children were very well behaved and people were friendly.

Interesting city center. The main plaza de armas is great to walk around. There is a starbucks there for some quick coffee and wifi. There is also a Mcdonalds and KFC for my fast food american eaters.

Great plave to take in the culture. We loved hanging out here and people watching. Ate at two charming restaurants with great food and get a taste of Cusco. Visiting the square was one of the highlights of our trip.
just 5 minutes walk. Just 5 minutes walk from Tika Wasi Casa Boutique, you will get to plaza de armas. You can go to museum, cathedral, cafe, shopping.

Impressive Square. I visited here with my wife. The view surrounded by the old cathedrals, historic architectures with corridors and mountains having numerous red-brown colored historic houses on their slopes was fantastic.
This square had been totally safe even in the night.
The square is must-visit place for all the tourists.

centro Historico De Cusco. lovely charming place . beware of tourist traps like people selling tours etc. the starbucks is very cute. the shopping is very good
I loved the fountain . a place to spend a good time relaxing and soaking in the city's charm

Nice Town. beautiful place to relax with a family, fun option for meals, very friendly people in the town and fabulous hotels.
definitely I will recommend to anyone.
It is fantastic. It is only in america Latin With great it tells the history for a big country in wealth And his very nice people his very rich food in variety

Allot of paint and massage sellers. Nice clean square with a beautiful statue in the middle. You will hear constantly massage or hello my friend wil you buy some paintings from me. But I think that is on every touristic place. Allot really touristic restaurants but there are a few good ones. For example Inka grill looks really expensive but it is with good service and nice Peruvian dishes.There is a Starbucks around the corner with good coffee and fast wifi if you need to search something online.
Lovely!. Beautiful! The church is amazing and awesome!Nice shops and restaurants around. Also money exchange spots :)

The centre of the old town contains lots of reataurants and interesting buildings, particularly around the main squaref. If you have a hotel located in the old town it is great to stroll round during the evening, to browse in the shops and eat in one of a number of excellent restaurants serving local dishes.The cathedral is well worth a visit and spending some time in. We got to know the centre by a guided walking tour.

Wonderful town for wandering. We stayed in Cusco for two days, as part of a South America tour. Some of our party were suffering with altitude sickness, so could not make it on the city centre tour, even though we had several days around Cusco to acclimatize. Cathedral and market areas are definitely worth the visit, and the central old streets, with evidence of the Inca buildings, are fascinating. Definitely somewhere worth seeing.
amazing little town. great town to wander around in and feels like its steeped in history but be careful of your belongings ,lots of stories of pick pockets and phone theft

Sooooo beautiful :) . I really really love the Centro Historico. The Plaza is one of the most beautiful places in Peru. Also, Cusco is quite safe compared with other places in Peru. Is you visit Machu Picchu, don't forget to allocate a couple of days also to explore Cusco.

spend some days in this impressive spot!. We visited Cusco already some years ago, but I saw Peru passing by and I wanted to describe our delight in spending a week in Cusco. We arrived there in order to get acclimatized, bt stayed on to take some Spanish lessons before continuing our trip from Peru to Bolivia. The big central plaza of Cusco is worth hanging around in as all of daily Cuscan life takes place here. Watching the people and having an drink or coffee, or even having dinner there was one of our great pleasures.
Beautiful!. Must see the cathedral and the Last Supper painting with Jesus eating guinea pig and having chicha to drink. One of the most beautiful churches I have been to

amazing town. I don't think you can beat this town for things to do. The buildings are so pretty. We had so much fun walking around and exploring the different streets. We felt very safe. Things are also pretty cheap so buy your gifts here.

Beautiful Architecture but Very Touristy. The history and architecture in Cusco is fascinating and the Plaza de Armas is beautiful, but it is very touristy. We were in Cusco for a few days, but our tour guide from Gutsy Women / OAT took our group outside the city most days to experience Peruvian culture. You can probably see everything in Cusco in a day or two. The shop salespersons and the hawkers in the plaza were irritating, but the food was delicious and the churches and temples were extraordinary.
a great show. When I arrived place of arms,it was crowded with tourists and locals,they celebrated sun festive,it was a traditional parade,a great show.

Amazing travel to a great culture!!!. You can´t go to Perú without visit Cusco.
The hispanic architecture is amazing. A lot of churches and the main Cathedral transporting you to another place on the earth. Also the food is really nice everywhere in town.
Cusco is a very enjoyable city that wont dissapoint to you.
Cusco has a lot to offer!. Lots to do and see in Cusco. Great nightlife, tons of good restaurants, museums, and some of the best tourist shopping in S America. I wish we'd stayed here longer!

Easily spend a few days here. There is so much to do and see around the historical center of Cusco. We spend 5 total days in 2 stays wandering and had lots of fun. Everything is within walking distance and there are several parks and squares to relax. The center is made up of several distinct areas and exploring them all is fun. We never felt unsafe wandering around, especially during the day.
Beautiful. Great place. Picture spot. Lots of restaurants in the area. Beautiful colonial buildings and churches.
Perfect vacation. Love Machu Pichu where life begins. People need to visit more of this places. I love Cusco, Peru. You need to be there. Love the people, love the place.

City with personality. Cusco is a city with great personality. The people, historical buildings and restaurants make it a great place to stop in.you can easily expend a week in Cusco and always there is something to do.

A lovely city. Cusco was the old capital of the Inca empire and very much based on the Spanish style of architecture. There are attractive pink tiled roofs, arcaded plazas and steep winding alleyways with churches and galleries in abundance. The city is filled with monuments and links with the Inca empire are everywhere. There is a local food market every morning which is well worth a visit and the city is filled with fantastic eateries and bars.
Love it !. Wonderful to hang around Cusco, with it cobble stone streets, the mixture of Spanish and Inca cultures.
Nice but simple. Great places with lot of vendors/tours agencies. Still, the center of cuzco is not as beauctiful as others cities like arequipa. The good thing is that you can find everything

cool old colonial town . the whole historic area is nice. we walked around at all goes of the day and night and felt safe the entire time. there are lots of old building and the architecture of them is amazing. take a city tour, it's worth the few bucks to learn about many of them.
One of the prettiest central squares in Latin America. Lovely for an evening walk, even if cold. Take a while in your schedule to visit this place and try to "get lost" in the nearby streets.

World class !. I loved this part of Cusco. It just oozes chatm.and character.
You can sit on the balcony of one of the many cafes or on a park bench and just absorbe the atmosphere.
Loved it !

On Top of the World! Stunning Gorgeous City.. We've traveled all over the World and Centro Cusco is now one of favorite places. It's super clean, beautiful architecture, lots of great places to eat and just a cool vibe. Loved chilling out here and soaking up the sun and sights.

Cleanness is an essential point. The historical center of Cusco is spectacular, I am not able to describe it in words. You have to see it with your own eyes. The streets and monuments are astounding. I mean, considering this was the capital of the Inca Empire (more than 400 years ago) the architecture and history within this city is great.Now it comes the bad part of it, the reason why I put a Poor rating to this place. It's sad because I love Cusco and wish the authorities could improve in this aspect. Lack of cleanness. You can see big amounts of trash (in plastic bags and not in them) every 200 meters or so. What is happening here? Dog poop is a serious issue too. Get rid of the dogs from here!. I have been in Cusco 3 or 4 times and this is the same :(
Amazing View!. Beautiful Churches all around. We had our kid and he had a blast taking pictures with baby "Llamas" Without any doubt a great place to start Cusco!

Beautiful, but take it easy the first day. We start taking diuretic pills (you can buy them in Lima also) one day before we arrive in Cusco. That day we followed the suggestion of eating light and resting for 2 hours before getting to know Cusco. And everything work great! At times it can feel very heavy, relax and slow down and everything should be fine. The city is very lively and beautiful. It is also clean. We visited the monuments and national parks that are very well kept. We ate very well and as usual Peruvians are the nicest people ever.
Prettiest at night. Be sure to include a stroll at night when the buildings are lit up & the squares seem to bustle with even more life!

Historical plaza. This plaza is especially beautiful and engaging at night. The dark hills above the city twinkle with the lights of homes high up in the hills, and the lighted statue of Jesus can be seen high above the city. Would give it a 5 rating, but the constant barrage of street peddlers was a distraction. A few are quite persistent, needing a very firm "no, gracias". No different than many cities I've visited, but a distraction nonetheless.

The Central Plaza is open and bright. We visited the central Plaza de Armas three times to enjoy the Cusco ambiance, visit the Cathedral and shop the perimeter. Probably should have investigated the side streets a bit more as they looked like a lot of fun. Just sitting in the center and watching the action can't be beat

Cathedrals, Shops, lively square. We enjoyed walking around the beautiful squares- everything from high-end shops for alpaca/vicuna items to opportunities for pictures with Andeans with goats and llamas- go and enjoy!
Interesting center. There is a few sights to see or visit but it's too touristy. Instead, try to get out of the center to feel the real vibes of the city and see the lives of the locals.
Cusco trip. Awesome place. Really beautiful sights. The churches are well preserved and the Plaza as well. You can walk around enjoying the scenery and just thinking about the Inca culture.

Cuzco is really fabulous!. Even though it is touristy somehow Cuzco rises above all of that. Sit on an upstairs balcony over the town center as the sun goes down and enjoy not only the ambiance but the views of the lights as they appear on the hills.
nice. all the cusco is beautifull i loved, thanks to my tour operator visit Peru and the most beautifull city was Cusco

Delightful plaza. The historical centre of Cuzco is based around the Plaza de Armas where the dominant feature is the magnificent cathedral. Other parts of this square are occupied by churches and numerous retail outlets (many of which are 'tourist traps" for the unwary). Although is a world heritage listed city centre, large multinational retail chains are disappointingly present. Nevertheless it is worth a visit.
The History is Incredible!. We loved the city center day tour as it showed us all of the amazing sights of Cusco. The history is just fascinating!
Beautiful. Amazing historic square with free tours. Beautiful scenery and full of culture. I miss waking up to Cusco.

Beautiful buildings, interesting sights and sounds. A lovely spot to sit and take in the culture, sights, sounds, and atmosphere of Cuzco. There are also lots of lovely little shops, restaurants and bars in the area to satisfy all tastes and budgets.Be prepared to be solicited frequently by a variety of people selling paintings, sweaters, hats, jewelry and souvenirs. In addition the goods sellers are the people trying to entice you into their restaurants. Although the solicitation is constant, most go away with a simple "no gracias".

Impressive historic architecture, but overly touristy.... This is a place of profound historic importance with each building telling us about the turbulent history of the region. To get the best out of your time here I'd strongly recommend working with a knowledgeable guide who can bring the place to life for you.There is however huge numbers of gift shops, tour shops, hostels etc ringing the city centre, and I was really surprised how "commercial" the place had become. If you want to see a more authentic slice of Cusco get outside the inner core.

Cusco is one of the most beautiful places in the world. I love Cusco. I go back over and over again (lived there in the 90s for a while and fell in love with it). It's my spiritual home. Wonderful people, wonderful things to see and do (too many to count), so much history, beautiful city to walk around - great restaurants, bars and nightlife (Peruvian food is fabulous as is Pisco Sour). Close to the Sacred Valley (for hillwalking, markets, local festivals, more site seeing, milder/less harsh climate) etc etc. But you don't even have to leave Cusco as there is so much to see and experience. Just the most wonderful, wonderful place!!
Cusco is a wonderful city. Great to walk around, I recommend hiring a guide and doing a city tour through the historic buildings.

Stunning town. This is a Wonderful old town to spend a few day. Lots of historical sites old streets,local markets and fun people. The locals are nice and welcoming. Bring candy for the kids there are a lot. Have fun.
Get lost!. Getting lost in the small historic streets of Cusco is a must! Nice bars, restaurants, churches and artist studios, besides a lot of nice pictures your camera will take!

Beautiful plaza if you can forget what happened here to the Incas. Beautiful plaza, filled with locals as well as tourists. Only downside is being constantly approached to buy one thing or another. That gets old fast.

Cusco imperial. Stroll through the historic center of Cusco, is a journey in time. The imperial city of the Incas submitted by the Castilian troops and missionary resisted, the urban structure remained in force

An elegant vibrant town - great!. With aspects of hill towns like Keswick and the renaissance style of Lucca - it is fair to say I like Cusco!I know it is touristy and the outskirts are very poor but i still like it

Delightful Plaza. The plaza and historical neighborhood in the center of Cusco is delightful. There are numerous interesting structures to see including the cathedral. It is also wonderfully alive with outdoor theatre and music. Do not visit Cusco without touring the plaza and nearby neighborhood.

Beautiful square. The historic centre of Cusco is beautiful. The main square is surrounded by two large churches and many shops and restaurants. The middle of the square is a beautiful park and fountain.There always seems to be some type of festivity or parade going on. This trip I saw a parade on my first day, two days latter there was a massive demonstration that shut the city down for two days and tonight there was a big fiesta with firework and bands.
EXCELLENT!!!. beutiful especially at night so much history and ambiance, everybody around is friendly great place to visit with friends, family or by yourself, it's a place to enjoy.

CUSCO, Centro Historico. Wow... so many museums, so many cathedrals. It's difficult to do everything in Cusco in less than a week. The historic district alone is a couples days worth of art, history and culture. Oh, and the chocolate muesem. Go there. Now.

Wonderful. City,the central area of Cusco is ideal for people watching and also the dogs !!!The main square is lovely ,benches to sit and rest after wandering around the city.There is a very friendly atmosphere with locals going about there business and tourists enjoying themselves .Many restaurants around the square to eat or stop and have a drink .
Beautiful plaza. Wonderful place to shop and eat. Nice for strolling and relaxing. Very active at night. Beautiful cathedrals.
All the Shopping and Museums you Would Want. Whether it is restaurants, culture, shopping, people watching or hotels, the Central District has it all.

Beautiful!. Really nice, beautiful and defiantly recommend place to spend at least 3 days! There are a lot of things to do in the center, but also just hanging out on the main square or walking up to the Christo Blanco is one of the bests i did!

Impressed - as good as mass tourism gets. I didn't expect Cusco to be so full of tourists. But then about 2000 visit Machu Picchu every day and almost all of them stop over in Cusco. The big surprise was that despite all the tourist shops and everything, the Centro Historico was REALLY interesting and kept some authentic atmosphere. Lots of surprisingly good restaurants gives you such a vast choice of affordable places for lunch and dinner. Trips to the archaeological sites are easy to do and mostly well worth it.

Lots to see and do. The centre of Cusco is buzzing all day. There are lots of street markets and activities. I would particularly recommend the Inca Museum (uphill to left as you face the facade of the Cathedral) Also worth a visit is the San Pedro market which has lots of local colour and wher you could buy virtually anything, including some grst food

BETWEEN MOUNTAINS AND CLOWDS. Cusco is a beautiful colonial city, with an elevation of 3,400 meters. It has a Spanish and Quechua mixture and influence. Inside the city you can visit beautiful Catholic churches and ruins of Incas buildings of the XV century. The historic district is fascinating.

A great place to people watch and take in the cultural attractions. The only thing that would have made our numerous visits here during our stay would have been fewer street peddlers trying to sell you their wares every few minutes. It is still worth it to spend time here and while you are at it buy a tourist ticked to visit the museums. To visit the church museums cost additional but it is still worth it.

Surprising city!. We did not think that this city was going to be of interest until we were there resting before going to Machu Picchu. We loved it. The colorful people, the gorgeous town square, the food and our hotel make this a wonderful spot. We highly recommend taking a tour of the city which will take you to the amazing cathedral. It is truly a sight to see. But also good to have a guide who can explain the sights.

Enjoyable area to enjoy the evening.. We enjoyed evening walks through the plaza, stopping by small shops, and enjoying a drink or meal. The area is very safe and relaxing so feel free to find a place to sit and enjoy the beautiful Spanish architecture
Tourist centre. Got onto a free walking tour which made exploring the area more interesting. Google 'free walking tour of peru'
Meh. Cusco is just ok. The buildings are nice, plaza is large. Lots of locals pushing their crafts. Expected more.
European Prague in a small scale. Romantic, alive, authentic, UNESCO World Heritage in the Peruvian Andes, the capital of the Inca empire

Take your time to walk around and feel the history frozen in time. A completely unique city, sights and architecture you won't forget and history within every stone you'll come upon. Take your time to walk around and visit as many landmarks as you can. Unlike several other places in Peru sometimes you feel this place has frozen in time for you to experience its ancient culture and it's just marvelous.

Beautiful. Our Peruvian trip would not have been complete without our having explored this lovely square. The side streets are laden with interesting vendors and shops while the main square is surrounded by restaurants and shops. We enjoyed great views from one second floor restaurant on the square along with delightful food. Looking down, we could see weddings at the churches, a parade and the colorful women and children offering to pose for pictures. This scene is marvelous and filled with the lovely people who make Peru so special.

European Charm in South America!. I absolutely loved that area of Cusco. The city center reminded me a lot of a few cities I had visited in Europe in the past 10 years. There is such a charm and atmosphere there that reminds me of Europe. It definitely exceeded my expectations of Cusco and was such a romantic area to walk around!

Really pretty town. Really nice little town. Although the 'headline' sights are definitely Machu Picchu and the Sacred Valley, the town is very ornate and holds its own. Cathedral is worth visiting. Also it is exceptionally clean and they close off parts of the road to make sure pedestrians have good access across the square. Very impressive.

Wonderful place to take in the views and people watch.. I enjoyed walking around this central area of Cuzco for four days. There were parades happening on multiple days and a real sense of pride by the locals.
A must visit in Cuzco. A beautiful Colonial Plaza, full of life. The surroundings comprising the Museo del Inca, the Cathedral and churches should not be missed.

Beautiful old city. I enjoyed walking around this ancient and charming city. It's plenty of churches, museums, stores, restaurants. We hired a private guide to go to the ruins around the city, it was worth it!

Incredible Architecture and People . While wandering the ancient streets on Centro Cusco you cant help but be inspired by the old stone walkways with stone walls. The plaza with its delicious restaurants, fine shopping, and magnificent churched. You can stop and get your picture taken for a few dollars with the local woman and baby alpacas. Yes I did that. Enjoy yourself, walk around, and explore. This part of the city has many hidden gems.
Beautiful city!. A beautiful city with ancient history. We visited the churches, markets and restaurants. The most generous people.

Beautiful. I gave myself a walking tour - much more enjoyable than the guided tour because I had some time to myself. Highly recommend the market! I drank wonderful juice - again! Amazing place to visit.

Very interesting and fun to walk around. Great photo opportunities.. We were here on two different days. One time we spend about 4 hr walking around, popping into stores and restaurants and churches, eating lunch, people watching, etc. the second time we hired a guy to take us on a foodie tour. It was great seeing many of he same places but having someone present the history of the people and the buildings and tell us what we were eating. I think I would recommend a small tour and then spend time walking and wandering the streets. We very much enjoyed our visit and will go back again.
Too much te see!!!. There are so many awesome features that it's never enough. The tour guide could make a difference. Ours was good.

VG. Cuzco is one of the most charming Spanish colonial cities in South America. It has it all ! It has a great sense of history, super shopping, and world class hotels. This part of time adds to the charm.

Very beautiful area!. Very beautiful area. Would recommend to have lunch at the restaurant around the Plaza with a balcony to look over this beautiful plaza. Check out at night also, it's really beautiful and safe around here....

A beautiful place. It's a very interesting place, with a lot of historical buildings, very good restaurants. I recommend at least three days there plus one day to Machu Picchu and another day to Vale Sagrado.
Great day out. Plenty of bars, restaurants that are reasonable with good food, plenty of sights and museums to visit with a parade every Sunday.

Great place to walk around while acclimating. Beautiful area, and lots of great historical sites to see. Be prepared, as there will be many locals trying to sell you paintings and other items, and some are aggressive about it. This is a very tourist-y location.

Take the time to take it all in. Take in all of the churches and interesting architecture. This is a great place to start in Cusco. Take it slow and adjust to the high altitude, if you go too fast you could do yourself some real harm.
Breathtaking!. This main square is breathtaking, the blue skies along with nice white clouds, the architecture and the culture makes cusco's center a must for all visitors.
Amazing history. The history is great in this city. Stop by this place - it's beautiful inside. There's great places to eat around here and it's easy to walk to from most places.
Great starting point. An easy walk around area of history from Incan and Spanish pasts. Great place to start the Incan/ Spanish journey within Peru.

More fun and interesting than I ever expected.. Cusco is a great town to walk in. Take in the sites, eat the food, and adjust to the altitude! They have several churches to view, along with Inca ruins spread throughout the city.

Beautiful Place!!!. It is very nice, lots of churches and cathedrals. Very cultural of Peru. Nice surroundings, clean and lots of flowers. Safe with police always around. Nice places to eat nearby and the perfect spot to eat or drink in the balconies in front of the main plaza. Love it!

Magic city . I fell in love with Cusco. Mostly with his people. We met our taxi driver Alfredo what a person. Punctual he knew about the incas history show us around and we walked in Cusco plaza de Armas, it's churches and surrounding area is just plain beautiful

Worth a visit!. Very well conservated, the centre of Cusco is Amazing!
Surrounded by beautiful churches and buildings. Be careful, pickpocketers are not uncommon here, and dont leave your things anywhere, they are faster than you!

Places des Armes - the centre point of Cusco. Buzzing and colourful, lots of shopping and restaurants nearby, fiestas and demonstrations about, was able to see local artisans in action, a great place to sit in the sunshine and watch the world go by, booked the tourist bus here.
The people hangout!. This is were a lot of action is during the day and night. I went here during both for people watching and cheap souvenirs.

One of the most beutiful places at Peru. Cusco is one of the most beutiful and interesting cities of peru. It is a city to walk around, to look into the orners and to discover interesting things to buy, to eat, to know. Plaza de Armas is huge and beutiful, the center of the city. Every Sunday at 10:00 AM there is a event related to the flag rise. On the other hand, there are plenty of historical attranctions such as the Cathedral, and Coricancha just a few minutes walking. It is a must to go place!!!!

Beautiful . I had an amazing time walking around Cusco's Historic Centre! It is beautiful, there is lots to see! I really liked the architecture of the houses! Usually dont visit churches but I am glad that I visited Cusco's cathedral, recommend it!

Where Tourists and Locals Mingle. New to the city? This is the hub of everything and all roads in Cusco seem to lead you here. It's perfect for people watching and you'll be in a tourist friendly area to catch festivals, parades, and trinkets. It's close to everything you didn't know you needed like Starbucks and an Irish pub if you're less than adventurous. You can go into the church or you can sit on the steps and absorb culture. The choice is yours and it's wonderful!

Lovely historical district. Very cool place. This is one of the bigger cities in Peru, and it still contains so many old and historical buildings and squares. It's very nice to walk around and just enjoy the views and watch the locals. Be prepared to be bombarded with people trying to sell you everything from hats to walking sticks to paintings. it's a little annoying at times, but don't let that stop you from going.

Historical Cusco. Very interesting site to see while in Cusco. We were on a tour of the city so it was quite informative. Lovely gardens. Note: no photos allowed inside the church. It looked like some nice shops around the square but we did not have time to stop.

Hıstorıcal. From the balcony of a first floor bar I watched the Festival of Antiryma, the Condor. The residents of the outlying villages arrived in their "Condor" feathers and paraded around the hıstoric square. A Peruvian festival, complete with fıreworks and colourful costumes, is not to be missed

The centre of the action.. This is where everyone gathers throughout the day to sit and watch passers by, get a shoeshine, window shop for beautiful baby alpaca sweaters or choose from a variety of good traditional restaurants. There are often bands playing or demonstrations of handicrafts or children making flower decorations on the cobbles to mark some festival. Sellers of all sorts of things (textiles, braids, jewellery, art work and toys) ask you to look at their wares but are never pushy.
Very old and beautiful. Very beautiful 10 sole's to see inside worth it. No pictures inside but so beautiful you just feel your in a sacred place.
Nice place to visit. The square is a great place to see cusco and it's goings on. The church and buildings are nice on their own but the various peoples and activiites make the square interesting.

Lovely buildings. We enjoyed walking round the main centre of Cusco, there are some beautiful old buildings as well as some wonderful little side streets to explore. Plenty of photo opportunities but also plenty of opportunities to get ripped off in the shops and restaurants on the main square!
Awesome!. this is a great place to walk around and go to the market! for 4 soles you can have an amazing meal. Also, it's just great to chill out!
A great place to visit. Cusco is a beautiful town with many interesting and fascinating places to visit. Nice restaurants, interesting cathedral and many ancient sites surrounding Cusco
Beautiful great atmosphere. beautiful plaza. great to seat on the garden around and look on the view. the cathedral is beautiful and very interesting to visit.Dont skip on a guide inside.
Worth the visit. Great architecture, fresh air, open space, friendly people and good food. A lot of markets with handcrafted items

Cisco plaza. Beautiful and interesting place, it is like the old Spain plaza area.This is the center where you can relax and just do
nothing but look at the people around you,people watching.

The heart of Cusco. Lots to see and do in this area. The Catholic church, the park with the fountain below Pachacutec's statue, restaurants and shops, cobbled streets, 3 star hotels and museums in private homes in smaller plazas adjacent to the main one, craft market and just people watching. Arrived in the late afternoon and saw the place transform at night with lights and evening strollers. The Museum of Pre-Columbian Art is a great find and so is the Limo restaurant on the same side of the Catholic Church.

Peaceful. This place is very peaceful, is quiet big, its always clean, is very nice to sit there em relax for few minutes, because we can see the locals walking, going to work the normal life. We can see the Cathedral and some museums.
Bring memory cards for all the pictures you'll want to take.. I stayed a just downhill of the San Blas church, which is south of the historic center, absolutely beautiful, and original.
Nice day. Touristy off course but nice to walk around. We didn't need a lot of time and had a nice relaxing day in the city.

Amazing! . Perfect for long walks, you'll find nice cafés, museums, churches, stores where you can buy some souvenirs and restaurants to try some local food. Don't forget to take some time to enjoy life and sightsee at plaza de armas.

Subversive art in church. Visit the cathedral with a guide to see how the Inca/Ketchwan craftsmen subtly subverted the Catholic imagery of their Spanish conquerors, by depicting key characters and concepts using their own culture and religion
Cuzco ciudad. Fantastic place to spend an aftgernoon, a day, or as long as you want; plenty to see; beauty and history at the tip of your fingers
Very nice. Cusco lives up to it's reputation as a lovely city. Many interesting areas to explore, good places to eat, good places, good shops.
The Heart of Cusco. Cusco is a great town featuring juxtapositions of Incan and Spanish cultures in their buildings. Must see en route to Chichen Itza!

Such a nice place!. Take time to walk in the small streets, to visit the market, to enter the shops and to talk to locals and you will discover a wonderful town which is very touristic but which can be authentic if you open the right doors...

Unique atmosphere!. Quaint historic centre. Lit up like a Christmas tree at night. Historic buildings in the centre. Fee for each building, however. Very safe to visit. Close to restaurants, kiosks, and cafes

Beautiful historic centre. Fountain, statue, and churches make it worthwhile to visit the centre. Unfortunately, you need to pay to see the interiors of all the churches. We didn't pay to enter. Many shops, smaller stores, and restaurants. It definitely feels like a tourist trap, sadly. Narrow streets, cobblestones lanes, and stairs lead you to other very safe places in the city. Little plazas and markets are dispersed within the city.
Spaniards and Incas. The center of Cusco is an interesting mix of Spaniard and Inca influence. The Spaniards were the Spanish colonists of centuries long ago.
Starting Point. Great place for starting your tour of The Sacred Valley with great view of the city around it. Good restaurants located throughout.

Highly recommended. The center of Cusco was built by the Spanish conquerors and is laid out with various plazas surrounded by churches and other colonial buildings. The cathedral is impressive inside and out, there are many restaurants and bars all around, and it is overall a wonder place to walk around, see the sights, and enjoy the food, drink, and people watching.

Charming and beautiful place. I really enjoyed visiting Cusco. In reality, historic Cusco. other than the ride to and from the airport, I didn't spend time in the rest of the city. But the historic town was a wonderful experience. Old buildings, charming squares, quaint streets, religious buildings with rich history and character, the colorful local market, the Inca ruins over the city. It is a wonderful place to spend a couple of days or more.Cusco is high - 3,500 meters above sea level high. For those flying in from sea level, reflect on whether you may need altitude medication to soften the impact on your body until you acclimate. Don't rush your first several days. It takes a couple of days to truly acclimate and enjoy your stay.
More than 3000 meters High.. Beautiful place. We sat and wait for sunset. A lot people around this place. We liked to seat in front of church and looking around of people , relax....
Nice place to relax. Very beautiful place to stop and look around for a little bit. The only downside was everyone trying to sell us something or shine our shoes.

Beautiful place. The centre of Cusco reminds me a lot of Florence . It's a very interesting place to visit . It's a plaza with few grand historical buildings and shop and small hotels around . All Over the place one can see shops selling the traditional Alpaka made clothes , crafts and souvenirs . There are many restaurants as well . Shops close at around 9 pm .
historical monuments and buildings. Area of ​​town with many historical monuments and buildings of great beauty ... a nice place...pleasant walk

Touristy but nice plaza de Armas. Like many towns in South America Cuzco as well has a Plaza de Armas. It is very touristy with many different agencies, shoeshine boys,women offering massages and even Starbucks and McDonals. It is still very nice though since on the plaza you can find a big cathedral, 3 churches (one is apparently the oldest one in South America) and it is great for people watching. Plus very central. On Sunday's in the morning they have a big parade.
Nice and cozy city. Incredibly nice, with good food, safe, clean and well eduated people. I was impressed how well prepared they are to receive tourists.
The first thing to see in Cusco. The Plaza is home to the main cathedral and several other great venues. People watching central. Lots of restaurants and souviner shops too.
Amazing Cuzco!!. Cuzco is absolutely marvelous! Everything there gives a sentiment of peace, strolling through the streets around the Historic Center is an awesome experience!! Very safe!!!
back to Inca's glory days. The centre of Cusco is soooo beautiful and takes you back to the glory days of the Incas. Had some rain but mostly sunny and warm.

Cusco a must to be seen !. Cusco, is from my experience unique, the historical part is about 1 square mile i guees and is so atmospheric, mystical and ofcouse historical. You need a minimum of 3 nights and two days to just have the experience in my opinion. Apart from taking a City Tour and the Surrounding Ruines, just wander arround the market places, the Artisn Quarter of San Blass and soak up all that atmosphere. After the 3 days, yes its time to move on and there is much more to be seen in the region, you will need a week in total after visiting the Sacred Valley and Machu Picchu.Have a great trip..... Stuart

Good prices on goods in local shops. Our hotel was near the historic center of Cusco. The narrow sidewalks weave along shops and restaurants. I found the souvenir shops to be so reasonably priced, I did not try to negotiate lower prices. The plaza, Colonial Cathedral and other buildings could easily fill a day of walking. Cobblestones are a bit rough. Wear sturdy shoes.

Beautiful city with its own character. Beautiful City. A place to unwind from the world and spend at least couple of days here. Must take in the city and the character of the place also ,instead of just concentrating on the Inca Trail. Yes altitude can be a problem , but the coca tea helps and carry your medication , if required
Most of the activity occurs here in the city in the evening.. Close to the hotel we were staying, in plenty of places to eat around the square in the evening, even an Irish pub.

Beautiful area. This is a beautiful area where you can wander around at night and still feel completely safe. There are a lot of shops selling Alpaca clothes as well as a ridiculous number of tour agencies and restaurants.

Fantastic trip. National Peru Travel are excellent, plan to the last detail, definitely will be traveling with them Loved the historical city centre of Cusco. The mixture of ancient inca structures, narrow streets and the colonial architectures made it a very interesting place to explore. The atmosphere was always vibrant and friendly. Souvenirs in Cusco were also much cheaper than in Lima! Hint: if you want to buy coca tea candies, much cheaper and abundant in Cusco (esp at local supermarkets) compare to buying in Lima.
Charming. Very charming, magic and beautiful place. Many restaurants around it, the Mama Africa nightclub too and the chocolate museum.

One of the prettiest city centres. There is so much to see in the historic centre - cathedrals galore, cobblestone streets and a number of plazas to relax in. It is a really pretty place and really easy to explore on foot - you can't really get lost!

absolutely beautiful historical city. Cusco is an historical and architectonic gem in Peru. the clash of cultures between Incas and the spanish colonisers can be witnessed in every corner. Strongly recommended visit

Best trip EVER with National Peru Travel. i traveled to Peru using National Peru Travel and it was outstanding! Everyone was very helpful and super nice. I would recommend them to anyone traveling to Peru.

Good place for tourist. Although it is a very good place to visit, the atmosphere was too touristic.You can exchange money, however, you should be careful not to get counterfeit. When I exchange 50 USD to peruvian Sol, one of three peruvian 50 sol bills was counterfeit.

Beautiful city . Loved the historical city centre of Cusco. The mixture of ancient inca structures, narrow streets and the colonial architectures made it a very interesting place to explore. The atmosphere was always vibrant and friendly. Souvenirs in Cusco were also much cheaper than in Lima! Hint: if you want to buy coca tea candies, much cheaper and abundant in Cusco (esp at local supermarkets) compare to buying in Lima.
Nice town to vist. . Beautiful town to stop and relax before heading out to machupicchu. If you like shopping you would love this place, lots to buy for souvenir.

Stunning city.. The centre of Cusco consists of wide open squares, lots of churches and some great shopping and eating opportunities. Traffic is rather chaotic, not really helped by the incessant whistling of the female traffic cops.Cusco is safe for tourists wLking at any time of day.
Excellent Plaza de Armas. Plaza de Armas is amazing. Big, with nice surrounding buildings and a lot of restaurants. Easy walk to neighboring plazas. Safe.

Inca Capital. Grand buildings with strong sense of history. Easy to walk between sites. Loved the atmosphere. Visit Santa Catalina monastery...well set out with informative boards in English and Spanish. Great value.

A LIVELY CENTRE. A great ambience in a bustling centre with both locals and tourists. Locals artists were displaying their works and there are plenty of bars and cafes from where you can people watch.
Very pleasant and friendly . Beautiful historical centre with excellent array of shops and restaurants. Watch out for some of the hostels which have bad rooms.

Very lovely city centre. The historic centre of Cusco is very lovely. Its very busy and there are lots of beautiful buildings with cafes, restaurants and bars galore.It was extra special when we were there in June because there were lots of celebrations going on and there were all sorts of different events going on around the city centre every day which was great fun.It's a great place eat, drink, shop and to people watch, however there are lots of persistent vendors and people from the cafes and bars trying to sell you stuff and get you into their establishments - which is a bit annoying at times.
Beautiful!. Cusco is an amazing beautiful city! The history and culture from Incan times to the Colonial period, is amazing. The architecture is absolutely astounding.

Spectacular. The central region of Cusco includes a few ancient ancient buildings and plazas. Most of the Cusco's liveliness centers around the Plaza de Armas. This is the largest square which has the Cathedral of Cusco and the Compania de Jesus church.The atmosphere is wonderful, particularly if it is a sunny day!One an also see a number of indigenous people (wearing their traditional clothing) and walking with alpacas!
Must see. Of course it's a must to see the Cusco Cathedral. I generally don't like guided tours, but this was interesting, because it represents the integration of Catholicism and Incan religions.

Amazing city center!. We walked around the city center yesterday and it very beautiful and the people are nice, sometimes a bit pushy to sell something but when you say no thank you they leave you alone.

People watch - extodinaire. Lucky enough to be there July 28th - Peru's Independence Day! Lots of activities and fanfare, parades, music. Surrounded by great food...peddlers can be a bit bothersome though...

Beautiful Area. We stayed in Cusco a couple of blocks from the square. It is a beautiful area very historic, there are a couple of 500 year old churches and history abounds. The area is nice, safe and there is excellent food everywhere. Where else can you get Trout Ceviche?? .... since the ocean is 500 miles away, they get fresh trout from the mountains there in the Andes ..... it is not to be missed! Yes there are a lot of people selling stuff on the streets and money exchangers....but it's still an awesome area. I recommend taking the bus tour.... it's a couple of hours long, only about 6 or 7 dollars US and they tour all around the historic center and also up on the hill side where their version of the Christ Statue is .... beautiful views down into the valley (Sacred) and gives you a good view of Cusco from high above.
Centre of town that has loads to see. Stunning architecture, lots to see and walk around and check out. Many restaurants, shops and interesting people

Charming Town. If you stay in Cusco then you will see the main Plaza and enjoy the atmosphere of this charming town. It's obviously the main stopping point for visitors to and from Machu Pichu and the facilities in the town reflect that. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit here.
A busy hub.... The town square, always busy and the fun begins at sunset. Make sure you visit the Cathedral, early morning Mass is free!
If in cusco, you will see this. Then central square, crowded and alive at night, peaceful and quiet in the early morning hours - great place to have a coffee and sit and watch the people go by!

Choose a second-floor restaurant and sit near the window to people-watch. Lovely central square with restaurants all around. A festival was taking place in mid-end June, so entertainment in the form of local dance troupes was abundant and free.

Wonderful. The center of this charming city is full of interesting buildings, museums and people. Be aware that the altitude can really affect you ability to enjoy the city. Follow guidelines for acclimatizing yourself
Cusco Plaza. This is a fun place to watch the locals and tourists. Lots of shops and restaurants to enjoy as well.

Touristy but charming. Extremely touristy but charming place. The view of all the little houses in the hills and mountains is beautiful, especially at night. One thing you can count on is that as it is so touristy, you can always expect that the shops will be open late and you can always walk up to any tourist travel agency and book a last minute tour if you havent planned your trip out well enough.

Gorgeous City. I am in love with my Home country. I promised to visit next year! Lots of History, Lovely buildings and structures. Great shopping, just be careful not to buy outside shops. People might sell you something else instead of silver. You may want to carry something to cover up. It gets drafty.

What a gorgeous city. We absolutely loved our visit to the historic town. Lovely buildings and structures with many little gift and other shops and tons of restaurants - there's not much to actually see beyond the square but it was fun to hang around and visit the stores.

You have to pay for everything.. Just be aware that people selling "silver" jewellery around the historical centre of the town will PROBABLY scam you, especially at night. Everything they sell is made of "alpaca" and not silver, and they look very similar. Don't buy anything at night. even if the prices seem extraordinary!
Nice place to spend a few hours.. Nice spot to watch people and many tourists coming from all over the world. Many brazilian visit peru each year!
Inca central!. Amazing mix of historic Inca foundations and spanish style.Some museums fairly rubbishy though. Yet so much to see and to learn about the Inca time.

The star of the Andes. Cusco is by far the star city in the Andes, and the historical center is the cherry on the pie. Majestic, colonial, clean and impressive, the historical center is the first and the last stop in any Cusco tour. All the interesting museums and historical sites are within walking distance from the Plaza de Armas. Down in the Avenida el Sol you will find the best modern weaving revival store, with many Kechua communities providing new weaving with traditional natural dies. Although not cheap, after you look at them for 10 minutes the cheaper offering with garish chemical dies look quite awful. The Korikancha nearby is a must visit place, to understand the great loss of the Inca civilization with its amazing stone masonry, its natural gods (sun, moon etc) and its total destruction by the Spanish barbarians.
Great Incan and Spaniard mix.. It's incredible how the remaining parts of the Inca Empire was used to built several colonial houses and churches for the conquerors.

Cusco is fantastic. We enjoyed Cusco and it was easy to walk around the city and see the ancient walls of the Incas underpinning religious and secular buildings. Do go to Sacsayhuaman which is a fantastic Incan site about 2 miles outside the city but its dimensions are incredible. We felt completely safe there and people were very helpful and friendly. La China was an excellent restaurant.
Nice. whent there during celebration. Markets needs to be seen. Lots of shoping. Its clean and safe to visit. Preferable with a guide to get more info.
Amazing!. Beautiful city that combines ancient, colonial and modern culture, with excellent gastronomy, art, beautiful handcrafts, indigenous communities and people from all over the world!

Totally over rated. I didn't like Cuzco because it has been ruined by tourism. Everything around the square is based on tourism so it is so fake. All shops and resturant cater to tourist. Hotels and hostels charge top dollar because most tourist are rich North Americans so they charge normal USD rates. ATM there exploit tourists too in only allowing $200 USD to be drawn out at once. So when you go to pay for your Inca Trail tour in cash (which is approx $800 include tips) you have to use their ATM 5 times which they charge $5 each withdrawal. Vendors follow you around all day trying to sell you stuff, they try to manipulate your emotions by saying they need to feed their children, you get bangered constantly. I would never return to Cuzco. The only thing I liked was the sun parades in the main square. Bolivia is fantastic in comparison as it's more of a cultural experience not influenced by tourism.
The best square in Peru. walking around the square is soo nice, the main square the churches, people, restourants, bars a lot of things to do.

No wonder this is the top city in South America. Not much to do here other than sit and look around. We were here during the big festival in June, coinciding with the summer solstice. Parades, bands and people wearing traditional dress. Just a fun place to be.

Cusco - the hart of the ancient culture. As most tourists, I spent a couple of days in Cusco before we went to MP. Looking back I would definitively spend more time in the beautiful city. Go by yourself and explore the historic center and then take a guided tour - first you will see its beauty and then its logic as well :)

Well maintained. Well preserved historical town centre. Colonial style with many alleys and side roads leading of to interesting places. Many cafés and restaurants worth a visit, and churches and museums.
Don"t miss. Cusco is one of those places with a lot of history .......have to walk....mixture of Incas and the Spanish .......traffic is very busy .....very good food and hotels....
Incredible!. Great colonial city center and very well preserved! beautiful narrow streets and an eclectic mixture of cultures: Inca and Spanish.
Very special city.. Cusco is one of my favourite places to visit. We felt safe and the whole experience was amazing. We walked around the city for hours exploring alleys and buildings.
Don't miss out!!. Make sure to go during June, tons of parades throughout the day specifically for incoming tourists and a lot of homemade food and sweets.

Inti Raymi Festivities. Nice walk to do. We were there during festivities, on June 23th and it was spetacular. All the city was doing a parade all day long. They were really proud ad it was a really nice day
Do not miss it!. Best colonial historic center in Latin America. Worth spending two to three days visiting old churches, museums and inca places

You must go ....... Cusco, the necessary station for the trip to Macchu Picchu, is a beautiful city.
Vivid, colorful, interesting.
We visited Cusco at September 2010
It's a must do.. You have to come to the center. It's a bit touristy for my tastes but there's loads of museums, old architecture, and boatloads of local color.

Great place to people watch!. Yes its touristy, but bustling and loads of fun. Wandering the cobbled streets and getting a taste of the atmosphere is all part of it. The central square is always busy with some show or dancing or festvity. A great place to wander.

Great atmosphere. Cusco is a beautiful city - you can spend a day just walking around the tiny streets of San Blas or the vast squares in the historic center, not to mention the numerous churches. Reserve at least a full day for exploring it.
Beautiful Colonial Cusco.. The historical center of Cusco is very lively and gorgeous in its colonial character. The cathedral is absolutely fantastic.

Highly recommend. If you want to learn about Cusco's cultural history, then you should consider visiting Centro Historico de Cusco. They have tours available that vary in length from a full day to a half a day. No matter what you choose, you will learn so much more going on a tour to visit this historic place. Highly recommend!
fun. This a fun place to spend a few hours. There is an abundance of shopping, food and just watching all the people and activity

Beautiful city. The city of Cusco is lovely. A lot of historical places to go in the traces of incas. It is very crowded city with a lot of tourists hanging around, but also local kind peruanian people. Cusco is also a entering door to the sacred valley of incas and of course Machu Picchu. It is a place to go!
Fun, fun, fun!. Great area for history, shopping, eating, and especially people watching. Great little shoppes to browse and buy!
Visit the churches if you like art.. Lovely walk, there is a lot of art to admire if you visit the churches nearby. Don't miss La compañía de Jesús and La Merced.

Beautiful space with lots of things to do!. The Historic Center of Lima is a very interesting spot, with several beautiful churches, squares, lots of restaurants and activities. Definitely worth a visit!
The historic city of Incas. Our first day in Cuzco was very interesting. We bought the touristic "boletos" and we visited many historic places. Quite interesting!

You'd think you are in Italy. The centre of Cusco is very nice indeed. Beautiful buildings, clean, feels totally safe (local people are very, very nice). There are many chic boutiques and that can be useful for gifts to bring back home. However, I'd reserve most of your spending to the local associations and communities. Not just because you'll get a better deal but mainly because you're quite sure you'll be supporting those locals directly.For example, next to the cathedral on that historical square is a market with local craftsmen and craftswomen. On one of the routes (we spend the week with Alpaca Expeditions, fantastic, btw. And actively trying to bring support to the "true" locals) you get the opportunity for an insight as to how the alpaca wool is treated, coloured and used. Then, you can do your purchases at these women's stands. We bought some stuff from an old lady - man, she was a dangerous seller and we had to be on our toes. Super sweet, though, never aggressive, always very kind, and really good prices.
Culture, sounds and food!. Definitely worth seeing and spending some quiet time walking around the city square on an off day. It's a beautiful space!

Nice, busy, and fun!. Cusco's historical centre has many things to offer. The best way to have a great time there is walking around! There are great museums, churches, cafes, etc! We had a delightful time! Many people forget about the historical centre as most tourist focus more on the pre-inca and Inca ruins; whereas we particularly loved the combination of Inca and Colonial past that the historical centre displays! Don't forget to take the time to discover the city! :)

Every corner... a new adventure. A lot of places and stuff to see. A variety of activities (city tours, Inka ruins, museums, handcraft markets). The food was amazing (different types of restaurants and menu style and pricing). In general, a great experience surrounded by Inka and Spanish architecture.
The time traveling. A travel to the past, where remains from the ancient Incas can be seen along with the Spanish presence. Good for shopping, too.

Surprising Gem. Cusco is a necessary stop on the way to Machu Picchu. But I will commit heresy here and say I think I liked Cusco better than Machu Picchu. Wonderfully preserved sixteenth century buildings. You really get the feel of what life in colonial Spain was like here. The people are friendly. Excellent restaurant choices. A photographers heaven. Compact enough to walk easily, but with enough sites to keep you occupied.
Nice place. Pretty good place with lots of places and stuff to see. A must check out here in cusco. Not so good to eat though since there are Better places going down the sun avenue.

Best to See the Artwork with a Guide. Loved looking through the cathedral. Well worth your time, particularly if you have a guide to explain the Andean/Incan influence on the Catholic(ish) artwork. Best reviewed through the eyes of the pre-Catholic

A real Peruvian cultural experience!. This is the must-see tourist attraction in Cuzco. The plaza is totally surrounded by authentic Spanish Colonial architecture, and cultural events happen there nearly daily. On the night we went, a religious festival was taking place, complete with fireworks and teams of schoolchildern in native dress performing their tribal dances. Awesome! The event also attracted aggressive street vendors, each begging us to buy a cap, t-shirt, poncho, necklace, you name it. Thankfully, most vendors stopped pursuing us as soon as we said, "No, gracias!"
loved the cathedral!. The cathedral is amazing! Don't miss it! Doesn't look that special on the outside, but you have to see the inside! WOW!

My favorite city in all of Peru!. I love the Plaza de Armas in the city center of Cusco. So much ambiance for walking around, sitting on benches and reading, or going out to eat or to a local bar. I will return here again and again in the future!

Delightful stop on the way to your destination. Cusco is a wonderful stop en route to the Sacred Valley and Macho Picchu. It's a charming area and well worth a visit. We stayed at the Monastario Hotel which is just magnificent, as are the attentive staff. It's an escape to a different world.
Colonial City. Really is good. You are in colonial city and the peruvian take care about remodelation. Honestly is very nice. Inca and colonial mix.

Bus+Train experience. When I booked the trip, it was not clear to me that I would not go the entire way by train to Machu Picchu. The bus trip, first part of it, is not bad at all, and you can enjoy sightseeing while going to the train station.The train trip, however, was really nice! The train`s ceiling are made of glass, which makes it possible to admire the amazing view of the mountains growing before your eyes while the train goes its way down to Machu Picchu. There is a snack served in the train, and the service surprised me: they prepare a proper table for the meal, and serve you a nice assortment of local snacks, such as fruits and corn, plus dessert.It is worth the trip cost, definitely!

You'll fall in love with the city. Cusco is one the most beautiful cities I've been to, the plaza is a great example of Incan and Spaniard classic mixture in terms of architecture and culture. In winter can be cold and if you come by plane may be affected by the "soroche" or height illness, natives recommend to chew coca leafs or take a coca tea to fight it. There is a starbucks in a second floor at the side of the church with a great view and Wi-Fi.

Cuzco, a cool place to stroll and visit. The old part of Cuzco is definitely worth visiting. We took a tour of the Cathedral, central plaza, and temple of the sun and monastery all within a couple block walk from our hotel. It is definitely an interesting place to walk around and check out

Always something interesting going on!. The central historic area of Cusco's heart is the Plaza de Armas square and it spreads out from there encompassing two large churches and many other historic sites. In our six days in Cusco we saw several parades pass through the area, one of which was a celebration of the coming of Spring (we were there in September). There are many restaurants with balconies overlooking the square and they are a great place to relax and take a break from exploring all that Cusco has to see and just do some people watching. Who knows, you might event stumble upon a parade!

Great City with Lots to Do. Lots to do and see. Cusco has a very European feel but packed with the action, smells, food, and excitement that is South America. We had no problems finding things to do for 4 days in Cusco. Also, there is a plethora of things to see within short day trips or taxi rides just outside the city.
Best of towns . Came here for two days with family and ended up staying five when husband got sick (good health care btw). Never ran out of things to do and see.

Everything you may want to do in Cusco is right here. Everything you may want to do in Cusco is right here. From historic churches to one of the most unique markets I have been in the Mercado Central de San Pedro. There are several museums within a few blocks of the center. Shopping opportunities galore. We visited the Inca Museum. Take your time and enjoy all the sites. Cusco is a very unique city

Cool area to cruise around!. Street artists are really great, lots of people asking if you want to buy things. They are nice, but say no and be firm and you'll be fine. There are so many stray dogs here, but they are all really nice and friendly, they only want some pets :)

Beautiful Spanish and Inca architecture. The historic center has beautiful architecture, it is very nice to walk around the narrow streets and sit on bench to enjoy the sun and culture. I recommend stopping buy the woman selling tamales at one of the corners of Plaza de Armas. Walk through the narrow streets around San Blas and visit the rock of 12 angles. While walking remember to look up! The balconies have amazing wood work! The cathedral is impressive many things inside the cathedral are made from cedar wood and you can see the oldest (and last?) cedar tree inside the courtyard of the Hotel Monasterio, you can enter to the courtyard and chapel even if you are not staying at the hotel, just ask at the reception. Qurikancha shows the remnants of Inca ruins within the church of Santo Domingo convent. I recommend getting a tour here to understand the significance of each of the temples. It is impressive to see the Inca construction… it looks like it was made of massive stone legos! The central market (San Pedro) is also an interesting experience, especially if you want to buy local food! (I didn’t try though). Finally you can go to the chocolate museum (free), where they explain the process of making chocolate... buying chocolate is expensive however it is cheaper than at the freeshop!

Enjoy walking the old stone street !. The hole city Cusco is B'tifull Historico city to walk around just look at the Inca wall ,building and So many Cathedral to visit and museum ..walking to Loreta lane I find small Llama farm with 6,7 Llamas eating glass and some Sven Shop too ! Go check it out ,very good prices !!! They let you take photo with all the Llama !! Love the people so friendly !!! I'm world travel been to many places and experience many problem before but Peruvian nice people !!

Cusco Plaza de Armas. Most people visiting Machu Picchu will begin or end their journey here in Cusco, the Imperial City of the Inca. The huge Plaza de Armas is the center of colonial Cusco. The square is dominated by the Cathedral and the Church of La Compania. The other two sides are lined with colonial arcades. In the center of the square is a beautiful fountain. Both churches are 'must see' sights. Guided tours are offered or you can walk through on your own. As with most churches in Peru, no photos are allowed. Both churches are a maze of elaborate altars and statues covered in gold, silver and gem stones. Impressive art works line the walls. Be sure to see the Zapata Last Supper and the Monroy painting of the Cusco earthquake of 1650. Climb the bell tower of La Compania for an impressive view of the Cathedral and the Plaza. The Plaza is beautifully illuminated at night. A video of the Plaza and churches can be found on my youtube channel: youtube.com/c/donstailey
Historical Square. Very interesting bustling square in Cusco. Lots of churches, pubs and places to eat. Great people watching.

Great city!. The city center of Cusco was great for walking around enjoying the day or evening. It was packed with tourists of course, but felt safe and quaint. The cheap massages being offered on every street are legit and highly recommended!

What a great main square. Normally I would not bother reviewing a "main square" but his one is so beautiful that it is really worthwhile just taking time out here. The gardens are well maintained and the Tourist Police on their Segways make sure there are no issue such as people sleeping in the park - it is safe by day and night. Close to many eateries across the price spectrum. There are walking tour guides looking for trade, but not hassling.Fancy a shoeshine only US$1.

The Heart of Cusco beats strong and loud!. A super town centre with ruins, cathedrals, gardens, park benches, statues, restaurants, fast food places, camping shops and a generally clean resting place right in the heart of Cusco. From here it is simple to find markets, bookstores, Silverware, Alpaca shops, quality accommodation and any amount of first class eating places. A good start to any tour of Cusco.

Don't miss this heart of Cusco. Enjoyed the plaza and both major churches - the entry fee was small and understandable to support the upkeep of the buildings. The Last Supper (with guinea pig on the menu) was terrific. Sure, a few tack souvenier shops around the square, but also lots of locals. Just remember to take it easy for altitude adjustment. Several nice restaurants to select from - guide books and of course TripAdvisor can get you to the right ones.
A Very Nice Trip to the Past!. Cusco Down Town has a very nice touch of a colonial city. The churches have a beautiful architecture and the large houses with their inner patios are a very nice touch.
Nice Plaza de Armas. This city centre is nice and you can take some rest there in the afternoon. The market is not too far and in the evening there is a lot of restaurants around the place.

Historic Place. I liked to visit Cusco , i wanted to visit cusco many years ago , cusco is wonderfull , there are many tourist atracctions , the historic center is interesting , i went with my family , i recommend visit this beautiful place .
City tour. Definitely tour the monastery and the Cathedral. reccomend guided tour and the history of the city is most intersting

Visiting Cusco is by all unforgettable!!. Patios, arches and doorways; colonial Temples and houses raised on Incan foundations. Imposing Churches and Convents with a profusion of works of art inside! Hispanic Andean cultural fusion is manifested, and its most intense, both trough its architecture and its people, who proudly preserve traditional customs! There are wonderful paintings and sculptures by renowned artisans of Cusco. Cusco has a good infrastructure in terms of leisure, with lots of restaurants, pubs and nightclubs, that make Cusco nights more attractive for tourists!! And much more, multicolored valleys, mountains and forests, beautiful lakes and rivers. Lots of adventure! Machupicchu, Ollantaytambo, Saqsaywaman, Sacred Valley, etc. etc.

Great character. The centre of Cusco has real character and not just made to look pretty for tourists . the are a example of statues, squares and buildings which demonstrate the history of this once Inca capital. Worth half a day to get atmosphere with numerous small cafes and bakeries which the locals use .

Beautiful Plaza. The Plaza de Armas is a beautiful city center where you can take in the sites, tour the cathedrals, enjoy great food, or get a very good (yet inexpensive) massage ($10 USD). This feels like the heart of the city, and though Cusco has more to offer, you could be very happy spending your days here:)

Very Historic !. Its a city bery beautiful , is the best place from cuzco , i saw an interesting church , there are many tourists from different countries in this historic center , its magic , this is part of the peruvian culture .
Interesting!. Enjoyed touring the city with local friends. So many beautiful plazas and parks, and charming historic streets.

June is the month to be there. I arrived in Cusco on May 28, 2015. There was the Corpus Christi wich was totally amazing to see. Almost every day, there was something going on in the city with traditional music or modern and people wearing traditional or special costumes. On June 23th there was a defile that was for over 4 hours long. All in music, dance and so colorful that it was difficult to stop watching.There are a lot of police presence so you can feel save even when alone.What I dislike is the overwhelming sollicitation by street vendors. At every door, you have someone who is trying to sell you something which is the same from one to another one. The number of dogs. Most of them belong to someone but they let them out all day and they feed on garbages. It is quite disturbing to see 10 dogs opening and spreading all the garbage around.

Ambience. This is a busy plaza surrounded by churches, restaurants with balconies, shops and other historical sites. In the morning, we were greeted with children dancing in the streets, soft church bells and there is such history that surrounds this place. If your going to shop, especially with street vendors, expect to be asked to buy something every 30 steps. They can be persistent. Speak in tongues and you should be fine.
