Beautiful and historic city center. Flanked by colonial churches, Inca walls, and stunning mountain views, the park like grounds are a great place to sit and people watch. However, be prepared for the copious and sometimes aggressive vendors hawking everything from paintings to coca candy.

Fantastic. If going in the month of June they celebrate all month with parades and fireworks. The centro has a beautiful church to see and lots of great shops and eateries to explore. Altitude is about 11,000 so be prepared and drink lots of coca tea in the morning to give you energy.
Charming. Cusco's old town is very well preserved and extremely charming. There are a lot of cathedrals, colonial houses, narrow streets with good bars and restaurants.

Beautiful. The town center is very safe and there are more tourists than locals it seems. There are police everywhere. Lots of historic places, shopping, restaurant, hotels, and hiking/camping equipment stores.
So many places to visit. and just enjoy walking on cobblestones , the fantastic perfectly lined up walls built by the Incas. i can't ever get enough. i love Cuco and is a very special place
So much to see!. It's just beautiful - great place to stroll around and explore! Grab a coffee and hang out for a bit!
It has to be done!. Excellent place to just walk and get lost in the streets, in order to get the feeling of old times in an old city.

cusco a city of the inca s. the cathedral in the maimn plaza with its extensive grounds where on 24th june-cusco day the scenes from inca days of the past are renacted in full pomp n glory with dances etc.the revelaries start from a week before-parades by different schools in the main plaza with local colourful dancers too n fireworks every nite!santo domingo church with its baroque syle interiors.the cusco school paintings which were so very beautiful.the cafes n museums around the plaza n the gardens at the center where u can just sit see some fountains n good landscaping or walk around taking in the local "flavours"

Lovely area to sit and enjoy cusco. Nice historical centre and worth a visit, I had dinner most nights in the restaurants around historical centre and enjoyed them all.Also many local activities ordinate in this centre and is a hub of activity day and night.

So much to see. Cusco is a very walkable city, and there's a lot to see and do. The museums cost very little and are full of interesting historical relics, art, stories and facts. Shopping and restaurants are abundant.
Plaza De Armas. Great restaurants & bars in the plaza de armas, as well as historic buildings & churches to visit.People are super friendly as well.

Wonderful historic area, but be careful. The historical district of Cusco is beautiful. A mix of Inca and Colonial architecture surrounded by large mountains and bustling traffic and people. Be warned, pick pockets abound and you should not take anything valuable with you. But using common sense and being aware of your surrounding, it is no different than any large tourist area. Great shopping as well.
Good historical place. The same need to be explored by walking, there are many places in the center down town area, but requires lots of walking.

Gorgeous town high in the Andes mountains.. The Inca and Spanish influences abound in what is now the historic center of Peru and once was the center of the Inca Empire, the largest empire in pre-Columbian America. It is a very safe city to explore as the Peruvian people are generally polite and shy. Accept the coca tea as it helps with altitude sickness since the city is at 11,200 ft elevation.

Absolutely beautiful . Now this is what I went to Peru for. The architecture is stunning, the weather is perfect, there a good bars, cafés, museums, hotels and hostels. Have a coca-leaf tea on one of the balconies when you get there while you take it all in.

Friendly and Fun. I loved it at all times of day: in the morning when children walked to school (mainly with dads, uncles, or older brothers); during business hours, and in the evenings when activities were so vibrant. The area was historic, safe, clean, and full of friendly people.

A great cultural attraction. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to Cusco which our group used as a base to explore Machu Pichu and the Sacred Valley. Cusco is a very cultural city with a beautiful central square with a large cathedral and many charming side streets. We saw some wonderful folk dances from the region and walked and shopped around the area.

Capital of the Inca Empire. The city of Cusco retains a great deal of architecture from several centuries ago. There are walls remaining that were built by the Incas. The cathedral is huge and very beautiful. The center city by the Plaza de Armas is very walkable.
if you happen to be in the area dont miss Inti Raymi. We attended the Inti Raymi ceremony on June 24th an extraordinary celebration of Inka culture not to be missed if one should get the opportunity

Sickness altitude. Cusco is an amazing City full of history! I really really recomend to Take Pills for altitude sickness before you get toHigh places. They have Sorojiki Pills. They do help. For our entire trip to South America we had guides all over the places. Of course diferent ones. I would recomend YOU to do THE same!

wonderful just to walk around. Nice place to wonder about. The city center is relatively small, so you can easily just walk around. A visit to the cathedral in the main square is worthwhile. Everything else... I'd just suggest to walk around, enjoy the little shops (always negotiate about the price!) and the lovely restaurants.

Enjoyed the City Center!. Hotel Novotel was very close to the City Center and we felt we spent most of our time here..the streets are up and down so if you have problems walking a lot and adjusting to the altitude I suggest staying near the City Center

Impressive Buildings, nice atmosphere and great places to see and eat. Impressive. Going to Cusco is a wonderful experience. And the city historical part make you travel to that time when the city was the Inca Empire territory.

A historical town, great for kids, couples, families, old and young!. You can spend hours and then days wondering around the city of Cuzco. Every street is magical and has something to offer. There is so much preserved history here, you can lose track of time. We went into as many museums as we could with our museum pass, Although the museums are all fairly small they each have something different to offer. There are many pedestrianised streets and our kids loved the place. Easy to walk about for hours, with many good places to eat just off the main centre. Pick up a leaflet from a tour bus trip and then walk to all of the places yourself !Don't miss the mural, sun temple, cathedral, Inca museum, ruins and Christ looking over the town (get a taxi/bus there)

Very Old but Vibrant. The historical district of Cuzco centers around the Plaza de Armas and for the most part, is fairly compact --- you could walk to the major sites including the Cathedral, various churches, squares, museums and even Qoricancha. It is crowded, noisy and bustling w/ people and energy but steeped in Inca and colonial history. There is always something happening in the Plaza, mostly fiestas.
Beautiful, Friendly City. I loved Cusco, it has a lot of historical attractions and natural beauty. Take a guided city tour if you're able.

Layer upon Layer of History. A spanish colonial city literally built on the foundations of the capital of the Inca empire. Pre-Spanish influence is very strong here. Its very easy to imagine what life was like during Inca times.
Cusco. We loved Cusco ! So many celebrations going on in the historic area. The nightly parades were tremendous!

Party all the time!. We went during June which is the sun festival and in the plaza the party never ended!! There are many shops and places to eat all around overall a nice place to find something to do!

The heart of Cusco. Plaza de Armas is where it all happens, and chances are if you in Cusco, you won't miss this area. Full of energy, there seems to always to something going on. Great to people watch, buy gifts, find a restaurant, or explore the various shops. If you find yourself ever bored in Cusco - just head to the main square.
Beautiful. Historical Cusco is interesting and beautiful with it's Colonial buildings and churches built atop Incan foundations.

Can't Miss. This is the center of the city, so you literally can't miss this as a tourist - you will definitely walk through it. Nevertheless, it's a great place to walk around, and you don't have to try to get a taxi or anything to see all of it. It's a nice and safe area to walk around!

Wander the cobbled streets. Great to wander around the cobbled streets, soak up the atmosphere and take in the architecture. Lots of hills so wear good walking shoes. Plenty of places to call into to buy some alpaca sweaters or boom tours.

I suppose you can''t miss this if you are in Cusco.. The historical centre of Cusco is a "must see". Walking along the narrow cobbled streets reminded me of cities in Europe.
There are a lot of tourist shops (and traffic) but once I got past that, the historical center had a lot of character and was a pleasant to walk around.

Cusco, my amor. I've been very lucky to arrive in Cusco during the city's celebrations. It's already a very lovely place but June it's the best time to go there to see parades, people in traditional customs and the main square, plaza de l'arma gets a particular colours, vibe. There was the celebration for a particular Virgin and people from every corner were coming wearing evil customs, dance dresses and traditional hats and ponchos and danced through the streets arriving to the main square.The cathedral is glorious and offers a solemn aspect to the venue. The other corners complete in splendid way with elegant buildings.
Quaint city, great people. The city of Cusco has many sights to see and visit. Spend a few days there in the main plaza, or cristo blanco or "sexy woman" ruins.

Amazing place to stay. Amazing place to stay, to stroll around and just enter any museum, church, market! People are very kind and helpful (although cars don't stop on zebras) food is tremendous and it's all very safe and sound! A very enlightening experience!

Spanish invasion brought Some good. Fantastic square, beautiful cathedral, great atmosphere, nice shops, good restaurants. We only wished we had more time to enjoy the practising for the parades and san the procession.
one of the most beautiful historical centers!. Plaza de Armas, San Blas, the historical center of Cusco is somewhere you can wander for several days and discover hidden gems.
Plaza de Armas. Great place to visit. Love the architecture and restaurants around it. Try the local food which is wonderful and a very good price!
great place. I loved it. It is just wonderful to be there. If you like traveling, it is a must see place. It has history, art, great food, very pleasant people. Just go without thinking twice.
Excellent. Always something going on in dowtown square. When we were there local Corpus Christi Celebrations were ongoing.
inca trail. Walking tour included history of cusco, well worth it, although make sure you have acclimatised to the high altitude before taking this tour

Amazing City Center. The city is breathtaking. Lots of narrow streets and balconies on buildings. Everything is freshly painted and picture-worthy everywhere you turn. The town is very clean and full of character. I'm not a city person, but this place is well worth the trip!

One day was not enough. I was on a tour so could't control the itinerary but wished I could have stayed longer than one full day in Cusco. This a very historical and interesting city. I loved the parts I saw but just wished I had more time.
Like all of Peru, people are very friendly there.

a lovely city, stay at least 2-3 days. Cuzco is a lovely city and a good place to stop on your way to or from Machu Pichu. It deserves a good look by it's own, and also the sites in the vicinity, like to Muray, Chinchero market and other places that are within less than an hour. The city is best seen by foot, and hiring a guide at each location you go to. The guides are everywhere, most of them are very knowledgeable and speak excellent English. Cuzco has an interesting history, and is visually interesting too.

Cusco. Generally liked the historical centre & found tour & history most interesting. Did not enjoy being constantly approached by the women & children wanting to sell their wares. The children were very insistent at times. Rather spoilt the atmosphere & charm of the area.

Visually amazing. This is where the city looks most beautiful, from the churches to the balconies, kids playing and people walking, the mountains in the distance and the sounds of the city. I enjoyed taking many photos in this area. It's worth your time walking to this plaza.

Amazing Culture & History. We visited Cusco before hiking the Inca Trail. Enjoyed seeing all of the historical sites around the Plaza De Armas! You must see the Basilica Cathedral - the construction and history is amazing. Enjoy lunch or dinner at any of the restaurants overlooking the plaza. Don't forget to walk over to the local market off of Santa Clara. The city is a must see!

What a difference in 40 years!. When last visited, Cuzco was a dusty, cobbled town of 160,000 people. Today it has 660,000 souls with about 2/3 of the populace supporting the almighty Tourist Trade. So many more decent priced lodgings....with or w/o heat.

Take Your Diamox and Enjoy the visit. At 11,000 feet the altitude might get to you so I would suggest taking some altitude medication. The traffic is congested and the drivers are crazy so obey the street crossing signs. The center plaza is full of historic buildings and shops. The flowers and fountains are relaxing to sit by and just people watch.

Great square/plaza. We were fortunate enough to stay right on the plaza. Great spot. We were also very lucky to be here at the time their Corpus Christi festival was on. The place was buzzing the whole time with performances around the clock. Great spot, highly recommend.
Charming city centre. All the tourist bureaus are in this area along with tourist markets.. Good restaruants with second floor balconies that overlook the centre - and great view of the many parades!

Lots of history. Interesting history of Incas and Catholocism. Had a 1/2 day city tour with Condor Travel and this really enhanced our experience. The guide was very knowledgeable and the information provided made the visit more interesting.
Rich Culture. There was an amazing awareness of the culture in this area. There were museums, markets, the people dressed in their cultural attire. It was great.

Interesting, beautiful historical city with much to offer. Cusco was the site of the historic capital of the Inca Empire and was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO. It is a beautiful city with well-preserved colonial architecture, evidence of a rich and complex history. The city itself represents the centre of indigenous Quechua culture in the Andes. At 3,400 meters above sea level, we were advised to take it easy as we found the high altitude problematic. There was much to see and so. There are numerous tours to take to see local historical sites (Tambomachay, Cristo Blanco, Sacsayhuaman, Q’enko). We also took the open top red bus tour. We stayed very near to the main plaza (Centro Historico), lots of shops, restaurants. Recommend you stay a few extra days and take your time to acclimatise and to enjoy all that Cusco has to offer.
Soak it in. Central Cusco is a wonderful place to walk, browse, listen and soak up the colonial history, plazas, street life and contemporary life.

History. Cusco is an amazing high mountain city.The history of the Incas and Spanish is amazing. Walking around the main square is a delight. This is also the sight of the highest Irish Pub in the world just around the corner
A fascinating and absorbing place to go on a rainy day. This is included in your Cusco multi-ticket, is easy to find and gives fascinating insights into the history and the Spanish invasion

Bustling, friendly, picturesque, historic Cusco. Liked all of it--layout of city, walkability, ease of navigation throughout city, shopping, dining, accommodations, friendly and service-oriented community.
I'd go back anytime!. Oxygen or not, I'd go back anytime! Lovely place, perfect location, great tourism related services. Give yourself time to adjust to the high altitude and go to explore the area.
Very well maintaned, beautiful biuldings and churches. Loved the feeling and sightseeing, if you go during the morning you can see the sun light in the cathedral windows

As it is its main square, you must go!. The Historical Center is a place that you must see. The plaza (not as big as you may imagine it) is surrounded by two main churches and several restaurants. Although the restaurants may be a little price, it is definitely worth it if you have the view of the "Plaza de Armas". Please, do read the statement that the locals placed in regards to the indigenous resistance. It is worth to be amazed at the statement...
interesting. Just great to learn about the Incas and the history of Peru and the religious ceromonies were interesting and i ate my first Guiena pig Cuy

Good Buying Spot. There are a lot of little shops all around the plaza. We found some things to buy there, such as, a couple of t-shirts, a polo shirt, a Peruvian travel bag, and a Peruvian purse as a gift. Our friends bought a sepia print. So there are quite a few things to buy. In addition, there are a fair number of restaurants to choose from. We were told to go to the San Blas plaza for better prices, but we never made it there.

The city of Cusco. Charming city located at 11,000 feet. The Peruvians seem to like to celebrate everything. On weekends periodically cannons going off, parades happening with regularity with people dressed in bright colors, costumes. A lot of well-behaved dogs roaming the streets. They seemed to know when to cross the street as the drivers don't stop for anything. People very nice

If you want to buy some gifts, buy them here!. The historic center in Cusco is magical! So many churches, cathedrals etc. If we knew before we would buy gifts here! Everything is so cheap and I would say same quality as they offer in Lima, Puno, Arequipa etc. If you want to buy little gifts as llamas keychains, earrings, hats, scarfs, purses... buy it here! There is also a great massage center on Portal Espinar N. 190, I believe it was 25 soles for an hour massage. It was a great massage. In other cities in Peru is much more expensive! There is also a lot of travel agencies offering the same tour for different price. Go and ask multiple agencies and you can get pretty good deal!

A lot of Character. A really good place to experience an old world Spanish colonial style town. The main square and all the cobbled streets off it are full of character (and characters !). The main square is a good spot just to relax or find a good restaurant for dinner. Don't be afraid to explore the side streets, there are some really nice restaurants and delightful views forr the photographically inclined.Quite one of the nicest town centers I have been in in S America. The outskirts (for example on the way to the Station at Poroy are of course more typical - very broken down and positively not for the tourist!
Interesting historical district.. The main square is quite impressive. Generally the old town buildings are Spanish colonial design (Balconies) but built on the foundations of the old Inca city.

Welcoming ambiance. I loved walking through these streets with picturesque view all along and then the sweet natured Peruvians helping with the local knowledge and directions. Cusco is historically rich and you can easily stumble upon places that once meant a lot in history. That is what it has to offer. Lots of surprising facts and places about the culture and its history. While here splurge on local foods and handicrafts.

Fun to walk around town, but air pollution is awful. Walking around central Cusco is fun, safe and entertaining daytime or night, but the air pollution from auto exhaust combined with the altitude can lead to a quick headache. Shame there is so much air pollution.

Central Plaza of Cusco. Such a lovely part of the city to sit in the sun on a park bench and enjoy the sunshine and take in the surroundings. We grabbed a coffee from Starbucks and enjoyed the atmosphere and planned our adventures in the sun. You are surrounded by so much history it's hard not to get caught up in it. Beware of hawkers and some shady characters eying off tourists here though. It really is a beautiful part of this town.

Awesome,. The History of the area was outstanding, the churches built in the 1600 to now breathtaking, The Stores and Restaurants were excellent. One young man came up to us to show the menu and then another from another place...so we could see what we wanted before we even selected a place.

Beautiful but way too touristy. Architecture is stunning, location itself but Cuzco is just way too crowded, too many tourists and too many locals offering you goods every step you take.I understand it all just for those who look more for peace it is a maximum 1 day trip. Worth seeing just not living or spending few days.

Underrated city . Cusco lives in the shadow of Machu Picchu. This city is so beautiful, cultural and welcoming! We spent 3 days here and it was perfect. We hopped on a touristy double decker bus for 7$ and saw the city. We also toured the city by foot- walked to the local markets. Try and find a hotel near Plaza De Armas. Eat at one of the 2nd floor balconettes overlooking the Plaza. Drink Pisco Sours. And get a 6$ massage! Talk with the locals- I found that they love foreigners and like practicing their English :)

Nice. This city is a breed between Inca´s and Spanish` culture. The ticket is expensive, but the good thing is that you pay one ticket to get almost every museum in Cusco. Machu Picchu is not included.

Fantastic place. We stayed right on the main square (Plaza de Armas) and had walking access to as many shops, restaurants, tour guides, etc that you would ever need. Very rich history and scenery. This is where the action is in Cusco.

Take a tour and spend at least 2 nights to enjoy it all. I liked everything, I would stay more time if posible, consecutive days and the continue travel to other sites or Machu Pichu, but definitely stay 2 consecutive nights to appreciate the most.
Many interesting churches,restaurants. That area of Cusco is easy to walk around and spend an afternoon a cafe patio and watch the slower pace of life

Favorite city in Peru. Cusco was a lovely little city with so much historical perspective. It is worth just wondering around and enjoying the sights. Never once did I feel threatened or worried about my safety, day or night. Most people stop in Cusco prior to moving on to Machu Picchu. This city is worth visiting on it's own even if you don't plan on going to Machu Picchu.

Culturally rich, charming small city is a MUST in S. America. Because its most recent history and culture were shaped by two very distinct civilizations -- native Inca and western European invaders -- the city reflects a fascinating blend of art, architecture, religion and customs. The main cathedral square is indeed a key touristic center, but it's also a lovely place to relax on a park bench and take in the scenery, or find just about any kind of food you're craving.Peruvians are very welcoming to guests and a good number of them speak English, especially in service establishments. Peruvian cuisine is OUTSTANDING, and because your hotel will likely be a bargain (especially if you're traveling on US$), you should splurge on food. Taxis are safe, the airport is close to town (though you hear no airplanes once you're in town), traffic isn't a problem and the weather can be divine most of the year. Bonus: Your'e just a train ride away from Machu Picchu!RECOMMENDED READING before you go: "The Royal Commentaries of the Incas" by Inca Garcilaso de la Vega.
Awesome and SAFE!. One of the most beautiful places on earth! Fun! SAFE! People are very nice and helpful. Great places to eat and a nice place/area to just chill and people watch.

History at every turn. It was amazing to walk the streets of Cuzco. Practically every street, sidewalk, building in the center of town has some meaning. We found out that the ancient town was built in the shape of a puma and significant parts of the city represented the head, heart, bellybutton, tail.
wonderful and most interesting city. Cusco is a must city to visit, and go to Machu Picchu, Sacred Valley, Go prepared with pills for the altitude, try to rest the first day.
Highly recommended. Great historical places, safe to walk at any time , nice people, good places to eat and traditional markets where you can buy peruvian handcraft.

Very historical buildings. the courtesy of the people was excellent throughout our Cuzco visit. I liked the great historical sites which were available in the city centre. You just have to be a bit patient with the traffic.

Beautiful Town. We loved wandering around the central areas of Cusco with no agenda or destination. There are beautiful streets, great views of the hillsides around and surprisingly perfect moments like an ancient Inka wall or a beautifully carved Spanish balcony. People were friendly and helpful. Enjoy.
beautiful. beautiful place, very much to see and admire. Inca people were amazing, great buildings. Cusco has an especial mystic.
Lovely Way to Spend Time. There are lots of historical places and shops to look at all within walking distance. The town centre is looked after very well and I always felt safe.

Beautiful quaint city!!!!. Spend an extra day! Food is good and people are lovely! Shops and land,arks everywhere you turn. The view from the square at night..fairy lights on the hill are just magical!
The center.. Yes.. a great place to start your daily adventures.. it never gets old.. find a hotel near this area..
History and Beauty. This is the best way to describe this place with Spanish architecture, Peruvian culture and all kind of people. Its a must know in Cusco.

Beautiful place!!!. Cusco is a magic place were the people can relax.
My trip was great.
I love peru :)
I will back in 2 years with my parents.

Hope to Return!. What a great city. Spanish architecture mixed with Quetchua culture. All kinds of restaurants, museums, markets, etc. Weather was cool but nice-make sure to wear your sunscreen, though.The area felt safe, very little panhandling and the haggling over prices was fun. the San Pedro market was excellent although as a norte Americano it was difficult to pass by many of the fruits and vegetables for fear of sickness. Great breads there, though.Area is best explored on foot as the roads are narrow and one way. Make sure to look for local entertainment at night!

The Best. There is so much to see here, beautiful city to explore with many history about the Inca civilization. The square of Cuzco It is a beautiful place to rest and try a typical chocolate in some of its picturesque wooden balconies

So much to see in this charming city!. There is so much to see here, but be sure to take a well-informed guide with you. The remains of the Inca civilization are all around you, but you must know where to look!
Ancient Inca city. different old worldly atmosphere - beautiful wooden balconies - a city different from any I've experienced
Cusco beautiful and colorful. Beautiful city to explore. The people are extremely helpful and nice. Don't miss the inexpensive massage. One hour massage including hot stones for less than 30.00$

Impressive inca town. Cusco is a sprawling city, expanding at a rapid rate. The centre however is unspoilt and fascinating. It combines the remains of ancient inca buildings and streets with fine colonial architecture and several impressive religious buildings. The inca foundations are particularly impressive.

Skip Lima and Spend Time Here. Cusco has everything I wanted to go to Peru to see. It is a lovely, safe place to walk day or evening. Great restaurants, places to shop all set in a beautiful historic district. The people are so warm and friendly, be sure to take home some souvenirs from the street vendors, many times women with their small children on their backs.
Beautiful. The site is beautiful, and very rich in history. For me the Catedral del Cuzco y just amazing. It is full of waoks of art and history. Also you could fill the peace in his walls.

Beautiful Town. Beautiful historic town with cobblestone walkways. Lots of shopping and delicious restaurants. I really enjoyed the Inca Museum with local craftspeople weaving on looms. I purchased handwoven wallets. Also I enjoyed learning about the Incan way of like and seeing ancient artifacts.
Beautiful. Get lost on the streets of central Cusco. Just gorgeous example of the architecture and city plan ot spanish cities in latin America. The city has kept the old look pristine!

Belly button of the World. That's what CUSCO means in Quechua. It is an amazing place in so many levels. History is intact in this suspended place where poverty and 5-star tourism meet every single day. Kids don't seem to realize that they are playing soccer in hundred-year-old cobblestones (and they are the cutest), not to say lama and alpaca pets roaming the narrow uphill steps. Hidden Starbucks share a sidewalk with an amazing 500 year-old Jesuit church... solid silver altars next to indigenous people asking for a "propinita" (tip) for taking a picture with you... That and more. Go and live your own story in this amazing place.

Amazing Architecture, Overwhelming Vendors. The city itself is quite beautiful and vibrant, but be prepared to be accosted by vendors at every turn. They do sell some incredible items (and some not so), but it gets exhausting to be offered something every five steps. Make your way to San Pedro market to experience how the locals live and enjoy the main plaza and the many museums. Practice saying "No, gracias" to ease your way through the myriad of people who make their living off of all the visitors. Don't miss out on getting pictures of the people in indigenes garb, usually with llamas or (more adorably) sheep in little knit caps. (They will want a Nuevo sole for their trouble.)

Beautiful, beautiful colonial city surrounded by Inca ruins. My favorite place in Peru (yes! better than Machu Picchu!) - the old part of the city is simply beautiful. Walk around or relax in the central square and enjoy! Don't miss the richly decorated cathedral and other churches!

Amazing square, one of the coolest places I have been in South America. One of the things I love about traveling is to find the city center, which is often around a large bustling square. Cusco has a great one, surrounded by amazing churches, restaurants, and shops. It was on par with Prague, Brussels, and the like in Europe. Just a wonderful place to soak up the culture of the city and enjoy life like the locals do.
Lovely City. We loved the Spanish Colonial architecture and the intriguing combination of Inca and Spanish cultures.
the heart of the city!. You will find anything you need for your stay in Cusco region, like restaurants, money change, and travel agency for the trips.

An Interesting Place. I came here with a friend and we explored on our own. We didnt take a tour but still had a good time. There is alot to see, and alot of history around. the square is very pretty and is worth taking the time to check out.
Congestion. I can't say liked or disliked since, we didn't see much of the city because we focus on out the city tour.
A great place to enjoy in the evening. The city center was great to grab a bite, shop and just take in the scenery in the evening. People were friendly, food was great, shops were varied and unique

The Tourist Center of Cusco. This area is clearly the tourist center for Cusco. Most of the hotels, restaurants and attractions are located in this vicinity. It wasn't until we adventured beyond this area that I realized how much bigger Cusco was (and where all the locals were!). Be prepared for people to try and sell you stuff or pull you into their restaurants. But also know that it is a pretty safe place at night to walk.
It is a great sight to see the colonial layout of the city. We loved every minute of it. The main square is very lively with local color as well as the various tourists that go by.
Heart of the city. This is the heart of the city and you should definitely try to book your hotel in this area. It is the best place for shopping, food, sightseeing, etc.

See the Cathedrals twice. See the Cathedrals I went to Mass every morning just to hear them singing and to see them as churches. It's also free. Then later on during the day you can get the tour of the Cathedral which costs money.

town square and cathedral. Beautiful view. Only a few feet from the hotel that used to be the convent. The traffic is pretty bad. The streets are very narrow and cobble stone. But, the Spanish architecture is wonderful. They have not tried to modernize it.

Cusco historic area. Loved walking around Cusco. People are very helpful, there is good police presence and the city is very clean. My wife and I walked several miles around Cusco, to the Marketplace which unfortunately was closed but the streets nearby were filled with local women selling numerous fruits, vegetables, cakes and cheese.

Cusco is a fab city for tourists!. We came to Cusco with high expectations, based on feedback from friends & we were not in the least disappointed!The historic heart of Cusco is so beautiful, with its mix of Inca walls & buildings, schemes by jowl with the Spanish colonial buildings. You can spend a day wondering around, admiring all the architecture, particularly the splendid earthquake resistant Inca masonry (which has repeatedly withstood the huge earthquakes which plague this part of the world far better than the more modern building techniques of the Spanish conquistadors!)There are plenty of hotels & restos in the historic centre. I'd certainly recommend that you stay in the historic centre, as close to the heart, the Plaza de Armas, as you can. I've written separate reviews about the various restos we tried out, as well as the various sights to see. If you enjoy trying out excellent local cuisine, you should try out Café Morena, run by a friendly Australian, Luke, & his Peruvian wife. Absolutely delicious food & a wonderful place for dinner!

Pretty Square. This square is very lovely and the shops that surroud it are good shopping spot. There is even a Mc Donalds if you feel like some fries. Skip the Inca museum just off the square it is a lot of stairs and little of interest. Linger instead around the center plaza with its charm and vendors. But watch out for the shoe shine guy our shoes went from 50 cents to 5 dollars when one shoe got a little more of something. Just say no to the shine and enjoy the cathedral at your leisure.
Beautifull surrounding. Safe and very casual, many nice buldings and coffee shops, restaurants. Often, events just appends there, religious, musical and social.
Simply beautiful!. Beautiful place, lots of history and restaurants around. Lost of different things to do around as well!

nice center of Cuzco. All the colonial and Inca architecture are amazing with the combinations of Cuzco valley, I was felling like in Inca and colonial times, we hope to come back another year, to stay longer in this beautiful places.

Fun place. I loved the downtown area of Cusco. We went downtown at night and did night photography. AWESOME! You need to be careful downtown late at night - three guys going out taking pictures and drinking coffee seemed like a great idea but we were approached several times with people trying to sell us drugs.
AMAZING. Cuzco is so rich in history. I felt lucky just to be able to visit this amazing city. The Cuzco Cathedral and the Qoricancha are places that visitors must see.
Lovely Place to Relax. Cusco historic centre is wonderful place to relax, chill, wander around local shops, restaurants, museums etc
history. great museums quaint shops and lots of historical landmarks . the main church is a must see. Super restaurants
What a amazing city. Strolling around in this magnificent city is a great treat. Cosy coffeshops, shops with inka souvenirs - look out for textiles.
Breathtaking. It's just beautiful. I wasnt prepared as I hadn't researched it but when I got there I was in awe the place has a certain energy to it and it's just a lovely place to visit

Beautiful!. I loved the historic center of Cusco - We were there for 3 days and I could have stayed for 3 more! There is a lot to do and see in the square and some nice places to eat and drink with balconies so that you can watch the people go by.

Amazon & Andes Tour. I cannot say enough great things about the Amazon and Andes tour arranged by Vertical Horizons Travel (www.verticalhoizonstravel.com). Our travel to Peru was seamless and there was enough tour time and private time where we did not feel suffocated by a rigid schedule. My favorite part of the tour was visiting Cusco and the surrounding sites. The central square was a site to see, with the old and new of the city intertwined. We were also able to visit the surrounding areas in the Sacred Valley, the Moray complex and the Mara salt pans. The ingenuity and innovative ideas of the Incas are all apparent in these sights and our guides were superb in narrating these tours. Overall it was an amazing trip.

Like No Other Main Square In The World. Historic Cusco in unique, a Spanish colonial city build over the foundations of the Inca capital. Don't make the mistake of thinking that Cusco is just a stopping off point on the way to and from Machu Picchu. Machu Picchu is one of the best destinations in the world, but 50% of the experience is Cusco if you have scheduled time to explore it.

Beautiful. Beautiful little square. Very narrow little streets with many little shops around. Beautiful place to see. Little restaurant with blue balconies, sorry- I don't remember the name of it, serves great alpaca steaks!

A place from out of a story book. The historic center of Cusco is charming, a place that can fire a poets or writers imagination. Its not only the buildings and architecture, but also the people. Andeans dressed up colorfully, cobble stoned streets, old baroque styled churches etc. There is a quaint cobble stoned pathway winding down the hill from Saqsayhuaman passing by San Cristobal church. Be sure to take this charming road down to the historic center. There are a couple of excellent restaurants (eg, Limo restaurant) at the plaza de armas.
Gorgeous. Great, as everybody knows. Advice, avoid the restaurants around the plaza, they are quite bad, for breakfast OK (how bad can that be !!).
Folk dancing. Pretty good for cheap entertainment only a short walk from the center of town, ask any one for directions, included in Cusco visitor pass
beautiful!. is like going back on time, people are really nice and it has still the walls and everything from years ago congrats!!!

Cusco is charming. There is plenty to suit many kinds of travelers here. Cusco is a genuinely lovely town. I found that after I'd done my sightseeing I was in no hurry to leave and I enjoyed wandering and puttering here. There are plenty of "B list" attractions that are quite fantastic in their own right. As a solo female traveler I always felt safe walking at all hours. Don't be in a hurry to leave.

Fascinating history. Cusco was the capital of the Inca Empire. The cathedral was build by the Conquistadors using stones from Inca temples. It is really three churches put together. Every altar and niche is covered in or embroidered with gold. No photos are allowed, but it's definitely worth seeing. Just be aware that Cusco is at 12,000 ft. and it takes a little time to acclimate to the altitude. Be sure to stay hydrated.

Diversion -are we selling Indian monuments cheap . We were on work at Lima and before going to next destination we had week end was free so decided to visit cusco and matchhu pitchhu.So here we were in great Inka seat of power many centuries ago,the city while preserving the old monuments turning in to a big Brick and concrete urban center.It's great location to spend and visit local and also visit sites of archeological importance in cusquena, chinqurra, matchhu pitchhu.Do not forget to taste Peruvian food at MAP Cafe and also other small eateries .It's a great experience except visit to historic sites is exhilarating but only thought in my mind was are we selling India cheap ?

Colonial Spanish Beauty. This square is beautiful and busy. It's the center, so there are expensive tourist restaurants, but there are some yummy more affordable eats just a little ways off the square.
Centro Historico de Cusco. Many good restaurants and shops very close by. This is the Hub of all the activities. Well worht hanigng out for a while as you vernture around .

A must see. The Central Historic District is one of the areas you must have on your list. If you can visit the week prior to Easter you can see the Easter Procession on the Monday before Easter. The whole area becomes alive. Visit at night too.

Great place to start your time in Cusco. I'd suggest getting a bite to eat at one of the many bars/cafés/restaurants around the plaza to take it all in while people watching, particularly when the sun's setting.

Beautiful. Cusco is a very beautiful colonial city and the plaza de armas is an enchanting place with its impressive cathedral and the fountain in the middle of the plaza, a tribute to the last Inca. Simply beautiful! The only thing that does not belong in this place are of course the fast food retaurants like KFC or Starbucks to name a few! Its a shame!
A balanced architecture.. Several narrow streets surrounding the main square. Some well -perserved colonial houses . A lot of restaurants with quality. Beautiful and safe.Not to be missed

beautiful. So beautiful....spent hours and hours just sitting on the main square seeing the world pass by...even if you are between tours take at least a whole morning to do nothing there sipping a fresh orange juice..

A walk in the America Colonial history. Select a guide for this… Most of the places have a history that needs to be listening.The Historical Center of Cuzco is a Spaniard city built over the Mayan city. You will have the opportunity of discover two worlds mixed in one city. Local people are great people and you will be welcomed all time.It is a secure city to walk around and to enjoy the different restaurants, bars, museums, etc that Cuzco offers you. Be careful with the altitude sickness. Cuzco is at very high altitude.
Beautiful view!. Thank you Renxo from Kaypi tours for such a wonderful tour of your beautiful city! Love the enthusiasm of Renxo treating us of his culture and historical legions!

Engaging sites of culture and history. Picturesque and engaging perspective of the marvelous culture with immense historical importance. Cusco was an exciting adventure during our experience as we enjoyed several days, both, with guided tours and time for 'self discovery, at one's leisure. Comfortable shoes are a 'must', clothing...layering is best, and a camera with plenty of 'storage' for photos! There are so many restaurants to choose from, a few with live entertainment during the evenings...delightful! The people who live and work in this area are friendly and helpful in suggesting additional sites and venues. We would have spent more days here, by choice.
Central Cusco is full of fun. There is so much to see and do in central Cusco... we ate, shopped and visited churches during our three days there!

our tour agency provided us a downtown tour. We had perfect weather and tour guides who spoke English to take us through all the attractions. We also had a free day to explore all the shopping markets by ourselves. Found a Chocolate/coffee cafe and the San Pedro Marketplace fascinating.

The Best. The best part of visiting Cusco (besides using it as a jumping off point for Machu Picchu) is just wandering around the center. You can get lost and always find something gorgeous just around the corner.

Wonderful old city with so much history.. This is a fascinating town offering so much of interest to the tourist . There are so many places to visit that it is impossible to describe them all. Cuso is the archaeological capital of the Americas. Visit the Tempe of the Sun, The Cathedral and the Barrio e Iglesias de San Blas. Wander the tiny streets, be fascinated by the friendly locals, have a pisco sour in one of the small cafes in the Plaza de Armas and watch the world go by. We visited during Corpus Christi which is a wonderful, colourful festival when the statues of saints and virgins from churches all around the area are brought to Cusco and paraded around the Plaza de Armes. I would like to point out that you do not need to be at all religious to enjoy and appreciate this spectacular event. We booked a balcony table in a restaurant overlooking the square and sat there for hours eating, drinking and enjoying what was for us a most unusual event. Every Sunday there is a colourful parade in the Plaza de Armes. .....The military, police, local business people, school children and tiny tots all take part . It is fun to watch. Cusco is a good centre for visiting the surrounding area and for trips a bit farther afield. Take the Andean Explorer train from Cusco to Puno. It is a marvellous journey as is the train trip to Machu Picchu. We have visited Cusco three times and love the place.

Wonderful sights. Walk through the different churches, Cathedral, San Ignacio, the plaza de armas itself, all is worth while We took a walking tour which I recomend: Free Walking Tour of Cusco, it works on a Tip basis.www.fwtperu.com
enchanting city. enchanting cobble streets, the people so nice just I think the prices to visit some churchs are too expensives. Really good restaurants and a lot of souvenirs

wow. if you love history and art take one day here at least!. Take a tour....you will learn a lot....then explore on your own....review Trip Advisor and Lonely Planet Before you go...to really do it right..take at least 9 hours
A lot of history. Many historical buildings with colonial designs, a beautiful Cathedral, shops and restaurants. One of the highlights of my trip in Peru.
Beautiful. Lovely huge Plaza in colonial style, beautiful buildings, typically dressed Peruvian people on the street and music from the Andes always present. This is a must stop in Peru.

Make this your first stop. This is a great place to start your tour of Cusco. I talked to one of the guys trying to sell paintings and he gave me a bunch of tips of what sights to see (I didn't have a guide book or tour). He recommended walking up to the church on the top of the hill for the best view of the city - and he was spot on.
Cusco. Interesting archaeologically, but polluted with too much traffic. Very touristy and very expensive in the centre of town. One or two good restaurants in around the centre.

Interestung. The historical center is very interesting place. Colonial architecture mekas you feel as being in Spain. There are also some fine examles of Inca architecture, mostly incorporated into Spanish colonial structures.Restaurants and bars are all around, giving the center thriving charm.If you are in Cusco, you will visit this place anyway - all roads lead to the historic center.
Quaint town. Loved the shopping and restaurants. We were fortunate to be here for the festivities of Carnival. Very fun!

Well worth the vist. A busy place at all times but the tourist police keep the hawkers at bay. You get a great view of the colonial city and could be in Spain given the structures around the square. If you have time though really take a walk through of the Jesuit Church just across from the Cathedral if you want to see where their money was spent.

Busier than it used to be. It is impossible to ruin Cuzco, given the incredible infrastructure left by the Incas and the Spanish, both. Having been there many times over the course of life, but not in the past 30 years, I was a little shocked by how many tourists there are, and the increase in prices. The basic experience is the same, and restaurant options are many, but I advise going at least two or three blocks off the main square to shop. Prices are half as much. Somewhere towards Ccoriquancha, but up towards Carmen Bajo, there is a Fair Trade store that has all you need in alpaca goods at good prices.

Lively and Interesting. Very charming setting but the day we were there they were having a taxi strike and the taxi drivers had shut down some of the main streets by placing large stones in the road. As the police tried to remove them the crowd of drivers would chase them away, which we thought was both interesting and hilarious. Lots of shops and restaurants throughout the main square to occupy your time.

Beautiful setting but not always peaceful. the views are astounding. The variety of architecture is amazing. Plenty of restaurants and some bars with balcony seating that would. Great place to people watch. But don't expect to be too peaceful as you get bombarded constantly with censors trying to get you to buy their wares. But that's ok, I get it. On a sunny day there it is the place to be!
one of the best. this is one of the best city centers of peru. very rich, quaint, picturesque and full of intereting buildings all around. very crowded by tourists during the day

Active Place!. Walk everywhere and walk slowly, the altitude is high! Grab a map.Even with a protest going on, it was a beautiful place. We ate, we shopped, we joined the protest for a bit too. The night time also offered up beautiful photos. Just be mindful that petty theft does occur there; stay in a group and keep your camera chord around your neck. Shops get less expensive as you move outward from the Plaza de Armas, so find those shops and haggle over the price! You will love it! Buy some snazzy shoes too; you'll know when you see them ;)There were vendors on the street selling delicious warm breakfast drinks, several parks, tourist information, museums, alpacas, I even spotted a Salsa Studio.

The Charm of Centro Cusco. The town is hopping! Visiting art galleries, meeting with local artists was so enriching. The restaurants and shopping are fun, colorful and make sure you get an alpaca sweater or socks and some colorful boots. The architecture of the Incan Empire was really amazing and to see how the Spaniards came in, conquered, occupied and built on top of Incan stones was a little hard to swallow. Walking the streets of stone was a very sacred feeling knowing that the Incan Empire created this beauty. It is a magical place and the city lights are night are magical.

A hour of gentle entertainment. Entrance to this centre is included in the General Tourist Ticket, and on this basis I would recommend that you go along to the dancing show one evening, as it doesn't cost you anything extra. The show starts at 7 and runs for one hour, there are live musicians and about twelve dancers who perform various folkloric style dances with a wide variety of brightly coloured costumes. It's quite low key and the seating is very average but we found it interesting as a display of the local customs and traditions.

Best Plaza de Armas. The Plaza de Armas in Cuzco is probably one of the most beautiful in the whole country. There are plenty of restaurants and some coffee shops where you can relax before touring in the rest of the town. Majestuous is the Cathedral. I have heard it is beautiful inside. Unfortunately, I didn´t have the chance to visit it inside as it is only opened at specific times. I believe you also need to pay an entrance fee.
The best city in the World.... The best city in the World... 'Must see' place. Be careful if you have dirty boots :) Local children will be very annoying trying to clean them :)
rich history. great place, open space... travel the best during spring or early summer as february is rainy season

Everyday for week. While in Cusco, this was just a small uphill, and downhill, stroll from our hotel. Great architcture, friendly crowds, nice to relax and be part of the old city. Great starting point for going up and down the small unique streets in the are.
Beautiful area . This is a great area of the city. Lots of interesting places to please everyone. Wonder around and there are bargains to be had.

Wonderful. We stayed 3 nights in the Historic Center of Cusco and were pleased with that amount of time. There's tons to do and see. The history is amazing and still so much to see. The Center is busy and active; always interesting. There are lots of museums, churches, sites, banks, shops, bars and restaurants. The Plaza de Armas is a wonderful square with some green space and benches for taking a break and just people watching - very enjoyable.

Colonial architecture/ modern convenience. Very picturesque, authentic atmosphere. Enjoyed seeing the local people. Be aware of the altitude before deciding to walk very far, and be wary of the speeding autos sharing the narrow cobblestone streets! Beautiful city.

magic. The city of Cusco is a magical place with a lot of energy, you just have to be in this place to feel a lot of energy, magic of a city that has many ancient places that you can admire walking, people are very friendly and helpful, this city is a wonder you have to visit.
Time Warp. Beautiful, it felt like you were going back on time. Lots of shopping and great churches. The people were very kind and honest

history densely packed. The old part of town is full of spanish churches and destroyed Inca ruins. All prt of history. Lots to see. But old town also includes a Starbuck's, as expensive as north america, McDonald's supersizing things and Colonel Sanders strutting his stuff. All totally out of place. Tourists everywhere and money changers like a plague. But still needs to be visited and explored. Beware of the expensive museum pass that you must buy, check expiry and whether you can actually get to ll the places within the time frame of the pass. Interesting old city.

Real History. Really enjoyed the Old Town with all the narrow cobbled streets, wonderful squares and lively atmosphere. Take time to explore the surrounding streets, walk outside the usual tourist routes to discover cheap restaurants and bars. Don't be afraid to walk into either, the people are very friendly and will go out if their way to point you towards food and drink in their premises. Visit the vegetable market four blocks off the main square. Ask any of the traffic ladies or police and they will direct you. It's a wonderful city enjoy..
Impressive city. A picturesque city with remnants of Inca precise stonework and spanish colonial buildings, very grand city

Clean place. The place is always clean, no any striped on the walls.
there are lots of street vendors approach you to offer their products (since keychains to paints).

Cusco!. Cusco is an enchanting town. Particularly its historical center which is well maintained and one of the richest old colonial Spanish cities in the new world. The city is worth a prolonged stay, not just as a stepping stone into going to machu pichu.

The navel of the world. No one downtown area on the world can be as beautiful as this. Two churches overlooking the square, never else seen before.
Huge contrats between the historical ancient city and the big modern world going on around it

Just beautiful. Favourite city centre in Peru. Cusco historical centre is not only beautiful and home to many magnificent buildings, but it's a lovely, friendly, relaxed place with some great cafes, restaurants and places to sit and watch the world go by. It is also really easy to see the entire place on foot. It was easily my favourite city centre in the whole of Peru. There are tons of fantastic food options, possibly a bit limited when it comes to bar options, but if you sit out on any of the balconies around the square on a sunny day with a few drinks you can't but have fun. A must-see on any trip to Peru.

Worth the visit. This is a must see when it comes to cities with local flavor. The people are welcoming and the environment is very relaxing. There is no stress in this city but do take the time to learn the history of it.

If you miss this you will miss the best of Peru.. Cuzco was merely a stepping off place for Machu Piccu in our minds...until we were there. The culture, the sweet people, the food, the history, the arts, the cathedrals all call us back to this place we nearly missed. The altitude was a challenge for us. One of our group, an older and perhaps frail person, ended up in the hospital. Do not take this lightly but realize that there are advance steps to take that work and that this one person was of more than 100 people in the whole group. Read and preapare for the 11,000+ feet of elevation. If you do you will meet a rare experience worth all the time and effort required to get there from and international origination. We hope to return and explore this facinating place more.
amazing!. all the history, the churches,the people !an amazing place to visit.you have to see the Jesuits Church, The Cathedral and the cocoa museum

Thunder and lightening. The Plaza d'Armas is beautiful, a garden surrounded by arcades. The Jesuit's church overlooks the square with an excellent view from the tower. Our trip was somewhat curtailed by the torrents of rain running down the streets, but the stonework of the Incas the carvings of the incoming Spanish, and quirky takes on the last Supper with maize, potatoes and guinea pig. Obviously lots of tourist stuff, but no hassle like you get in some places.

Party everyday hehehe. I liked the Coricancha, Sacsaihuaman, central market, some night clubs...like indigo bar, nice place to met beautiful people and make friends...also ikukus bar...very good one...
like in Spain but in America. amazing how it seems that you are in old Spain when you are in America, and also the Inca ruins are unique (the 12 corner Stone, the main temple), really worth

Dream come true. The history about it, the architecture, the streets and corners and the food! Our hotel, Palacio Manco Capac was amazing..an old hacienda with only 5 guest rooms, great service and beautiful view Cusco is great...only thing to complain about: the street vendors, too aggressive, in your face, didn't like that!.

Beautiful!. The square is beautiful, night or day. At night, the photos are beautiful with the lighting. Be sure to walk the alleyways that surround the square, and enjoy this city so charming and quirky.

Cusco, a royal Inca city. Having a excellent tour guide to show and explain all the modern building sitting on the Inca ones. To see the ancient stones but also to understand what this city meant to the Inca and how much history has been lost.

Beautiful. The historic center is full of life and color. If you are in Cuzco you will undoubtedly spend some time here. Its a great place to people watch and generally get a feeling for the town. After you are done walking around and exploring the town, grab a drink or coffee at one of the places on around the square and enjoy the view.
Month of Peru exploring. loved the country, mountains, rivers, canyons, the Inca History ... disliked the smog , the constant never ended car horns and noise factors.
Really interesting city. We spent days wandering around Cusco and there is loads of things to see. The main square is a good place to sit down in and see life go by

Get lost in the streets of Cusco. Get lost in the streets of Cusco, don't go to the tourist trap restaurants. If you like history check out the Temple of the Sun and the main Cathedral where the Inca Garcilaso is buried.
Lovely place to wonder. A lovely town/city that allows a lot of space to be available to really appreciate what is around you.Some beautiful historic buildings all around.

One of my favorite places in Cusco. I love this area from the amazing resturants, lounges & clubs near by, shopping, walking tours and organic ice cream they make before your eyes. I literally fell in love sitting by the fountain talking for hours and walking around this beautiful city. Very safe for solo women travelers and lots to do, you do know how to say no firmly to unwanted solicitation of goods or services but this is common in many places. I would recommending finding a hotel close to this area as you will spend most of your time here, I can't wait to go back.

great for rooming aroind. Cusco has a lot of sites to show, but Centro Historico is just good enough to keep us busy for 1 or 2 days visiting its museums, churches, markets and restaurants. Best time to avoid either so many people or raining season would be May to June and mid September to mid October.

Interesting old town. Walkable and lots of sites, archbishops palace was excellent for Cuscueno art and the La Casa Concho museum about Macho Picchu was interesting (good to see after visiting). Every restaurant was relatively inexpensive with US dollars and offered different and delicious dishes.
Really still has athmosphere. Lovely surroundings with the Andes. Not to energetic sales people. They do accept a no thx:) xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxcxxx

Cusco. filthy dirty city the only interesting part was the old city, lots of restaurants and shopping, was only there to transfer to Mucchu Pucchu. Be care about the altitude it hits you especially if you are from the beach as we are.

Great area. This was a fun area in cusco. Don't sit on the grass! Not allowed! Who knew? Lol. Great reastaurants and lots of really good stores to buy some great baby alpaca sweaters and scarves. The market is close by and not for me but and amazing experience to see the way the locals live.

Old Inca Capital. Still lots of traces of the original Inca city built on by the Spanish. For me there are just too many tourists.. Perfered Ayacucho as a city to explore. Lots of good restaurants to choose from , the market was great to explore. Whent north of the main plaza to explore the back streets and was rewarded with good food and real locals
Should be cleaner!!. Should be cleaner (lots of dog poop and smelly alleys) but remains a spectacular sight!! After many years in Cusco the Plaza de Armas never bores.

Puma and Serpent. Around Cusco there are hidden gems. Around the corner from the famous 12 sided stone on Hatunrumiyoc, we found the Puma & the Serpent wall to be fabulous. This is between Inca Roca and Hatunrumiyoc, where Artisanias Asunta is. The small boy who showed us the configuration with his very long pointing pole was quite a character, give him a good tip, he's worth every sol. Artisania Asunto opposite the wall is ran by friendly people and prices are reasonable too.
Great museum. We both liked the various examples of Inca stonework & how the pieces were fitted & locked together. We had no dislikes.
Worth it. Very nice, but you should go before you visit Machu Pichu. Nothing is beautiful after Machu Pichu. Go with or without a guide. Ruins arent that great there, shopping is fun.

HISTORIC CUSCO. Cusco is a very historic city where indigenous culture meets European culture. The evidence is found in the architecture of Centro Historic Cusco. It is only part of of Cusco I am familiar with, so I may be bias in saying it is the best part. I spent a week walking the streets of Historic Cusco and enjoyed every minute in spite of altitude sickness. It is safe with many restaurants, cafes, interesting people to watch, and very artistic. I hope you have a positive experience when you visit Historic Cusco also. Happy Travels!!!!
Marvelous Colonial City. You can breathe the pre-colonial and colonial history in this city. From Incan ruins to colonial Spanish monuments, Cusco says it all.
Machu Picchu. The respect the people around show it for the archeological sites. The incredible engineer and architectural achievements of the Incas

Must visit. The grandeur of the main cathedral was stunning. For anybody interested in history, architecture, religion or art, I would highly recommend. Most younger kids and teenagers would not appreciate it. We bought an integral ticket for 30 S. The ticket included an audio guide, which was good after you figured out how to use it (there were no numbers on the walls, so you had to guess a little to find the correct item). Audio was of professional quality through a tablet. (You'll have to leave and ID to get a tablet, many people left their passports, but I'd recommend leaving a drivers license or something a little less critical just in case). You'll need ~ 1 h for this cathedral.
Perfect Cuzco. the energy. the cuzco feel. the humble welcome and nature of everyone around us. the visit to the artisan market and the women's weaving center was a terrific find.

Very Educated Guides from local University. We were really impressed by the wealth of knowledge displayed by our guide who had specialised in his native history at the local university and spoke a very fluent English. We were taken to the Dominican Convent as well as to the outskirts where we "invaded" a local wedding reception. The work of local artisans was also drawn to our attention and we found well-crafted souvenirs.

Amazing!!. This place is absolutely amazing!! From the hill above at some of the archeological sites you can see three different courtyards, these used to be one large courtyard during the Incan time. Each one now is still so amazing!!

Cusco is one of the highlights of a trip to Peru. The historic centre of Cusco is beautiful, photogenic, interesting. It is convenient to walk around. We caught a colourful parade. Each side street has another whole adventure waiting for you.

I couldn't be more pleased!!!. Cuzco was amazing, without a doubt, every single corner holds a piece of history, there's no way you'll be bored, there's so much to see, every house, every museum, every church, every monument, every single restaurant or posada; everything has something to say, and walking along its streets is the only way that you can feel such an incredible vibe that connects you with their past, their traditions, their culture; I have always believed that you need to do as locals do sometimes to better understand what you are witnessing, for me it was such an experience, I found Latin American history fascinating, without being an expert, you don't need to be, to enjoy that much they have to offer, so wear comfortable clothes and shoes, be aware of the temperatures that often changes, and pack hats, gloves and scarves, bring water with you and cash to enjoy the fantastic gastronomy around. Also I knew the language and that was super helpful, so if you don't, ask for help in your hotel/hostel about local tours, there are millions of agencies, but if you look for locals, you'll get the real deal as they might have better knowledge of the Country and the city itself, they have really skilled people that will even offer you tours in english, french, portuguese, italian, and to my very own surprise even chinese , just to make an example. Enjoy!!!

Incredible town. Just came from Lima and this more what I expected in Peru. Lots of charming colonial architecture as well as craft shops with local artisans and regions well represented. Nice quality, worth buying a souvenir that is local and not a spoon or a shot glass with Cusco stamped on it. Plenty of restaurants with Traveladvisor ratings.

so much history. We decided to do a private tour of Cuzco and it was great! The guide helped us understand the history, how and why the buildings looks the way they look, differences in paintings. We also went to the main church on Christmas day and it was amazing to see all their traditions and people dancing on the streets with colorful clothes
Excelent place. All were wonderful, nice place to visit in all season, many things to do in Cusco and nearby places.

Organize your Visit and get ready for Uau!. There are a few tricks to visit Cuzco: City pass for museums, churches and historic places can get confusing if you don't know what you are doing. And leave some time just to walk around. It a great place to wonder with no destination.
Great location to see a lot of the best Cusco has to offer. Looking for great food and drink with a relaxed pace, this is it. Best massages for less than $20! (They're professional)

A Magical City. Found it extremely interesting and loved the feeling of discovering new spots. It's never ending!!
Along with the monuments and churches you have the market of San Pedro where you can spend half day browsing around and enjoying there amazing fresh fruit juices!!

Decked out for Christmas. Since we were in Cusco for Christmas, the plaza was ready for the holiday with lights, trees and a special nativity scene. Everyone was out looking, visiting and having a good time - and we did too!

A charming mixture of Inca & Spanish architecture. We really like this beautiful city and were happy to see that the historic centre has been preserved for new genration of visitors. We did appreciate the mixture of Spanish and Inca architectures specially around the Koricancha and Main square not to mention San Blas.The historic centre can be easily visited on foot and following a tourist map, available at any hotel.

Beautiful city with a vintage feel. I loved walking around. The views are great. You feel transported back in time. The food around the central plaza is great. However, you do feel sick due to altitude so better to take the medicine.

Rare Air in Cusco. Cusco is beautiful in the historic centre with spectacular Christian churches and Inca ruins. The only down-side is the lack of oxygen. Both my wife and I had to have oxygen at the hotel to combat altitude sickness. The view from Saksaywaman Inca ruins is worth the trip up another 1,200 feet above the City centre. It was worth the stop on the way to Machu Picchu the next day.
Plaza. The central plaza is bustling tourist area with plenty of landmarks as well as shopping. There are many trinket sellers, but the quality goods are in stores. :)

Nothing special. The downtown area has beautiful architecture, but is dirty and packed with people offering you all sorts of services and goods. If you are in town, it is something you can't really avoid, but don't expect much.

Charming city. Cisco is out of this world... A little crazy and super busy with tourists and locals.... Beautiful buildings ... Many local women with little babies on their backs.. A true adventure.. Super safe place! One of the highlights of my South American trip!

The Cusco experience. Cusco was a city with a diverse range of experiences.
It was a cultural feast in terms of what the Incas offered. The city is filled with quaint streets and shops and restaurants. The people are lovely.

WOW!. Amazing city. So much history and culture. Simply astonishing architecture.
Walk around, enter the churches and temples. Sit at he magnificent plaza. Imagine the old Inca capital.

Nice Place to Stay. Staying at the historical centre means everything you need is in walking distance: ancient ruins, churches and old buildings/urban features dated back to Incan days, good food, beautiful plazas, shops even supermarket.
However, too many cars around so be careful when crossing the streets, those cars wouldn't stop for you.

Historic Cuzco. Peru's first city for historic sights. The Inca walls are fascinating and there are at last a dozen Colonial churches not to be missed. The entry fee system is complicated but it can be evaded by attending a Mass service; I attended an evening service at La Merced, and was well advised to get there early as the seats filled up quickly.
Nice. There are a couple of cathedrals right on the square but are only open from noon - 1PM and again at 6. Lots of hawkers. Nice fountain.

Grab a map - but just wander.... if you like wandering cities for a day with only a rough idea of the path you'll take, Cusco is a city for you. We planned roughly what sites we wanted to see in each 'neighborhood' but didn't follow a path with precision. This is a city where that's the best way to see it. Head up taking it all in and not consulting a map every 10 mins. If you take a wrong turn, chances are you'll stumble upon something of interest. Enjoy!

Saqsaywaman. I found the history of Saqsaywaman very interesting. It was the former Empire of the Incas. The terrace walls where the stones are so closely spaced that a single piece of paper will not fit between they, is mind blowing. This precision, combined with the rounded corners of the blocks, the variety of their interlocking shapes, was fascinating for me. Make sure you pack some food and water before you go because there is nowhere to purchases them.

GREAT CITY, AMAZING !!!!. this is the most unique city i ever visit in my life time, never seen anything like this before. the Peruvian people are so very kind, i recommend to walk around the city as much you can . they have great restaurant they include local tradition & even western food too. very gorgeous spanish architecture over incan ruin. please dress warm because its very cold your 3000 metres high attitude.
Awesome Experience of Cuzco. November was a good time to visit . We also tried their local dishes( roasted pig, civeche and guinea pig in a restaurant overlooking the city of Cuzco.

My favorite city in Peru. A lovely central plaza and a lively market a short walk away. Good restaurants and lots to see. The trip into the city after sunset with street dogs and garbage did show the other side of urban Peru but even then the streets were full of people going about their daily business. There is much pride here in the Inkan traditions and contributions and that was good to see.

Great way to meet Peruvians. Very unique city center with so much local culture. The people of Peru are kind and friendly, the nicest people I have ever met. You see so many local secrets when you tour the center of Cusco. The centre of Cusco is a great place to visit for a few days at least.

gorgeous.. known to ancient incans as the center of the universe, it really is the center of things: amazing architecture, cathedrals, museums, restaurants. very gorgeous spanish architecture over incan ruins. colonial tragedy and beauty at the same time.

To be visited. Avoid the toursitic bus (20 soles as of 11/2014). Buses are not allowed to enter Plaza de Armas and are too large to drive through some narrwo streets. Should you want to go to the large Cristo uphill arrange a taxi drive (which pays if you are not alone).Avoid the so-called factory outlets around the Cristo. They are not cheaper than shops in the city (where you can bargain: this is a must!!). If you think you have to buy something typical look out for stores of non-governmental organizations (beside the church).Bookings for excursions to Valle Sagrado or elsewhere can be made in travel shops at and around Plaza de Armas. Beware of too cheap trips to Machu Picchu (they may leave you nowhere waiting for a pickup that never arrives, although that may be funny too)
So beautiful. Cusco is a must see place in the world. Beautiful architecture, beautiful people and great food and shopping!

A Beautiful Historical Place - A Must. Almost every corner has a building with a lot of history. You can find the main square where Tupac Amaru II was killed by the Spaniards; Inca Garcilazo De la Vega's house; the Cathedral and several other astonishing churches; and on and on...

Cusco is beautiful. I loved Cusco. So historical and charming. There are so many small handicraft shops and resturants. Downtown is beautiful, specially at night with the lighting. The people are nice and welcoming

Nice plaza with two competing churches. The square/plaza is very nice. Cool fountain in the middle, lots of places to eat or have a coffee, but no outdoor cafes. Cost to enter the Cathedral is 25 soles, steep! and you can't take pictures. I didn't go in.

Amazing Place. Whle in Cusco you have to walk the area around the Main Square known as Plaza das Armas. This place is amazing with all the old buildings and beautiful mountains that surround the area. It is very clean and there are police everywhere. At night the square changes totaly when the lights come on. A must see while in Cusco.
Very nice. Possbile to know the Plaza das Armas, nice streets, nice restaurants.You can go around just by walking

Do not miss it!. Cusco and its Plaza de Armas deserves to be visited with some time to enjoy and stay just to see people walking around.
There are banking, cafes, beautiful flowers and it Is very clean! During the night Is is another nice and enjoyable experiente. There are beautiful yellow lights chandeliers that transform that part of Cusco! Don not missi it!
Great centre. If you have limited time take a tour for very affordable rate... they can show you best locations in the center
So much to see & do. Before you go, research the museums & historic sites; create a wish list; map it out on your own or share with a guide. I could easily have spent several more days in Cusco.

Incredible. This place is one of the most beautiful in the world. Remain in awe of the location and the architecture, with the mountains setting. Bluest sky makes for incredible photos. Side streets are fascinating. Square is a great place to just sit and watch the world go by. Surrounded by great restaurants.Make sure you get at least a day to enjoy.
sightseeing. Plaza de Armas, the Cathedral, local market to see what locals bought in their everyday lives, shopping , restaurants

Must visit for one week. Centro Historico de Cusco is a very nice place to visit with a lot of interest places in the areaYou can find good accommodation, restaurants and coffee shops. You can find agencies for travel planning visits out of the city. I recommend one day walk to ruins: Saqsaywaman/Q'enqo/Tambomachay/Puca Pucara
Nice center area. Very nice main square, beautiful churches around it. Try to go to the museums and bars around. They have plenty options.

spend at least one day here. There is ALOT of interesting places to see and visit here and we are really glad we opted to spend part of 2 days doing so. You can easily use the map of the Centro Historico to get around but it is spread out over a fairly good area so be prepared to do some walking or using taxis to get around.

Most delightful sights and tastes I found in Peru. Cusco was the most intriguing of the cities we visited in Peru. The preservation of Inca and Colonial architecture embedded in the historical district has served the city well. By celebrating its past Cusco effectively benefits from the tourist economy which has contributed to an improved infrastructure for the city .

Unmissable!. The historic centre of Cuzco with its cathedral, is full with colonial style houses all around and with dozens of cuzqueñas dressed in the famous skirts and the typical hats. There are plenty of streets to admire the colonial style balconies and see local craft shops. Highly recommended!
