Interesting place to visit and eat. The center of town is really interesting with some good museums, restaurants ans small streets to explore. You can't spend too much time at the Plaza de Armas as there are too many hawkers bothering you.

4day/3night Cusco-Machu Picchu. I liked the ruins and how they are being preserved. I cannot say I disliked any of the trip. The high altitude was a little difficult but if you take your time you can cope with it.
Beautiful centre of Cusco. A wonderful centre with lots of squares and churches to see. A great place to wander around and visit the markets and shops or just sit and have a coffee.
Wonderful. Cusco is a beautiful Andean city. The central part is warm and welcoming. Prices are reasonable off the main plaza.

Golden visit. Visit the Cathedral it is full of gold and is beautiful. Look out for the painting of the last supper with guinea pig for the supper. The town square is very picturesque but it is the people who make this city.
Very Fun Place. There is a wealth of things to see and do around the plaza. Museums are really interesting and inexpensive!

Great architecture. The town is full of beautifull churches and other buildingsYou can walk from one square to another and go up the narrow slipery stone streets spending easily 2 or even 3 days doing that...Of course, that´s the old part of the townIf you walk from the Bus Station to Plaza Mayor (as I did) you will see there are 2 diferent Cuscos...but that´s another story...

Rich!. Cusco is a wonderful town, rich with Inca and Viceroyal legacy. The many churches and plazas make the environment welcoming and cozy, and you can find Inca ruins and influence everywhere, from the walls to the food, to clothing and art. Even the people will often speak in Quechua. Learn some words and make some friends, they are great people!
Safety for All. Plenty of Police presence throughout Central Plaza and surrounding areas. It is certainly noticeable in Downtown Cusco area.

Great city to visit. it is a safe city with nice spanish churches around the plaza. At the center there is a very nice park and some nights they have a cultural dancing show. The streets are full of restaurants, shops and adventure agency. We choose marcelo adventures because it has a great tour and the cheapest in the area. You can get tours of maras y moray for 25 soles, city tour for 15 soles, sacred valley for 25 soles and you need to buy the boleta tour to enter in some sights. If you buy the full one it will cost you 130 soles that is valid for 7 days. There is a different price for locals and for foreigners. That is the down side it is half the price for locals. The buildings are mixed of spanish and inca style houses. At night the mountains look like a bid christmas tree because of the lights from the houses. It has a breath taking view. The people who worked at the tour work together in one. It doesn't matter which tour agency they are from. They look after the tourist. The tour is in English and spanish and some circumstances it depends how many in the group they can do Japanese and Koreans well. The hotels are range from 5 star hotel to hostels. The altitude make you a little bit sick but you can always buy the altitude sickness pills. I suggest to relax on the first day and do the tours the next day to help you adjust. Overall a nice city to visit.
♥♥♥. What a splendid city! The present, the colonial past and the pre-Colombian past all meet up at once. Great food, wonderful architecture.
Historic Cusco. Beautiful, historical city. People were friendly and helpful, accommodations very good. If you love history, like I do, this is a great place to visit.
beautiful place. the city is great the hotels are expensive for the quality and those are the problems I think i go back but i expect dyas when don't go many people maybe in november or march
Lovely area. Great place to walk around and take in the atmosphere. Loads of churches, museums and restaurants to discover. At all times the main area has a nice buzz. I felt safe at any time.

A lot af traffic and culturw. Comming with kids and being more into nature Cusco is a hazzle. Busy, noisy, trafic and dirty. After a lot of ruins in Sacred valley and MP we should have stayed closer to the river in a lower altitude. Culturally and as a hangout with good food it's ok. Not for kids

Beautiful downtown area. Great to walk around and explore. Nice museums and buildings to see and explore. The main cathedral was a nice visit, but the museums nearby were even better. The main plaza is a nice place to sit for a while and people watch.

Cusco - not only for one night. Cusco offers a lot of things to do: leanr spanish, eat out, party out, enjoy museums or hike to the near by Inca ruins. Do not only stay for a night before you head off to Machu Picchu.

More than expected. Whether you're a sophisticated traveller or a back packer or in between there will be something here for you. Fabulous churches,shops,restaurants and tour companies taking you to other to be viewed sites both near and far. A very interesting place and well worth a visit.

A South American gem. What a great place to visit on your Peruvian adventures.There is so much to see and do that you don't know where to start.Sensory overload in the order of the day but relax and spend at least two full days exploring and discovering the backstreets.

Stop over to Machu Picchu. Beautiful city to walk around and explore streets, churches, restaurants & shops. Walked through San Pedro market, where the locals shop. Stayed here before and after our trip to Machu Picchu. Only downside of the city was packs of dogs roaming around. Felt very safe walking around the town.

Beautiful colonial city built on inca capital. Loved the casual atmosphere, the happenings on the main square, an international meeting place like no other. We purchased a 30 soles pass for five attractions which included the cathedral (normally 25soles by itself), the art museum, San Blas church and its famous wood carved pulpit and others. Many tourist traps and street vendors but a quick "No gracias" helps. Colorful artisanship, great inexpensive dining, many hotel options, easy access to many ancient attractions, friendly locals, all in a relatively small city of about 500,000 people, half of it orob tourists.

Great location to explore the city of Cusco. We visited this city on our way to Machu Picchu. This is a fantastic city that is very easy and safe to explore. We highly recommend visiting this location and spending some time to get to know the area. It takes a few days to acclimate to the elevation and it definitely makes it hard to walk around the hills that are throughout the city but there is enough to see that it's worth the effort.
Great city to visit and tour. Very good place to visit. Cusco is a great city to explore on your own. It is very safe and there are a great deal of places that are very informative and interesting.
Walk friendly fun. Lots of history and "walk" friendly, really did not need taxis for anything. So many excellent restaurants to choose from. Clean and friendly town.
Great city to explore. Most of the historic part is walkable. Lovely squares to explore and don't miss San Pedro market. Apparently this is the best place to buy gifts. Try the free walking tour.
you must see Placa de armas. Very nice city center with lots of things to see and to visit. you can do a nice city ride in an old tramway waggon.
Lots of nice places. There are lots of places to eat: definetly eat "empanadas" and have a cold beer or pisco sour in any place overlooking the plaza
Beyond my expectations. The city of Cusco is just fantastic. So much to see, so much to do. I think that you could live there for 6 months and you would still have things to discover.
Great architecture. The place has a lot of history and the streets were cobble stones.Very quaint town. Oxygen conveniently located all around if needed due to the height above sea level.

A lovely city. Cusco has a busy life, with a lot of attractions to do: There are several churches, old Inca time buildings, colonial stype constructions. The geography contributes to make it more interesting, the central market is a place to know, and the handcrafts are surely one additional attraction
Lovely city centre. Cusco city centre is very attractive, with rows of Spanish style arches, a superb Cathedral, an abbey, parks and plazas.

Great place to explore. We stayed there only day and a half, but wish we had stayed longer! There is a lot see and do in Cuzco. From cobble stone streets to old buildings - a charming city. A local market is not too far from the Plaza de Armas. Lots of local eateries to Starbucks in the vicinity :-) Something for everyone. Buy local chocolates if you are in the market - cheaper and better!

A Lovely Town to be marooned in.... Ended up spending longer than expected in Cusco following head and arm injuries when falling down the steps in a museum ! It's a beautiful town with so many nice cafes and restaurants. There are good museums, old Inca stonework, colonial Spanish churches, dozens of good shops and stalls to buy all those peruvian souvenirs. At least two good chocolate shops too. It is an endlessly fascinating place and it is also safe and well policed. The locals will try to sell you paintings and crafts etc, but a polite No, gracias soon sees them on their way.

Cobblestones!. Very quaint city with lots of cobblestone streets. Take a city tour bus right away to get acquainted with what's available. Many have mentioned the amount of pick-pocketing. Though I didn't have any experience with this, there were plenty of shady looking characters. I was mostly near the Plaza de las Armas center, which is probably your safest bet at night. You'll be approached by vendors constantly. If you're not interested, give them a tactful and firm "no" and walk on. I recommend eating in the restaurants on the second floors that offer balcony views. (Balconies are everywhere!) When choosing a hotel, you may consider looking at reviews regarding noise. Church bells and firecrackers can start as early as 5:30 in the morning!
A great city square.. A brilliant city square, bordered by old and new, with the Cathedral and municipal buildings, alongside restaurants and boutique shops.

Great Centre. Really nice feel of an old colonial town. Very pleasant to look at and despite the obvious tourism has a nice vibe of it's own which adds to it's character.Felt quite safe wandering round the centre, even at night

Amazing stone work. Just walk around all of Cuzco's monuments and you'll be amazed at the stone work. I must have taken 100 photographs of the stones as they are so impressive. On one of the days we were there, there was a street march with thousands of participants, dancing and performing with the bands. I stopped to watch for a few minutes and finally left more than two hours later. The colour and movement were quite emotional and overwhelming at times.
First day of the trip. Very interesting history you learn about the city. Cusco is a very underrated city, safe and clean. You can see around the city the influence of Spain.
a brief history. This place gives you a history of Cusco from Inca to the arrival of Spaniards. It's located pretty close to the Cusco city and a walking distance from the centre.

A buzzing centre!. Lots of great places to eat. Interesting history and architecture. Good shopping - although of course mainly aimed at tourists and more expensive than the local markets and smaller towns.

Great to stroll around .... take it easy!. I liked it all, great city! I atarted with one of the churches uphill, and then through the barrio San Blas, before getting to the Plaza de Armas, the center of old town.

See an ancient civilization. See a people relatively unchanged for 35,0000 years. An accident of natural barriers and malaria have kept this continent pristine. You only want to witness it and leave it unscathed. I was called "Marilyn" and "muneca" which means doll and you never realized you would look that way to others.

Beautiful and peaceful. Visit the historical city in the experience of a life time !
Cusco is very noisy with a lot of traffic in the city but the charm of the road and the atmosphere is unique.
Cathedral. Liked all noted attractions. Dusty and dry with chaotic traffic and roads. Locals very helpful. Shopping good and food excellent. All round good place to visit.
So much to see. History was everywhere. The how and why of the Incas on every street. Always so much happening in the cathedral plaza.
Very cool square. I really liked this square. It felt very european and had some fun restaurants. They had a free concert one evening on the square. Good times.
What a town. The food is amazing. Fresh from the gardens, prepared to perfection! Lots of shopping and sights. You can walk to some ruins from the town square.

Absolutely picturesque!. The main plaza of Cusco is not only picturesque, it is the epitome of a romantic, South American square. The Cathedral is a "must see" (no pictures but you are given a CD with everything on it) and try and schedule a meal somewhere looking out over the square - delightful!

Historical Plaza. Spacious historical area which included two large cathedral and numerous shops and restaurants. At the center was a nice plaza. Fun to observe the gathering of many locals, especially in the evening time.

Very Touristy -- TON of street hawkers. Cute historic area well worth visiting. But be prepared for the onslaught of street hawkers selling "100% alpaca" hats, "massages", carvings, and various other sundry items.

My favourite city!!. I loved the peaceful surroundings. No neon signs, billboards,...
There are a lot of people in the center but it is not crowded, you feel relaxed in this city.
gorgeous. a must see, one of the most beautiful cities in peru. good base for travel to macho picchu. Will like to visit again some day

Beautiful. The Inca and Spanish Colonial history as well as the architecture
are beautiful. We appreciated the old churches and art work.
Very nice place. Very nice place with wonderful landscapes, churches, temples and a lot of history about Inca Empire.
beautiful city. spend some time here - its lovely. Lots of shops and restaurants. Definately wished we had stayed here longer, especially before the trek.
Great! Great! Great!. Cusco is extraordinary, full of surprises, this is a must, you really have to spend at least one full day in Cusco and in its surroundings.

Heart of a great city. A must visit area if you are in Cusco. Exploring surrounding area is particularly rewarding if you know a bit of Inca and colonial history and can see the blending of these cultural influences in the narrow streets and architecture.

most visited. Centro Historico is one of the most visited destinations. In this part of town, there are several impressive landmarks to visit such as Coricancha, Jardin Sagrado, Hosp Antonio Lorena. Centro Historico has a lot to offer: famous sites, great restaurants and a range of exciting entertainment. I liked it very much

Pretty part of town. A different feel from the rest of town, quite well maintained and pretty in a different way. We almost missed it because of unexpected construction that was blocking the easiest access, and some of the sites we had wanted to see were closed when we arrived so be sure to check hours and availability.

Just enjoy. We had to abandon our transport way up due to the school leaving hour and latin tempers of the parents,down the hill and into this great square
Vibrant to say the least, so we spent some time wandering,taking a drink in odd Irish and English pubs...well why not.
Then came back in the evening....great fun.

Beautiful if you ignore the touts. I loved the centre square of Cusco, so beautiful with the old colonial buildings, the distant mountains and the balconies all around.It is a but touristy - a Starbucks, a macdonalds and countless "posh" jewellery and boutique stores (not for us backpackers) and so many people constantly trying to sell massage (when I returned to Cusco after Machu Picchu I realised this might not be such a bad thing for my poor feet but didn't indulge!)Really pretty and worth a visit but be prepared to pay more for the food at the restaurants here

Vibrant but touristy. I loved the Centro for the wonderful food and fun shopping. There was a daily parade for some reason or another which also thrilled me. I would not have fallen in love with Peru over this area in particular as it contained a lot of people approaching you every five minutes or less trying to sell you something. A simple, "No thank you" was not always enough either as some would follow you and ask you why not. Over all I would and will stay here again if only as a central location to explore the ruins.
Not much to see. Everything was closed for an election. Even churches were closed on a Sunday. Outside of shopping there isn't much to do or see.
Sweet city. Very interesting architecture, after spending a week in smaller places like Aguas calientes and ollantayambo this was a welcome change.
Lucky Day!. There was a festival going on with music, parades, costumes, folklore and all. Very interesting visits to the cathedral, the convent and all around.
Colorful and joyous place. Several authentic plazas that are also touristic in a happy way: nice restaurants at fabulous prices, a good museum (MAP), and very real life in the churches and parks.

Arthictecture was familiar.. Having travelled the world, I have found that the lay out and architecture of many cities are very similar; likely because of the colonizing influences. When you understand the history of a country or region, you can generally anticipate what you will see. It is the local customs, the perspectives of the locals as to their history, and unfolding story lines that intrigue me.

Small but fun. So much to see and explore here. We did it in sections over the course of two days between group activities. Excellent place to people watch as lots of tourists and locals in their cultural attires going about their things.
Springtime Flowers in Bloom. It very Carnival and there were parades and vendors. Very vibrant and cultural. The native Andean costumes were everywhere.

Centro Historico. The city center is relatively small and has that Andean colonial charm with remnants of Inca buildings throughout. You can see it all in one day or in smaller portions in the afternoon or evenings if you plan to visit sites around Cusco during the day. The Boleto Turistico gives you a few museums options: Museo Municipal de Arte Contemporaneo, Museo Historico Regional, Museo de Arte Popular, Museo de Sito del Qoricancha, Centro Qosqo de Arte Nativo and the monster of Monimento Pachacuteq. But if such sites as Pisaq, Tipon and Ollantaytambo are not on your list the Boleto is a waste of money

Cusco ha a lot to offer. If you have the museum pass there are a lot of options to visit. The church is not on the museum pass however it is worth the charge to see it. The town is charming and there are lots of eating options.
Atmospheric, elegant, touristic. Festivals, processions, weddings, touts. Echoes of Europe and the edges of a developing country. Great food and stunning views everywhere.

Nice Little Historic Center. An earthquake in the 1950s revealed Inca foundations. So during the rebuild, the buildings were built on top of these foundations creating a nice combination of both modern Spanish and old Inca architecture throughout the center of Cusco.

Beautiful. My sister and I loved cusco. From our hotel rooftop we overlooked the city and roofs and felt as though we were in Tuscany, Italy. The narrow cobbled streets were beautiful surrounded by lovey old buildings and churches. Not too much hassle from vendors or folk trying to bring you into their eating establishment. As two women we felt very safe walking around
peru 2014. We walked through the main plaza each day. It is the way all cities should be. very clean and safe. The Inca constructions form the base of so many buildings
Breathtaking at night. The main square and the area next to it is fabulous - the narrow cobblestoned streets, alpacas at some corners, it is like a fairy tale. And even more enchanting at night!

Most beautiful mountain city. If you are in Cusco on your way to Machu Picchu, be sure to spend a few days here as the mountain city is an attraction in and of itself. We stayed 3 days here prior to our hike on the Salkantay trail to acclimatize and in retrospect, could easily have spent a week as it's a really beautiful city to just hang out. The historic center is charming and very walkable, there are lots of shops and many good restaurants (MAP cafe, Cicciolina, Incanto, Pachapapa, etc), museums (Inka museum and MAP- Pre Columbian Art museum), cute neighborhoods (San Blas), historical sights - Qoricancha, the main cathedral, various churchs, and the busy local market San Pedro selling everything from produce to wooly hats and sweaters. On Sunday mornings at Plaza Armas there's always (so we were told) a flag raising ceremony and celebration, with appearances by local dignitaries, little kids all dressed up in various native costumes, musicians and masked performers dancing along the cobblestoned streets, military bands, soldiers standing in formation and singing patriotic songs, very festive and energetic. The city overall feels very safe, even in the evenings. Just wandering around, even getting slightly lost, is immensely enjoyable because there's so much to see. Take it easy the first day or so, and keep well hydrated - usually any mild altitude discomfort will pass in a couple of days.
Worth the visit. Very nice architecture, and history, pretty gardens and a fun atmosphere. Well worth visiting while in Cusco.

Anniversry Trip to Cusco and Machu Picchu. Cusco is a very interesting city with great historic attractions. Peru has come a long way in accommodating tourists but there is still a great deal of poverty in country, expect the strong smell of diesel as you walk along the streets of Cusco
Beautiful Inca trail... I liked it all, except the short opening hours of the Cathedral....The Plaza de Armas is really nice as all the people of Cusco...
feels like home. I grew up in a medieval european town and Cusco feels somehow like home. Wonderful experience fro just walking the streets and looking at the architecture.

Walking through history. We had a walking tour of the old city around the central square. Great tour, learned much about the history of the Incas, the Spanish conquest, the role of the church, and saw the only depiction of The Last Supper, with a guinea pig as a delicacy on the table

A strollers paradise. Cusco is a destination in and of itself...the historic center is made for leisurely walking and admiring the architecture as well as getting a sense of place...while there, do not, absolutely do not, miss the Central Market.....

So Much Fun. This town square is so much fun. Countless restaurants and plenty of locals selling there goods. At times they can push too much but whatever, that's normal I guess. Great pubs too, with lots of travelers looking to meet and have fun. Can't wait to return although I doubt I will.

Central Historic District (Centro Historico de Cusco). At what point does one designate something as historical? In the case of Cusco, is that break between the Incan Empire and the Spanish conquest or should some specified date be determined? The Spanish influence was strong and structures constructed in the 20th century look much like those from the 16th century. Once the Spanish took over, it seems as if change has been slowly adapted. Of course it may have been slow in the Incan times, but so much has been lost. I mention this, as it was difficult to determine just when you enter or exit the historical district of Cusco. So much looks the same of at least very similar is styles. Cobblestone streets are still being constructed in many parts of the world--they work and last a very long time.The narrow gate our bus drove through was an obvious feature, but our guide helped. You can only see so much from a bus… Many of the major attractions in Cusco are within the historic district and reviewed accordingly.

Ancient meets modern .... Be ready for a lot of up hill walking in this most beautiful of cities, as it was originally founded in a valley but has since expanded up the surrounding mountain side. It is a city rich in history, architecture and culture and definitely NOT to be missed while in Peru.

In love with Cusco. There is magic arriving to this city high in the sky (3,400 mts above sea level), a valley surrounded by mountains (Andes). Blue skies, incredible views and majestic constructions. Great restaurants, hotels and boutiques.

Centro historico de Lima. As it is one of only really beautiful parts of Lima, I recommend that you go there. Check out the main plazas, the churches, the market and the barrio chino. If you have the Lonely Planet I recommend the suggested walking tour. San Francisco and Santo Domingo were beautiful monasteries. Try and do what all you want in the center in one trip, as getting around with public transportation is quite a long undertaking.
Live history and the encounter of two cultures. Loved everything. It is a place to visit and learn about one if the greatest civilizations in human history.

beautiful city Cusco!. I didn't like the altitude, Cusco is very nice and inexpensive, love that. People are nice and friendly, I bought from shopps but found that the ladies selling their handmade goods were lot less expensive then all other places.
Cute!. You can walk a lot and see many stores, museums, coffee places, churchs and inca ruins! Great place!

BEAUTIFUL CENTRAL DISTRICT. The main plaza is beautiful during the day with the blue skies and mountains as backdrop, during night with the churches lit up. It was a nice place to just sit and watch people in the main plaza. There are plenty of good restaurants surrounding the plaza as well as places to get inexpensive massages (greatly needed after two days at Machu Pichhu).

Cultural Knowledge and Amazing Architecture. The architecture of the buildings, house and street on Cusco- Historical Center- are fabulous, you can appreciate the ancient architecture and the whole center is in my opinion a work of art.

SO COOL. Such an amaze city and historical central is beautiful. Feels like a crazy European city up in the mountains. For sure stay here for at least three days and eat all the guinea pigs in sight!!!!! Just kidding the guinea pig edibles look like fried rats on a stick. I live in NY so if I want to try that I can wander down to the subway with a deep fryer.But anywho, cusco is a must see and you won't be able to miss the historical central because it's right there and if you wander around you will end up there

Marvelous!!!. I guess. If we find ourselves in Cusco. It is because we have a sense of wonder and a thirst for knowledge!!! I suggest that you at least pick a a travel book about Peru and at least prepare yourself for what you will be learning! Had an awesome guide!!! Just ingest the wonder and enjoy the people!!

Lovely Old Buildings, Too Much Tourist Hype. I am not sure that Cusco would be such a draw if it were not a takeoff point for Macchu Picchu. It is a lovely colonial city, much like several others, with impressive stone work in its buildings and walls. We were just there in August, which is high season for tourism, but even so, it was unpleasant to have menus pushed in our faces on the streets, plus so many hawkers of tours, souvenirs, etc. It would be interesting to visit in low season and, hopefully, see a difference.

Great for dinner/ shopping. This area was near our hostel and was the nightly entertainment for us. There was plenty of shopping, restaurants, and things to see such as historic churches and cobblestone streets. Make sure you're staying near this site or you'll be in the wrong spot for sure!
Pretty city. Cusco is a stopping point for many who are visiting Machu Picchu and it is a beautiful city. The cathedrals are impressive as is the history of this region.

a little hidden gem. This museum is included in a tourist ticket that covers over 10 different places in and around Cusco. It takes less than an hour to see round the place but some interesting pieces and stories in the building.
Wonderful, as you wanted it to be. Very beautiful mix between the Incas wall and the Conquistadores constructions. Magic at night.You must enter the place by all the streets.
This is where it all happens.. Dancing in the street, pubs off, nice cathedral...plenty of very nice cafes and restaurants in the cobble lanes that run off the square.

Perfect if it was flat. My favourite town in Peru. More manageable in size than Arequipa or Lima but with masses to see, not only in Cusco itself but in the surrounding area. I suggest that you start with a free tour of the town which leaves the main square at around 11:00am. These are available in both English and Castellano. The guides are very knowledgeable and provide you with an overview of the town, that you can then explore in more depth. Cusco is a rich mixture of the traditional and the modern. Free wifi is widely available, as are cash points and credit cards are accepted in most places. Though I did not suffer from altitude sickness as such, I certainly felt the effects. Climbing countless steps every night was a killer. Next time I go, I will get accommodation nearer the square.

Lovely centre. A lovely small town. The central square is a pleasant place to sit and people watch. It is surrounded by lovely buildings. There are plenty of restaurants including McDonalds, KFC and Starbucks.There are the normal people and children trying to sell you things but they only ask once and go away if you say no. The side streets are also worth exploring.

Amazing historical center at 3400 Meters.. Of all the places I visited in Peru, one of the most amazing was Cusco and it`s historical center. I really loved this place and will definitely come back to Cusco and it`s amazing old town!
Perspective of history. Interesting to see and hear with a guide what transpired since Spainards slaughtered the IncasWortha visit if one is in the area
cultural delight.. Cusco has a lot of museums, art, culture, as well as good restaurants, shopping, and general people watching.
Historic center. From here you and see and walk to most of the historic sights of cusco as well the plaza is a good meeting point if you are traveling in a group.

nice ,naif. you can take some local boys that guiedes you to city center, but if you can't find no problem it is a small city center.you must see inca museum,cathedral of cusco;it' free early in the morning;till 7 am
such a great place. you must go to cusco its so charming with great places to eat and see. check out the old city and the museums too the people are just great!
Love the quaint area. Definitely will return. Great food, bars, massage options and touristy trinket shopping. Reminds me of a little ski village but without the terrible high prices.

Ancient Inca walls everywhere! This is a living museum!. I love The historic Center of Cusco for many reasons...the smells, the abundance of Inca walls around ever corner and the immense history. Wind your way around the historical center by climbing high into the hills and then back down into the hubbub of the squares. There is often celebration in the largest, Plaza des Armas. Bakeries, crafts, and colonial stuctures will cause you to pause every step of the way. When you are not studying history in the center, there are many treks, tours, and ruins to experience. I even joined the South American Explorers club to socialize and participate in the many educational events they offer. I have stayed in four hotels so far, all within the Puma of the historic center. I start Spanish classes next week because I plan to stay for awhile. Loving it!

Lovely cultural town . Small town filled with restaurants, historic sites and alpaca clothing stores. Everything is within walking distance. Cusco is beautiful and safe day & night. It gets very hot & sunny during the afternoon and very cold in the evening. The town area is kept clean and has been somewhat westernized as you will realise how and where the local people really live driving in and out of the area. There are quite a few dogs roaming the streets which apparently aren't strays- they go home to their owners at night and stay out of your way during the day. Local cuisine includes alpaca and guinea pig which we tried once. 90% of the market shops sell the same thing so you can bargain - almost everyone walks away with an alpaca beanie and jumper. You will learn to say no gracias (no thank you in Spanish) very quickly as locals will constantly approach you selling art, massages, souvenirs and Machu Picchu tours. The people are very friendly and the town is filled with tourists. Just watch while crossing the roads as the local driving does get quite frantic!

Everything Walking Distance Around Plaza. Within walking distance around Plaza De Armas, which is called the historic center, are lots of hotels, inns, restaurants and many shops. Some of the best food is within a block or two from the main plaza. Use the plaza to rest and get your bearings on your location. Seems like there is a parade each day in the area. Most of the higher priced stores are on the boarders of the plaza, walk a few blocks away and find same items for a better price and opportunity to haggle.(To Travel Is To Live)
Beautiful City. So much to see and all close together. The open top bus was worth doing to get an overall feel of the place.

Beautiful. Had a great time, gorgeous place, so much to learn and see. Just walking around the plaza de armas was a pleasure . Uncle restaurants great food, tried grilled alpaca for 1st time and it was delicious , Cuzco is a magical mystic place

What's authentic is wonderful! But beware abundant fakery.... Let me start out by saying that Cusco is fantastic, beautiful, amazing, wonderful, and a VERY worthwhile place to visit. LOVED IT. That fact remains! However, there's a lot of fakery and deception around town surrounding the indigenous culture (or what's left of it), and I sometimes found it disheartening.Some examples:- Many of the women (and men!) in the handicrafts markets PRETEND to be working on creating the "handmade items" right before your very eyes. Closer observation will reveal that it's a sad little pantomime, and that these vendors are not the artisans. Women will sit there stitching a very, very crude (and unnecessary) yarn border around a much more impressive woven piece that they acquired from elsewhere. Or, a woman who knows a little bit of basic knitting might be sitting there knitting on a very small, monochromatic project that looks NOTHING like the much fancier goods she is selling. Worse, a vendor will sit there and simply "play" with an item in such a way to make it seem that they are making it on the spot. I once saw a woman sitting with one of the ubiquitous knitted hats, teasing the pompom incessantly with a crocheting hook, as if she was "making" that hat. I also saw a man pounding senselessly and purposelessly on a piece of leather with a hammer as he sold tooled leather goods that he clearly did not make himself (I'm a leatherworker too, and quickly noticed this deception). Vendors will very crudely carve your name into the bottom of any artwork that is carved, at a skill level much, much lower than what was used to make the piece itself. Jewelry vendors will sit there for hours and poke their pieces around with little tools as if they actually made the pieces. Most of the time, this is all a theatrical attempt to make you think you are buying from an artisan, when you're not.- Another example of Cusco fakery: when a talented ensemble of Peruvian musicians wanders into your restaurant to play a few tunes, they will often attempt to sell you a CD as well. Do not assume that this is a CD of the wonderful ensemble you just enjoyed: in many cases, it's not, even if they tell you it is. I was very disappointed to buy 3 CD's from various different performing ensembles that were very good live, yet the CD's sounded NOTHING like the music I'd actually heard performed! In fact I later saw many of the same CD's for sale in the marketplace, causing me to doubt whether the CDs had any connection to the ensembles I had heard.- Women in indigenous dress carrying a cute little lamb, or walking a llama. You'll learn quickly that these are not surviving representatives of some local, colorful culture, but women in costume who are almost always looking for tips in exchange for taking their picture. Around Cusco, it's HIGHLY unusual to see a woman wearing colorful, native dress unless she is working for tips from tourists. Want to take their picture? Fine -- just be sure to tip them, and be aware that it's highly likely the only reason they're dressed that way in the first place is to get your tips.- "Handmade objects". A large majority of the "handmade" items for sale, particularly textiles, are actually machine woven (or knitted). Don't assume it's "handmade" just because the vendor tells you it is. Look around, shop around. A great majority of the items for sale in Cusco are mass produced and you'll find the same "handmade" item at a hundred other stands.- "Baby Alpaca." Yes, there is real baby alpaca wool all over the Cusco markets, and yes, it's luxurious, but not everything marketed as "baby alpaca" wool actually is. Vendors know that the "baby alpaca" designation is attractive to buyers, but I've seen anything from regular sheep's wool to llama to even SYNTHETIC fibers on the market being touted as "baby alpaca." Learn to tell the difference before buying.But all of this deception and fakery shouldn't dissuade you from going. Like I said at the beginning of this review: Cusco is fantastic, beautiful, amazing, wonderful, and a VERY worthwhile place to visit! However, oftentimes it can be a challenge to figure out what is real, and what is "for show"...

So much history in one place. Amazing city for its cultural and historic history - so much to see in such a centralised area - obviously a very religious history when you see the number of cathedrals and churches.

Sightseeing Cusco City. We start from the Plaza de Armas led by a guide, we visit the highlights in and around Cusco.At the square we see Cathedral of Santo Domingo and Church of the Society of Jesus. Then we continue along other churches and squares, along Arco Santa Clara, nice streets with Spanish balconies. Further we go out of the city to the nearby ruins of Sacsayhuaman and statue Cristo Blanco.This Sightseeing gives you a good impression to see the city continue .

Beautiful city. We passed through cusco twice on our G adventure holiday. This is a beautiful city and well worth exploring. We took a trolley tour to help with orientation and then wandered around the sites. You need a good day at least to appreciate this city.
Mystic city. Cusco was for sure one of our Highlights, our guide Marco was outstanding and he knew everything about the Inca Culture, we loved it.

great spot to walk around and feel the local culture. small ancient streets, with many spanish buildings (mostly churchs) with breathtaking interiors. Safe, pretty cool and with good restaurant options around... we really had a nice time there...
Beautiful place to see. Great place to see and eat. Go to restaurant jacks first day rest attitude is hard. But just beautiful.

Cusco neat little town. Square-park clean, visit the Cathedral worthwhile. People helpful- Pub'sa couple there -Restaurants plenty the one I went to the culturel show fantastic. Found a nightclub there spent my birthday there. Realy enjoyed my stay at Cusco.

Cusco and the Sacred Valley. The historic center is nice and compact and can be easily visited in a day or long afternoon. The three colonial squares line up with beautiful churches on every corner. We were lucky and got to see processions for a local holiday.

Delightful 4 days and Nights. We spent 4 days and nights visiting churches, Inca ruins, museums, beautiful vistas, quaint buildings, wonderful people and delicious reasonably priced food, all in Cusco. We walked everywhere and really enjoyed exploring this culturally rich city.

Charming city. Every corner was picture perfect the balconies were very artistic, and even cheap restaurants were better than any other place in Peru. Drink a lot of coca tea it will really help you with the height issues. Try to walk through the narrow streets instead of main ones is way more charming

Fantastic, bustling historic town center!. While making your voyage to Machu Picchu, you should definitely spend a couple days in the Cusco area. While I personally would not want to stay in a hotel right in the middle of all the action, noise, parties.... I would highly recommend spending some time in the area of town soaking in all the sights and sounds of this wonderful town center. A glorious fountain, tourists, street performers, locals, musicians....it's got it all. Surrounded by massive Cathedrals, cafés and shoppes, narrow alleyways, this area gives the quintessential vibe of an international city. You could grab a coffee and just sit and watch people and snap photographs for hours. There was some sort of municipal band playing that night along with a juggler, young lovers, families and young tourists ready for a good time. I really did enjoy this experience. It's a must see part of town if you are in Cusco before/after heading to Machu Picchu.
So many colors. Beautiful square. I was here during festival time and everyday there was dancing or parades or something going on. It was fabulous! Amazing history and culture in this city.
Really cool vibe. Lots of stuff to look at, nice feel to the place, heaps of shops and restaurants, want more time to wander around!!

Very interesting historical city. Lots of things to see, nice atmosphere especially if you arrive during one of the religious holidays. Beautiful Plaza de Armas, with the cathedral in its center. Temple of the Sun nearby. Nice little streets climbing up and down through the city.

A dream come true- Un sueno hecho realidad. La bella cultura y su impressionante historia. La amabilidad de su gente. The beautiful culture and the impressive history. The people's hospitality and their humble demeanor.

Really Nice. When you think of the history that occurred here - it is indeed very impressive. The city offers a free tour guide for groups and it is really worth it to discover. We were there in June which is a month of celebration for the city of Cusco. Lots happening (dancing, music etc...)

Historic Picturesque City Center. Great city center with many sites, places of interest, and restaurants. Started my daily city explorations from here and wandered off in a different direction each day. Last couple weeks of June the city center is none stop festivals. The restaurants on the square are predominantly geared to tourists, but still good food. Shops provide many travel items, from souvenirs to luggage, cameras, and tours. The churches on the square are worth seeing with or without the tours. Don't be afraid to buy the multi-site entrance tickets. Unfortunately the two main church groups are on separate tickets.

Stroll Around. The Cusco Historic Center is relatively small and easy to stroll. Stop by the Cathedral, shops and restaurants, and maybe even walk up to the Hotel Monestario to see the artwork on the second level. The altitude may force you to slow down a bit, so sit in the plaza and do some excellent people watching.
Cusco magnificent. Beautiful Inca city. A lot of activities, great shopping, excellent food everywhere. Also safe city to stay a lot of History.Recommended 100 %

Love the city. Cuzco is a beautiful city that I love. It more fun than going to Machu Picchu and that is great also. I have been here several times and I love to explore the city (slowly the altitude is rough). This is a place that has surprises around every corner. the history and beauty of Cuzco is off the charts. I most highly recommend that you explore and enjoy Cuzco.

Beautiful historical centre. Shame about the Mcdonalds and KFC that have snuck their way in!!! Lots of photo opportunities here and can get some good shopping done too (north face and Columbia for hiking)

Everything you imagined and more!. Cusco truly is a magical place and whilst there are many tourists here it's easy to get one or two streets off the beaten track and see the place as it once was. Even the busiest parts of the town are beautiful - incredible buildings perfectly maintained....and llamas!

Cusco City Tour with Llamapath. We took the half-day Cusco City tour offered by Llamapath. They focused on the attractions beyond walking distance from the city center, and in the immediate countryside (as described on their website). We got a capable driver, and a guide who provided knowledgeable and interesting descriptions of all of the sights, plus some commentary on other related cultural topics.

Cusco square a great place to visit. Having read all the does and don't I was expecting to be in a old cowboy town, but apart from I THINK someone tried to pull my Camara from my pocket, I felt real safe, the locals are very nice when I visited they had festivals every night for the week so that real made it special, the weather was nice, and warm even at night, felt safe, apart from the altitude which I struggled with and had to take a puff oxygen one morning but like everyone says just take your time it's not a race,

Wonderful plaza de Armas. The centre of Cuzco is architecturally magnificent. Lots of touristy and rather expensive restaurants, I'm afraid McD's is the best VFM. Don't like not being able to buy a ticket for individual museums: you have to buy a 130 soles 10-day ticket for all of them, and another ticket for religious places such as the cathedral.

One of the nicest cities I have been in S America. Very nice city. Comparable and even better than Oaxaca in Mexico, or Antigua in Guatemala. Touristy obviously but not to bad. Beautiful plaza, nice streets, easy to walk through. Beautiful old buildings and local markets everywhere. Nice people. Could have stayed here much longer than just a day or two.

Everything you could need at hand. This is one of the most (if not the most) beautiful plazas in Peru. Not only that, but around the historic center you will find everything you may need. If you want a burger you have Papachos or Bembos, if you want veggies you can find a lot of joints around the center, if you want a fancy dinner or if you wish an economic “menu”, there are a lot of different places to choose from. Expensive clothing, cheap clothing, original Peruvian clothing, sports clothing any clothing!Museums, churches, discos and bars, your choice, everything is a couple of minutes by foot.I've been here 4 times and every time I find more and more reasons to stay

Beautiful, but more of a backpacker culture than Peruvian culture. Yes, the city center is beautiful and quaint. It's also reminded me of Disneyland: expensive with a definite tourist culture all its own. Example: there are women and children all over town dressed in traditional Quechua clothing, leading llamas or holding lambs. When you get close you can hear them repeating the words, "Una foto por dos soles"=a photo for 2 soles. It reminded me of having my foto taken with Cinderella at Disneyland. We found ourselves wondering where the real Perú was underneath Euro-American-Japanese backpacker populace. What follows is what my husband and I recommend if you are interested in more than just the tourist culture that pervades. 1. Don't stay in the historic center of Cusco. By all means you should visit it and see the historic sites. You can easily take a cab and spend a couple of days exploring the beautiful architecture. The historic center is hugely expensive and even catching a cab from the center is twice as expensive as catching a cab anywhere else in Cusco. I met very few Peruvians while staying there and the ones I did meet were largely interested in selling me a tourist related service or item. When we went out of the city into the suburbs we saw and met wonderful Peruvian families and got to see where they lived, worked, shopped, etc. 2. Remember that the most authentic places to eat are the places that have never even heard of TripAdvisor so they won't be on here. After a couple of days of only getting trendy recommendations from other backpackers, we finally asked a local where she eats and she recommended a small kitchen called Rancón del Rey (maybe Rincón spelled incorrectly?). We ate the plato del día (daily special) for 6 soles and it was wonderful Peruvian food. We were the only Americans in the restaurant. 3. Ask locals where they purchase their food and visit those markets instead of the touristy San Pedro market. The market in San Sebastian is a large market in a suburb area of Cusco and there were no tourists there. They had great local food and for a fraction of the cost of San Pedro market. Also be sure to visit the Chinchero artisan market on Sunday. It's very small, but we were also the only tourists there (and in high season!)4. The cathedral in city center square is beautiful, but I was amazed to see the price to get in. We went very early in the morning one day and discovered that it is free to get in before 8am. We also discovered that if you attend mass, you (obviously) get in for free, plus you get to participate in a great cultural experience.

A leisure walk. We had a leisure walk through Cusco's historic district upon our arrival from Lima before heading out to our hotel in the Sacred Valley. Cusco is often hub for travelers between Lima and Machu Picchu for agency planned tours. Try and schedule some time to explore this district - up and close. There is truth that visitors who are not accustom to the elevation (3,399 m / 11,152 ft) should not overexert themselves and take the time to acclimate. The walk through the historic district climbs up and down hills, but overall provides enough resting areas where someone can sit/stand and enjoy the local sounds, sites, and color. Locals may be walking about with their llama - be prepared to pay a couple Soles, but the cost is very worthwhile for the memory.

I wonder what the Incas would think of Starbucks?. Cusco is a beautiful city and the starting point to visit Machu Pichu and other places in the sacred valley. For this reason it is a tourist hot spot.The architecture has a strong influence from the Spanish conquistadores, and you can see how they destroyed and built on top of some amazing Inca buildings. This is something that we can learn from in many places, what a pity it is not to maintain historic cultures and buildings. What is even worse is seeing fast food restaurants nestled within the old buildings, however for many people this can give a comforting taste of home. However if you are like me and want to try local delicacies I highly recommend Ceviche and Alpaca meat - the ceviche is delicious and very healthy. As it is raw fish make sure you pay a bit more from a restaurant that looks the part or you could pay dear in the middle of the night :-( The city is pretty clean and felt safe, obviously you need to be street smart and avoid walking around at night in smaller, less busy areas - but hey thats my advise for many large cities in the world. The hostels are a bit more expensive than in other areas of Peru, but most are very clean. I stayed in Pisko and Soul in San Blas which was a great area for bars, restaurants etc. To get to Cusco I highly recommend the Cruz del Sur bus - this is by far the best bus company I travelled with in south america, on one journey I even played bingo being hosted by a very funny cross dressing attendant whilst eating jelly - an experience to remember!This is a great place to acclimatise before trekking and relax afterwards. I stopped drinking before my trek to ensure I was well hydrated before the trek. Obviously water being key to move oxygen round the body. So it was nice to sink an ice cold beer when we got back .... and a sneaky coffee too!Cusco is well worth the visit and is a great place to meet other travellers, party, relax and see the traces of Inca culture!

Fun, bustling historic centre . We spent a few days prepping before and recovering after from our trek in Cusco, and could have spent far longer. The city has tons to offer and many hidden corners to explore - from Incan ruins to lively markets to relaxing massages (perfect for post-trek recovery). We were around during some of the festivities in June, and it was incredible to see the city party!

Thoroughly enjoyed wandering around. Cusco is so compact and full of history and museums that we thoroughly enjoyed and recommend wandering around from place to place, visiting the museums and taking in the whole experience of this wonderful city.
Great Place!!!. This place is really amazing to spend time with your couple or by yourself, meet people from different countries

festival of the Sun. Our trip coincided with this festival. The plaza's were crowded with people all in traditional costumes from various areas. The dancing, music and activity went on for several days culminating with the Festival of the Sun celebrations. Amazing!
Quaint and beautiful. This historic center is very well kept and very safe. It has a lot to offer. We wish we could have stayed longer.

Escape to Cusco!. The people in Cusco were celebrating the festival of Inti Raymi so the city was packed and there were lovely parades, etc. The people of Cusco are very friendly. Watch out for tour agencies!
We were disappointed in ours.

Cusco. Beautiful city. Lots of alleys and steps. We stayed here in between Machu Pichu, Peruvian Amazon Puerto Maldonado, and lake Titicaca. Our hotel was just off the central square. We found a lovely blue balcony bar that overlooked the square. It became our regular stopping spot each afternoon to have a drink and people watch. A lovely lively city. Lots to see and do. We walked everywhere and loved the old parts. The food was great. Roasted guinea pig an interesting long debated high light. Lol. Shopping shopping shopping. Just say no. Not maybe or tomorrow. They will remember you. Lol. All in a days fun.
Wonderful old world feel. During the month of June, the city is full of festivals and the major square is always filled with dancers and parades. Very festive time to visit.

The Emperor's Groove. I loved everything about Cuzco! A few nights before heading off to the heights of Machu Pichu prepared my body for the oxygen deprived thin air of the mountain heights. As if the incredible plane maneuvers negotiating the sharp tips of the Cuzco giants as it arrived for landing, the village it self was a trip back in time. The fact that the village was full of tourists from all life on earth did nothing to damper the beauty nor authenticity of the surroundings. The best time was spent sitting on a cafe balcony overlooking the town square and people watching. The various religious and other parades, the sun rise and sunset over the mountain tops and the square and village lights as darkness set. I hope to return for a longer stay next time!
Beautiful, charming city. This was one of our favourite spots in Peru. Felicious food, great shopping, fascinating historical sites, very safe. Wish we could have stayed longer.
Great Cuzco. Loved Cuzco very interesting history amazing Cathedral.Didn't liked being offered a massage all the time!
great place to stroll around. we had 2 days in city centre,plenty of interesting places to visit and also just an interesting place to walk around

Cusco...Top of the world!. Cusco is a stopping point for machu pichu. this is a good stop to become acclimated to the altitude change in the Andies, otherwise you may get altitude sickness. It a cool town to hang out in for a day or two before and after Machu Pichu. there is a lot of historical building that are great for site seeing. There is a big statue of Jesus overlooking the city, much like brazil, just not as big. Amazing squares surrounded by old churches and fun store. i really enjoyed this place.
Cute, fun. Like: safe feeling, great atmosphere. Lots of food and shopping choices, have a large amount of food choices. Dislike: none

Loved this city!. Clear a week of your schedule for day trips from this Peruvian Gem! the city boasts amazing restauraunts and history and even your three star hotel is likely to be built upon Incan walls carved to perfection!

Marvellous. Cusco really is one the most beautiful cities in the world. We were expecting it to be a kind of Gringolandia, with oppressing vendedores everywhere, scams masters and pickpockets, but you only find them on the Plaza de Armas, and still, it's really not hell. We felt safe everywhere we went (it is not the case in all Peruvian cities), and the city is just so beautiful. We spent one week there, and we could not see everything we wanted to (including the Sacred Valley sites)

Traditional City***:). Cusco city was the famous city that we visited in our honeymon vacation I love Cusco, people were very friendly the accomodations were excellent Cusco had a lot of history.Thanks Cusco Arends Tash.
Fantastic old buildings and quaint shops. Narrow historic streets with lots of Hostels, B&B's & restaurants. Nice time just wondering around and enjoying the architecture.
Charming, exotic, great fun!. The narrow streets are picturesque and it is interesting to see the locals ho about their everyday lives. Very historical!

Touristy but worth the trip. Great museums, spendid walks, beautiful monuments, great markets. Cusco has a lot to offer on foot. Very easy walks in town and lots of good places to stop for a drink. One can even find some spots vith very few or no tourists at all.
Incas' capital. A great city to walk around. the people are very nice. A lot of history to see and discover at a high altitude.

Beautiful city centre. This is a must when visiting Cusco, actually you can't really not go here ;) have a seat and soak it all in. However you'll be hassled by the locals selling their crafts. Just say no gracias
Inca launch pad. Cusco is a wonderful place to begin explorian Andean countryside, culture and cuisine! The MAP Museum was wonderful.
Cusco Historic Centre. Easy to walk around, lots to see & learn about the capital for the Incas; Cusco busy with celebrations, so there is fireworks on a regular basic

Beautiful heritage listed city. The central part of Cusco is a highlight to any trip to Peru. It truly deserves its world heritage status. Not many cities in the world can claim to be built so seamlessly on top of a former civilisation. Inca stonework can be seen in countless side streets. It survives earthquakes a lot better than modern structures. Focal point is the plaza de armas, surrounded by a beautiful ensemble of colonial churches and exclusive shops and restaurants. Minimal advertising and no gaudy colours here. You'd hardly notice the MacDonalds tucked away in the corner.

A combination of the very old, merely old and modern. At first glance, the centre of Cusco looks a little ramshackle - but then much of the centre is a UNESCO world heritage site and presumably can't be renovated. So if you can ignore the bustling traffic, it doesn't take too much of a leap to imagine you're seeing the place much as it was when the conquistadores were in charge. What kept surprising me, initially, was how many Incan buildings still remain - or at least, the first couple of meters of their exterior walls, subsequently built on and extended by the Spanish. But then, it's easy to think of the Inca empire as ancient, while really it's just old, ending a mere 500 years ago. If this seems like a long time, consider that the Incans were contemporaneous with King Henry VIII in England and only just pre-dated Shakespeare. So on second thoughts, it shouldn't be surprising that the original Cusco was a sizeable and substantial settlement, constructed of those wonderful Incan stone buildings, and that many of these buildings survive, albeit in modified form. Today the tourist centre of Cusco is the Plaza de Armas, a large square next to the cathedral, and almost everything of interest to the casual tourist within the city itself is located within no more than 10 minutes walk of this spot. However there is much more to the historic centre than just the Plaza. Narrow streets in all directions lead past the remains of Incan / colonial dwellings, and you'll find many beautiful little courtyards hiding, Spanish-style, behind unobtrusive doorways. From nearby Sacsayhuaman, looking down onto the town from the top of a hill, the courtyard and square nature of the old town is clearly visible, and the orange / red tiling on the roofs gives almost a Roman impression. Of course, Cusco's historic centre isn't really a single attraction - almost everything worth seeing here will have its own separate Tripadvisor entry, and you would be well-advised to seek these out too. There's a surprising amount to see and do packed into a small space, particularly if your interest encompasses history, religion, museums, gastronomy, and shopping. With regards to the latter, most of the old buildings in the centre, at least at ground level, have now been converted into shops. Kuna and Sol Alpaca are probably the two most reputable places for good quality alpaca clothing, with a number of outlets on or near the Plaza de Armas. Avoid buying from the sellers wandering the Plaza itself unless you have a particular desire to wear acrylic. Allow at least 4 days to see everything including the nearby ruins of the temple complex at Sacsayhuaman, which you will need transport (or an organised tour) to get to. Some attractions require you to buy the all-in-one Cusco tourist ticket, while for others you can simply pay on the door. If you need local help organising tours or guides I highly recommend Amazonas Explorer.

People Watching. Really quite a lovely square. Explore the range of shops and have a bite to eat or an ice cream. Sit for while on a bench and people watch. The light in the late afternoon can bathe the square in a golden light and we were able to capture some beautiful shots.
Plaza de Armas. Pretty park but be ready to be inundated with people of all ages selling trinkets and souvenirs. A simple "No, gracias" and they usually leave you alone.
The Place to be in.. Cusco is itself a beautiful city with a pleasant weather and the Historic Centre is the place to be in.A day well spent in this Boutique City.

cozy. The cuzco historic center is a place to remind us of those past times. Such an amazing place combining inca history and buildings and this modern life. You can find amazing places just walking through the streets... restaurants, museums, ancient inca sites! You'd be amazed!!!
Quaint area to walk around. I enjoyed casually walking around this square. There are a large variety of shops and restaurants. The architecture is interesting to look at.

Nice Spanish colonial square. It is a very nice example of what the Spanish colonial powers built. Contemporary shops range in content and cost. Since we're not into shopping everywhere we go, we have no further comment about that.

Taxi tour driver the best. Victor our private tour guide arrived on time, took us to all the ruins, and was full of information. In a country where integrity can be questionable, Victor was a pillar for us. It was good to have him looking out us as he showed us his country and customs. We cannot express or appreciation enough for Victor.....victortour2012@gmail.com.Thank you Victor.

Pretty square. This is one of the prettier squares in Peru and safe. Cuzco is an easy city to walk but the guided tours are inexpensive and well worth the money. The restaurants and stores around the square are touristy. If you want a more authentic experience then go off the path a bit.
nice place. full of foreing people, quiet a nice place you can find some good restaurant around the main square.

Chill out before Machu Picchu!. Chances are you flew into Cusco because you'll go to Machu Picchu, right? Fine, but before you do it is advised that you chill out in the city to allow adjustment to its high altitude. And what better way to do this than hang out in the plaza that's surrounded by restos, stores, churches and other businesses that cater to tourists.

Impressive city. Very nice city and surroundings, spectacular views from all different point and locations. Plenty of restaurants, museums, cathedrals, churches, hotels, etc. You can not miss this city.

Definitely worth the time. Easy and safe to walk around and discover all the historic places on offer. The local market is also a fascinating place to visit. We found a little coffee shop upstairs on the square and watched the activities from their balcony.
Spend a Few Hours Here. The history of Cuzco and the Inca is all right there. Easy walk everywhere. And when you feet are tired, several great places to grab a Coke!!

This is where most of the action is in Cusco. The cathedrals and shopping are all located in this area. Good place to spend a day. Make sure you go to the market - lots of cheap things to buy and check out the farmers market - especially the butcher area - you see how they use every piece of the animal. Their food "court" looks wonderful - but you don't want to eat there unless you are a native. They also have an area for shamans and tarot card readers, etc. Never seen so many smoothie vendors in one place.

Nice atmosphere strolling around. Lots of nice photo opportunities in historic centre. We chose to eat a little away from main square at Chez Maggy restaurant. The San Pedro market is worth a visit....quite an experience. Nice atmosphere in this area.
The light and energy in Cusco are very special!. The light and energy in Cusco are very special! A must stop is the Museo de la Coca--very enlightening!
Cuzco. Not what I expected - not quaint, charming or fun - I would recommend staying in Ollantaytambo....which is quaint and most importantly is at a considerably lower altitude.

The heart and pulse of the city.. If you are going to Cusco be sure to visit the central plaza and cathedral and spend some time exploring the side streets and smaller plazas. There are excellent museums, coffee shops, restaurants and the shopping is great, even if a bit expensive by local standards. There our outfitters in the side streets and backpacker hotels abound. It is an easy walk from here up to Sacsayhuaman on the hills overlooking the plaza. If you are looking to exchange money this may not be the best place as rates can be higher than outlying areas. Check for local festivals and celebrations in this area as they are a site to see. The costuming and dancing and music are an added treat if you timing is good.
Interesting. Self tour and we enjoyed - be bought a table runner made in original had made and hand died yarns. Close to the central square.

Attacked by 3 men by knifepoint. We have spent 2 days in Cusco to get acclimatized for an 8 day trek to Machu Pichu. The information we had been given was where to go, not where not to go. On the way to hotel from airport, our driver told us of a nice view overlooking the City. Day 2 we decided to hike up. On the descent we were attaced by 3 men one with a knife... do you know what an experience it is to be 2 hours from the City and having someone holding you down, with two people on your husband??? The worst thing was, after we gave themeverything we had with us, the knife man kept trying to stab my husband..... luckily he was a foot taller and got the other guy by the wrist, so damage was minimun, one puncture wound on knee, scratches and bruises. We were going to cancel trek, but have decided as it is an organised tour, we will go.The police and our tour operators have taken this very seriously, and out tour operator has promised to change info package.So,for people travelling to Cusco, Peru, organise a taxi with your hotel or tour operator ( which we did) and be very careful where you go. Eventhe landmarks of this City are not worth the experience we had today.Ps.we cannot post pictures as our cameras and mobile phones have been stolen.

Lovely sights, great views, pestering hustlers. Spend hours walking around the historic center. The hybrid colonial/Inca sights are spectacular. The trinket, art and photo hawkers are a constant annoyance. Oddly, there are very few sidewalk/patio cafes.

Stroll in Colonial time. For all the horrors that the Conquistadors did in Peru, they also left beautiful architectural marks with plentiful of churches, convents and plazas. Don't try to visit all the churches … overdose guaranteed otherwise, especially if you travel with kids or teens!

Stroll in Colonial time. For all the horrors that the Conquistadors did in Peru, they also left beautiful architectural marks with plentiful of churches, convents and plazas. Don't try to visit all the churches … overdose guaranteed otherwise, especially if you travel with kids or teens!
Cusco is magic!. spending some days in cusco is amazing. one of my favourite places - I will definitely come back with my family

An excellent walking experience!. I enjoyed the many colonial old churches, the San Pedro Market, the Hand crafts market, all museums, very specially the Inca Museum. Just walking and observing regular people walking on the streets is an unforgettable experience. Do not forget to take pictures of the natives in traditional customes holding baby llamas! ...Peruvian natives selling on the streets do not put pressure on tourists to buy! I really like that.

Cusco - Peru. I came to Cusco after a few days in Peru's capital Lima, the flight was fine, and one of the good things flying during the day is that you can admire the landscapes and mountains of one of the most beautiful countries in the world.The landing manouvering is really nice, and gives you a nice view from the city, the airplane must manouver in low altitude to land in Cusco's airport, nothing to scare about, but if you can look through the window, you are going to have and amazing view from the city and it's sorroundings.As Cusco is located about 3,400 m above the sea level, you must be aware of the problems you may face due to it, the peruviand calls it Soroche, so the recommendations you must follow as soon as you get to cusco is to drink some coca tea and go to bed and rest for about 2 or 3 hours, this is necessary for you to acclimatize with the altitude. As soon as I got to Cusco, I was feeling fine, went to my hotel, drunk some coca tea and then, after going a few steps on the stairs I felt the altitude action on my body, I've lost mey breath and got tired really fast, so I went to my bed as soon as I could to rest.One problem, my hotel was located at the top of a very steep street, so it was hard to get back to the hotel walking, I had to stop several times to try to catch my breath and rest, I had to walk very slowly, and just started to get used to it in my last day in Cusco.The architecture in Cusco is another amazing feature of the city, old spanish archtecture mixed with old inca archtecture, the churches and old building are all very detailed and with brown and characteris color.From the Plaza de Armas you can have a really nice view of these constructions, and close to it you can also see the exemple of mixed archtectures, the Qorikancha Temple, or the Temple of the Sun, build over an old inca construction stand as another eye-catching and most importante places in Cusco. Get on a tour and get it know from the inside, you will find a lot more inca construction inside it.And of Course, the night life, Cusco has an amazing night life, with plenty of pubs, restaurants, caffes and night clubs, Enjoy the local cousine of the place, like Lomo Saltado and the Cuy, there you can also find a Mcdonald's and Starbucks, but I would not recommend it, of course, the local pubs, crowded with turists and locals.I'm going to detail it on my next post about cusco.You can also check my travel videos on Youtube:https://www.youtube.com/user/ricfsSubscribe to my channel.Also visit my travel blog:http://www.tripcall.net

simply A MUST. as always, I love Cusco paintings, churches, streets, each time I come back, I find it more beautiful, safe and with more options to offer to tourists... feeling proud of being Peruvian.

A blend of two cultures. Cusco is really what you would call the fusion of the Spanish and Inca culture - despite the tumultuous past and clashes between the Spanish and the Incas - the good news is that today the agricultural, cultural and archeological heritage is still alive!

Old Colonial at its best.. One can revel in the colonial richness, whilst still touching the magic and mystical Inca history. The only downside was the persistance of street vendors plying their crafts. 'Gracias, no', was not sufficient to keep them at bay. But if you choose to take them on, enjoy the bargaining!

Amazing cusco. Loved the walks thru the streets, looking into churches and art centres. The museum which houses the largest fresh water pearl in the world was amazing with. It's handcrafted gold and silver embellishments. Must be worth a fortune but not much safety measures. Most tourists don't know about this piece, I think.
Pritty / interesting. I did like the Cathedral, pretty square. Fun people trying to sell things (way of life )Saq say mama ( ruins ) were good to see, Intrtrsting
Lots to see and do. Historic city center and surroundings lots to see many nice museums and churches as well as nice ruins

Historic venue mixed with modern commercialism. Everything is based around the Plaza de Armas, where you will find the main cathedrals, in addition to a McDonalds and a KFC. Locals will offer to take pictures with you for a few Nuevo Soles, but ignore all this and wander the side streets. You'll find classic Inc architecture mixed with every day business. I was surprised to discover a jewish quarter near my hotel. It was surreal to see classic Inca/colonial buildings with signs and menus printed in Hebrew. Other hidden gems you'll find just wandering are Inca double doorway entrances just mix with modern architecture. Enjoy eating from a street vendor or just wandering.

A very special place. Loved walking the streets, visited the Cathedral well worth the entrance fee of 25 Nuevo Sol or $10 Canadian, drank pisco sour at one of the bar/restaurant on the balconies with view of the Plaza. We were lucky to be there during one of the street celebration, the sounds and music were a treat. Walked up the street of San Blas artists area, sorry I did not buy a retablo, beautiful paintings of angels... another time

Pleasant are to walk around. We stayed in Cusco for three days and every day spent a bit of time walking in and around the city's historic center. There are a number of attractions within easy walking distance, as well as restaurants. I think the key to fully enjoying this area is to stay within easy walking distance.
No flies but too many vendors. Great City, nice people. But just keep get annoyed every two minutes by someone who waqnts to sell you something. Make sure to visit the Cathedral,
Interesting center. I enjoyed my visit to this Historical Center. It was well laid out and presented interesting stories. Well worth a stop.

A top city despite the draw backs. Cusco was the centre of the Inca Empire, and is one of my favourite cities in the world. It’s my second time here, and we will stay about three weeks, but it’s not really long enough to absorb everything that this city has to offer. Apart from all the official ruins, there are so many original Inca fountains, walls and little lane ways to admire around the city (San Blas comes to mind), as well as all the impressive colonial architecture and the beautiful plazas. The people here are also generally very sweet if you take the time to relate.On the down side, the street vendors can become annoying (best just to ignore them), almost all the clothing items for sale that they say are 100% alpaca are actually synthetic and made in China, as are most of the souvenirs. There are still authentic artefacts and fabric to be found, but they are becoming few and far between. There is an abundance of hostels, hotels, cafes and restaurants, so you should easily be able to find accommodation and food to suit your taste. (Jack’s is undoubtedly the best café in the mid-range space if you can get a table) There is not much available in the top end, but that’s probably a good thing as it keeps prices reasonable.One could complain that it has become too touristy here, but that is only to be expected in such an archaeologically significant area that Cusco is.
Lindo. You have to take care of your health, it is better to walk slow and relax the first days in order to get used to the altitude.
worth at least two days!. We spent nearly 4 days walking through this entire area. The cathedral alone is worth one full day. There is a heavy police presence, so you will be safe, even at night.
cusco. The center, is very nice, neverthless the streets around are so dirty, it's a shame locals just don't care
Wonderful Squares. The squares of Cusco are all incredible! The beautiful and restored buildings are plentiful and some with balconies have been converted into fine dining restaurants.

You will go on your way to Machu Picchu. Very small. Not all that much to do. I stayed here for 5 days and was a bit bored. Really it's only a staging post for MP! Maybe better in the on-season! Look up pubs, bars, restaurants and museums on Tripadvisor…

Beautiful. Capital of Inca civilization. Beautifully preserved center. Impressive mixture of Inca and Colonial architecture. Good choice of restaurants and accommodation that cater all budgets...but it is at the age of tolerable level of touristiness. As a foreign tourism you are mostly considered just as a walking wallet. I found it rather hard to make genuine conversation and make. As Per city this size I found it surprising that there was no cinema. Drivers excessively use horns ( again beyond the level observed in any other city in South America)
fascinating old town. a place of real character with mix of cultural heritages. Well preserved. Easy and safe to walk around

Too much to see too little time. We loved Cusco the tour was great but there is so much to see and do I advise you spend more than one day. We took a half at the pool I our fabulous hotel Palacio Nazarenas and then did the tour. Our guide was great and we had done a few other day trips with him by then. We felt like we made a local friend. This was all arranged by Hernan at Pachamama

A lovely cobble stone area with many restaurants. It is just nice to stroll around, look at the souvenirs and eat at the quaint restaurants. Plaza de Armas was one of my favorite spots. Also, the massages are just 30 soles, so go ahead and get one - there are many salons. Some are located on the Triumph street.

Interesting and educating centre of all civilisations occupying this area including the Inca. Very interesting and thought provoking. Give yourself enough time to spend reading and absorbing this information.
