Clean, friendly and safe!. A great old town central plaza with good food, nice sights and amazing history to take in while enjoying Cusco ; ) Do go!!! Hope this review was helpful!!!
nice town centre, impressive Cathedral. Watch out for the hawkers, though they're not as bad as in Egypt for example. Great bars to chill out and most of the tour companies are located here
3D history. You get to see the mixture of Inca/Spanish/peruvian culture infused in this city. Walking around near plaza, you also see authentic bakery shops and coffee.

Follow the Centuries through the Narrow Streets. A unique piece of Inca and Spanish colonial history, fascinating buildings built on top of Inca foundations, sad that one culture decided to destroy another!
Walking Cusco. The striking thing about Cusco is the inca architecture and their mastery over the stone cutting, it looks like all is cut with a later..just unbelievable.

colonial city but where are the Peruvians. This is really a very beautiful city, not comparable with any other city I have visited in S America. It is however stunning that you don't see poor Peruvians on the streets like in other cities, selling all kind of stuff and adding a lot of local charm. There is a very high police presence - do they chase away poor Peruvians?
Beautiful quiet colonial town. Cuzco was the best city we discovered in Peru thanks to the architecture, the food and the friendly Peruvian people.

Beautiful romantic colonial center. This is a great walking city (we liked it best between La Paz and Surce) although you get approached much more by sellers of various wares. You must pass through the central plaza at night too see the lights and people watching. Its also a good place to buy bus tickets and plan excursion. But shop around for both as prices and services very from shop to shop. You can also get a good cheap message (25-30 sols 10 usd, negotiable ) in the center plaza. (they will find you don't worry...)

Cusco - Peru. I had only perfect experience from Peru, It was so fascinating to capture life here. Especially old people ! Also young children was so cute for photography. I hope i can go back again ! Cusco has a lot to offer to tourists !

Great place to walk around and dine. It was really a cool place with all old type buildings and modern shops and restaurants. We loved the stroll. We also found a nice Indian restaurant here. Only that it rained quite a bit during our stay
You can Find everything. In Cusco historic center you can find everything with good prices, typical food and also foreign food, mexican, Indian, french, italian and others.

Lots of history!. The center of Cusco has a lot of Incan history to offer. Not only the many museums are worth a visit, but I also liked the small little streets with original Incan built walls. The Plaza de Armas is lovely to just sit in the sun and enjoy the day, The only thing I don't really like are the many sellers that don't let you a minute alone enjoy the sun, but I guess this is normal in such a touristic place.

Cusco - beautiful and bustling. Cusco is a great place to visit, with lots of beautiful architecture in the historic centre, but it was a bit overwhelming at how touristy it was. We were used to visiting places in the north of the country where we hard pressed to see any other non-Peruvian tourists most of the time. Obviously we were 'part of the problem' in Cusco, but we did find it a little too much, and it was the 'off' season. It was nice to grab a taxi to the bus station, quite a way out of the centre, and to walk back through neighbourhoods where there were no other gringos, and to stop off at a menu place for a very nice meal at a very reasonable price.

Beautifully preserved, yet modern. What a great place. I strongly recommend you visit. Watch for the tiny Starbucks with a balcony overlooking the plaza. I know, I know....I shouldn't hang out at Starbucks when in such a lovely area, but it was a great place to watch the activity on the square and enjoy some travel journal writing. Lots of good shopping nearby. Residents selling trinkets have great deals and are willing to barter. Ask about the Chocolate factory right off the square...it's really good!

Cusco was the highlight of our trip. Cusco deserves at least two or three days to see it all (not counting a full-day trip to Machu Picchu), and more if you want to take a walk to the hills and see Sacsayhuaman and the surrounding area. The iconic Inca sites are as striking as you imagine them to be when planning your visit, perhaps especially the Corikancha. The central squares are great places to stroll and browse, though in the evening you can get some hassle from street sellers and people trying to persuade you to try their restaurant - nothing very aggressive though, they were always polite. Many of the immediate post colonial buildings are based around courtyards and are definitely worth stepping into when you get the chance. The building housing the Machu Picchu Museum (Casa Concha) is a good example, but others house many small shops and restaurants. We were very struck by the pottery in the Museum of Pre-Colombian Art which clearly influenced early 20th Century modern artists such a Picasso, Klee, Moore and others. Your appreciation of the Spanish colonial churches will be determined your attitude to the imagery that characterises their interior art. Top tip: take the time to have an early evening beer or wine on the balcony of one of the many bars and restaurants overlooking the main square. After a long day, an hour spent 'people watching' was always a treat. Our trip was in 'the rainy season' (late December) and there were a few showery days, but we really enjoyed the more temperate weather as we wanted to get out and about without having to worry all the time about intense UV exposure at 3,500 meters. My wife had been once before (15 years ago) when it was dry and parched and preferred the green grass and mountain flowers of this time of year.
Bustling, vibrant area. Look for a restaurant with a view of the square. Walk around, go to the local market - not just the tourist area, a few blocks from he main square.

Center of Town. Being in the center if Cusco has its advantages. This is basically the starting point for all things Cusco. The plaza is attractive and the surrounding buildings make the area beautiful. What I liked about all Peruvian plazas, I first saw here; true community activity. It was a wonderful visual and cultural experience.

History and Architecture in the Old City of Cusco. I was absolutely amazed at the amount of churches in this little city. As I walked around, I tried to imagine what it must have been like to live in Cusco 300 years ago. I could not keep from looking up to admire the beauty in the architecture on every building. Such a beautiful place against the backdrop of the hills of Cusco.This is a city definitely on my list of cities to visit again.
Lots of Churches to walk around. Many OLD Churches to see, but don't try to come in ,the have their FEES that will cost you a Hand and a SOL ( PEN- NUEVO SOL $1.00= 0.36c )

Loved the city. The city has an Andean look but is quite rustic and vibrant making it a beautiful city. Has lot of history associated yet modern with all pubs. The plaza de Armas, the cobbled narrow roads, Cathedral, Cristo blanco among many other things are must do.
great city. Cuzco is a charming city , with airy Plaza de Armas , ranged with 5 beautiful churches, restaurants and bars .Lots to see and shop!

Cusco - What A High!. Historic Cusco, worth the visit. The old town is beautiful with quaint cobblestone lanes teaming with restaurants and cheap eateries, souvenir shops etc. Don't underestimate the risk of altitude sickness, crept up on us the 2nd night and at 2:00am felt like someone had placed my head in a vice - beware! The people are calm, polite and beautiful.
Nice town. Cozy town, but believe it or not it has 750,000 inhabitants I was told by our guide. The monastery is something to see and the surrounding narrow streets and shops.

A great place to visit!. A days worth of wonderful things to see within a one minute walk of each other! The plaza is terrific with a wonderful fountain and beautiful landscaping. On one side is the cathedral which is a must see ( be sure to do the audio tour, it's free) . The architecture is great and the artwork is terrific. Across the plaza is the wonderful Jesuit church, with a fabulous Baroque interior. From the plaza there are many streets which still have the original into walls intact (and generally built upon by the Spaniards). A real jewel.

Free walking tour. We joined a free walking tour @ Cusco. Guide was well prepared and gave us a good time for reasonable tip. One thing I missed: peruvian restaurant instead of japanese recommended by him.

Need Improvement in Infrastructure.... For someone in a wheelchair or handicapped i can not recommend that town at all.. In churches museums you have to pay the full price, noone will help you going up the stairs... and you will find out soon that you can not see even 50 % of the assured wheelchair accessibility of the place from the person which sold you the tickets.Excuses like it s historical and nothing can be changed ...makes me laugh..Cusco People don't respect handicapped people at all ...on the road or on the pedestrian way....might be they are ignorant... Interesting to tell you that Arequipa is much better in this regard...people respect you more...and are helpful and you don't get ripped off at cathedrals to pay soles....you have nice broad pedestrian ways....and nice squares..thats the experience of someone in a wheelchair which traveled across south america...

Historic gem!. My husband Peter and I spent 3 days and nights in Cusco and easily could have spent a few more days with so much to see and do unchecked on our to do list. With the exception of catching a ride from the airport to our accommodations, we walked everywhere. The stone work on the buildings and the streets alone were spectacular sights, and architectural beauty could be found everywhere in the Spanish Colonial part of the city. (Outside central Cusco was the typical developing nation city.) The Plaza de Armas and the other plazas were always teeming with activity, so, when we needed a break from walking, we simply sat on a bench to people watch for a while. The traffic may seem absolutely crazy to some people, but drivers did one thing they rarely do in Austin, TX: use their turn signals so pedestrians at least know what's going on.We trekked up and down hills to see all the plazas, San Blas and most of the rest of the colonial section. Our trekking included worthwhile visits to Qorikancha (Quechua for “Golden Courtyard”), Museo de Arte Precolombino, Museo de Plantas Sagradas, and Sacsaywaman, all of which I plan to review separately. The guide books list Sacsaywaman as outside of town, but we made the steep uphill walk in less than half an hour. Plus, the views along the way were amazing, and we saw a section of town we would not otherwise have traversed. Our favorite places to dine were Victor Victoria (breakfast one morning), Aroma (in Plantas Sagradas), and Café Punchay, all of which offered casual and fairly inexpensive healthy food that was vegetarian friendly. The travel guides were not exaggerating, however, in describing the incessant push from those selling tourist trinkets; however, with only one exception, a simple, “No, gracias,” repeated a few times if necessary, generally stopped the sales pitch that was immediately followed by another and another and another. The one exception was a teenage girl who hurled at our backs what I’m sure were expletives in Spanish, but we laughed it off and went on our way. One travel guide suggestion with which I highly disagree, specifically with regard to Cusco, is the recommendation that travelers merely use their ATM cards to get cash. Instead, I recommend bringing some cash and changing it to soles at one of a multitude of kiosks set up to do so at a reasonable rate. We never found an ATM that allowed us to take out more than 400 – 450 soles (about $145.00), and each transaction cost us $10.00 ($5.00 at each end). In addition to this problem, our bank, Chase Bank, flags Peru as a high fraud risk country, so we would make a withdrawal then the second or third would place a flag on our card that required us to call the bank to tell them that the transactions were ours. Finally, one ATM ate my card, and the bank stalled us about calling the subcontractor to retrieve it. We never had any of these problems outside Cusco, though.Many travelers use Cusco as a pit stop on their way to and/or from Machu Picchu, and, by doing so, miss a lovely and friendly, albeit, frenetic, city.

Pretty city. We stayed in total 6 nights in Cusco and don't regret a single day of it. The city has number of interesting monuments and museums to see, has good shopping possibilities and a number of fine restaurants. Above all it is easy to get around, most of it you can do on foot. We only used taxis a few times and they are very cheap to any European standard. I have say we were lucky with the weather, nice and sunny and not too warm.It is also easy to visit the Sacred Valley on daytrips from Cusco (avoids switching hotels, we don't like the packing/unpacking if we can avoid it).

Fab. I have travelled a lot, and I think cusco beauty wise, is high up on my list. It is so beautiful, and at night there are a million lights shining down on you from the barrios around the town. Amazing.

Wonderful city to visit. Cusco is much more than just a gateway to visit Machu Pichu. Wonderful hotels in old Spanish colonial monasteries and homes, for example, the Hotel Monasterio, an Orient Express Hotel, is just one of many options. Great shopping, excellent dining options and much more await you in this charming and elegant ancient city.

Back in time. On coming into the town centre of Cusco I immediately felt like I had stepped back in time. The architecture and the locals trying to sell their wares. You do need to be aware of the cars zooming around as you cross the street. We went to Paddy's Irish pub, the highest Irish pub in the world which we thought was amusing. We only had 2 days to visit and wished we had more.
Cusco. Cusco was wonderful and my only regret is insufficient time to explore all of the sites. our guide was great and we saw the main highlights. Plenty of restaurants to chose from.

Living history. Even if you aren't a history buff, you'll enjoy Cusco. The old buildings and narrow streets provide a backdrop for current-day Cusco and some great people watching. The altitude robbed me of my ability to do anything strenuous so I enjoyed the chance to see ice cream vendors carrying their ice cream in a thermal bag over their shoulder, young girls hoping you'll pay for a picture of them and their lambs, young couples cuddling on park benches. It felt like a glimpse into life for residents of this popular tourism destination.

One of the most amazing places in the world. I enjoyed every second here. It is beautiful, people is warm and welcoming. Food is amazing and sightseeings well is Cusco! so there is plenty to see. Fantastic!

Cusco historic center. My daughter and I fell in love with Cusco. Lots of great historical sites to visit in and around the city. From Saksaywaman one can see the entire city, the snow-capped mountains and the glacier on a clear day. The people are friendly, and the city is easy to navigate. The architecture is varied. We stayed at the Terre Andina and loved the hotel, especially the staff. We were there for 6 days, well worth the time.

A living museum alright.... We ended up not having a whole lot of time to enjoy Cusco on its own merits, and we wish we could have had at least a couple more days now, just ambling about and enjoying the history and ambience: it most definitely is a living, breathing city, and you just want to enjoy it, revel in it, and soak it all in. It's obviously completely touristy, but it doesn't feel overwraught, overdone or overly stuffed with the most heinous aspects of tourism. A real charmer of a place.

Beautiful historical center. It's simply beautiful with Spanish colonial buildings constructed over Inca walls. The main problem is the heavy traffic and bad air, the city should ban cars from the main square, Plaza de Armas, to preserve the buildings and make the place safer for the many people who stroll around
The Heart of Cuzco. Beautiful area, many things to do and see, many restaurants from fast food to full service, Peruvian or International, walking distance to many area attractions.
Beautiful. The main plaza in Cusco is lovely, as are also the sorrounding streets. A very enjoyable place to visit before and after your trip to Machu Picchu.
Enchanting city. Cobblestone pavement, little houses, churches and a nice atmosphere everywhere. I loved walking around day and night.

Museo Machu Piccu. The museum was a little disappointing. Machu Piccu itself was, as expected, incredible however the museum was had few artifacts and little information, there were however one or two rooms that were being redesigned. It was also considerably more expensive than most of the museums in cusco. The Inka Museum was more informative and accessible.

Cusco's Plaza Mayor and its Official Flag. Among the various attraction in Cusco's historic center is the Plaza Mayor or main square, an ubiquitous feature/attraction in most Latin American cities and towns. Cusco's Plaza Mayor is no exception with important buildings and structures surrounding it. Among these are the Cusco Cathedral of Santo Domingo, the Jesuit Church of the Holy Spirit, the Church of Triumph, the Church of the Holy Family, and the Municipal building. at the center of the square is a statue of Pachacutec, the Incan emperor who built the Machu Picchu Lost City of the Incas.An interesting item about Cusco is its official flag, flying high atop the municipal building in Cusco's Plaza Mayor, a rainbow flag consisting of SEVEN stripes each of the color of the rainbow (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, and violet) except the blue and the indigo have been changed to sky blue and blue. This official flag of Cusco (symbolizing an Inca territory) is very similar to the rainbow flag used by the present gay and lesbian community world side (only SIX stripes - no sky blue stripe). This has led to a concern locally, nationally, and internationally because the similarity of the two flags could be mistakenly interpreted as a tribute to "gay pride". This is particulary an issue with Peruvians who are predominantly catholics.

Really Great, but altitude is high. Cusco is a really interesting and varied town with many museums and historic buildings. The Inca sites above the town (Saqsayhuaman, Tambomachay etc) are really impressive, but as they are several hundred meters higher than the town, make sure that you get used to the altitude before going up to see them

Stunning!. A beautiful old city built on Inka ruins. A surprising delightful city center that is vibrant and alive with activity. Enjoyed exploring and just being a part of all that this city has to offer. Highly recommend!

Cusco City's fascination. Coming to Cusco after time in Lima & Amazonas it felt as if I was in a very different part of Peru. There's a kind of buzz, a constant activity to the ciudad. Lots of people wandering everywhere of course. But also, more than anywhere else, you could feel the footprint of history in Cusco, Santo Domingo/Qorikancha, the fusion of Catholic Spanish power & Inca culture & worship; the narrow lanes & the ancient footpaths with their huge slabs of stone squares & thin strips of small, rounded cobblestones. Unaytambo where I stayed, was on the site of the former Inca palacios, the centre of the once great Inca empire. The high altitude added to the slightly surreal feel of the place. It's a tourist hub also, so lots of interesting sights, San Pedro Mercado (where you can buy all manner of exotic produce), the imposing El Catedral, Inca Museo, numerous restaurants where you can try llama if you like, & so on. There are faux museums too it must be said, Chocomuseo & the Pisco Museum respectively are, transparently a shop & a bar, & don't even attempt to thinly disguise this fact.

A Colonial Gem. The city is easy to walk around and every back street seems to have another beautiful building to marvel at. A real buzz to the place, it is not just a touristy place, real people live and work there and its interesting to sit and watch from a coffee shop or bar
Cusco Historic center. The city and surroundings are among the most interesting in the world. Peruvian guides are knowledgeable and friendly.

Interesting architecture. We were in Cusco for two days and enjoyed the lovely square with all its interesting buildings. The only downside for us was the inside of the Cathedral which, in my opinion, was much too ostentatious and overpowering. We had a delicious buffet meal and Andean entertainment in one of the many restaurants on the square. On the Sunday we watched a ceremony led by the Mayor with various bands, army, boy scouts, girl guides etc. As with cities worldwide, the little streets off the main thoroughfare are often more interesting than the bustle of the main tourist areas with all sorts of different shops and cafes. Well worth a visit.

Lovely, historic town. Cusco is the embodiment of a beautiful, historic town. Fabulous restaurants abound, shopping is a wonderful experience, and the hotels are charming..The colonial architecture is magnificent.Plan to spend a few days and enjoy a Pisco sour or two!

Beautiful During the Day and Night. A typical colonial square always full of life! There are many restaurants and places to shop for souvenirs.Charming colonial architecture, baroque churches and narrow streets. There is a lot going on and maybe not enough time to go exploring everything. The only thing annoying are the people trying to sell massage packages or try to convince you to go to restaurants.

One of the most romantic places in the world. Staying there in the evening, there is the most beautiful place I've ever been. I wish I could stay here longer.
Totally in love with this place.

A special city.... Cusco is a very special city, lots of history and places to see. The old churches are full of art and history. One can wonder through the little streets and observe beautiful architecture of colonial times. It is very easy to walk through and the streets are very clean. It is a lot of fun just to walk everywhere, there is always something to see. Old cafes with balconies to sit and just people watch. I enjoyed my trip to Cusco!
Cusco. Fascinating city .... so much to see and do. Colourful markets, historic buildings, winding streets, great restaurants, a real feast for the senses.

In love with Cusco. Is one of the cities where you can stay more than a week and find what to do. If you want some action, you can find some trekks in the region. For the viit, plenty options and also to eat. Even some shows with loal dances. I want to plan to return to see the jungles and do some more trekks.
worth a couple of days. Cusco Historic center is well worth at least two days to visit, lots of interesting architecture and history
veautyfull. The houses have a colonial stile with clay tiles and the bases of the buildings are old Inca buildingsCusco has many colonial churches.
Nice place. Nice place to wonder around and look at the various shops, restaurants and bars. Everything is on walking distance.

i love cusco!. cusco has soo much to see and do ! the people are very friendly(some a bit too much, LOL) the shops are fun to go thru and when u go make sure you look for the tiny little shoppes in the way back at the end of the roads. they have some of the most unique and actual handmade stuff. and better priced. altho considering how much they make a month to live on; i wasnt too keen on bartering.also make sure to go to their market!

Good way to pass the day. Had a great time walking around the square, very active at night and lots to do during the day. Some cool churches to see and some great restaurants. Also just a cool place to hang out and watch life go by.

Cusco Historic Center. There is a lot to see and do in this area. It was an easy walk from our hotel and there are many hotels in this area. The nights are crisp and the sparse lights on the hills surrounding this area seem almost like constellations. The streets to and from this area are quaint and historic. Just a pleasant area to walk with historic churches to visit. Plenty of restaurants and shops. Having a Starbucks right there was a nice surprise! And a great Irish bar in the area!

Altitude experience worth doing!. This was our second stop on the way to Machu Picchu and is where you get acclimatised. Don't underestimate what the altitude can do to you- whilst I felt ok, simple walking up hill leaves you feeling a little breathless ( and I'm reasonably fit for a 50 plus person).They may give you coca leaf tea to help, but be prepared it can knock you out :0)Once you settle in its worth exploring this old town and a tour is well worth it. It has fantastic history and the trip to sexy woman ( not spelt that way) will truly blow your mind in how clever the Incas were.You'll be amazed at the amount of traffic going round and round the main square at all times ( I now detest the crappy little taxis!)If you fancy a few beers in a nice atmosphere, visit Paddy's Irish bar (highest Irish bar on the planet) in the corner of the main square for a nice atmosphere.The market is also a experience worth trying with pigs heads etc all openly displayed! All in all a fascinating place well worth experiencing

Acient City with a metropolitan colonial, modern flair!. When you're in Cusco you can feel in your heart an entanglement of the ages and Cultures!! INKA, Colonial Spain and modern... It's fun to be there all day long day and night. There is always something to do and see whether you like it or not you become part of it. Don't miss it. It'll be worth just even to set on the benches and see the day go by. It's energy is so positive that leaves you clean of stress.:)

Cusco - still worth a visit. The first impression is that this place is too touristic and you may get annoyed by all the people trying to sell you tickets to Machu Picchu, rafting, etc. or all the "North Fake" outlets. However, the city has a charm that you will find if you stroll along into the backstreets. You may also take a short drive to one of the nearby Inka sites or visit good museums. If you fly directly to Cusco to do the Inka trail I would advise you to spend 2-3 days in Cusco to get used to the altitude and thus avoid altitude sickness on the trail.

A long day well spent in Cusco. We decided the best way to see Cusco was to get up early and walk. We visited all of the churches, walked around the three squares which make up the old town, and generally tried to fit in as much as we could. All or any of the churches or cathedral are worth a visit on their own. Together they are a sensory overload of artworks, cedar carving and speak volumes about the excesses of the Conquistadores. Many of the streets in Cusco are still lined with Inca walls, one of the best being along side the Archbishops Palace, itself built on an Inca temple utilising a lot of the original walls. For us, the jewel in the crown was Koricancha, where the Convent of Santo Domingo stands. Following an earthquake in 1950, the Spanish building collapsed, uncovering the Inca walls they had rendered over. In the rebuild, they have left the walls exposed. The quality of the stonework is beyond belief. If you go nowhere else in Cusco. go to Koricancha. Lastly, for an excellent, reasonably priced meal, go to Jacks Cafe or the Irish pub (allegedly the highest in the world). The meals are rather large and we found it best to share a main, the owners are used to it and happily provide an extra plate and cutlery. Drink plenty of coca tea and take it quietly, but if you can, spend a lot of time wandering around Cusco. You will not be disappointed.
nice place. we liked the place because although very touristic, because of Machu, it is also a "real" town; We just like to stroll through the town and enjoy the atmosphere

Scenic and inspiring...just watch your wallet/camera/phone/Ipad, etc..... Downtown Cusco and the historic center are beautiful and the architecture is amazing. At night, the lighted fountain and buildings are beautiful and the surrounding hillsides are like mountains full of stars. Just be careful there because it is often very crowded and there are plenty of pickpockets, hawkers, and other folks who prey on tourists. My only complaint about the Historic Center was that it was almost impossible to just sit down on a bench and enjoy the park/scenery without being constantly harassed. I got very tired of saying "No Gracias" over and over again to street salesmen, and being harassed by beggars or locals wanting to charge me to have my picture taken with them.

Cusco Historic Center is still present. Most of the places in the world have changed nowadays. But Cuzco remained still deep marks from the past and that makes it interesting. If you have time plan in the festival of Inti Rahmi justunforgetable where the natives meets in the countryside dancing, eating and just let the work a little bit behind. Wonderful churches and Museums .

Well conserved and vivid historic center. Compared to other historic centers in Latin America, this one has more Inca influences as it was the Inca Empire Capital. Also as it receives so many tourists, it has lots of restaurants and hotels. Also it is safe and clean. Very nice to walk in. In terms of Spanish buildings it is not the best thou.

Absolutely fantastic. I love Cusco! This place is full of life and colour. The beautiful colours of the clothes of the local Inca ladies is fantastic. I love the narrow streets and the buildings. Ok. I love it all.After seeing Cusco, it makes me wonder why Colonia in Uruguay is considered a World Heritage Site. There is no comparison.
Really nice. Really enjoyed this area. Shops were everywhere, beautiful fountains and flowers. Well Policed felt very safe here. Just beautiful looking up toward the mountains at the houses.

Cusco Plaza de Armas. Cuzco's Plaza de Armas by night is a beautiful sight to see. is surrounded by historical buildings, restaurants, stores, churches, and more just like Starbucks & McDonalds . but why would you eat money when you can eat good Peruvian food.

Colonial splendour and history.. Wonderful churches and buildings of the early colonial era, with many built on Inka palaces. Narrow streets and beautiful balconies and a picture opportunity around every corner of the old town. Also, find time to visit the central market for color, smells and food items of real Peru.

City Center. We stayed off the square and found it a great place to spend 3 days unwinding after a hectic trip. Great restaurants and coffee places. The artifacts returned to Peru from Machu Picchu are in a small museum, well worth a visit.

Under the Radar Gem!. Cusco is very beautiful and has less tourists than other major cities. The Plaza de Armas, Saqsayhuaman, Cristo Blanco, Moray, Salineras, and the Pisac Market are all a must-see for those who are stopping here on their way to Machu Picchu. As I was staying with a Peruvian because I was volunteering, I was lucky to get a personal tour of these attractions. Driving on unpaved roads to Moray and Salineras are absolutely stunning, especially with the Andes as the backdrop. Breathtaking beauty!

History history history. Wow what amazing things to see here it took us two full days just to get round Cusco historic town. Definitely go with a guide their knowledge is second to none. But I would recommend going for a wander after your guided tour on your own pop in and out of the stores stop for a drink a one of the many cafes just remember to check your bill. Well worth a trip.

Cross between Colonial and Inca - Magical. The dichotomy of the Colonial period of Peru clashes directly with the mystery of the Inca in the Historical Center of Cusco. Where Imperial Build, closely knit stones of the Inca form the foundations of later Colonial (Spaniard) build leaves one in utter awe of the ancient Inca builders and their society. Great city, amazing cross architecture, wonderful vibe and people located in a dizzying 11,000 feet above sea level!

Beautiful Highland Inca Capital. Cusco is a beautiful city at an altitude over 10,000 feet. You need to take precautions for the altitude. It was the capital of the Inca and there is evidence of Inca stonework everywhere. The Spaniards used the Inca stone work for the foundations of their later structures. Cusco is a city of beautiful churches and your should visit the Cathedral on the main square. Not to put to fine a point on it, but the Inca statute on the main square is not so bad. The locals are very proud of their Inca ancestors. Cusco has several fine hotels and restaurants. There are fine shops along with those selling tourist mementos. Cusco is much less populated than Lima (500,000 vs. 9 million) and was sunny during our visit and not as gloomy as Lima was. You can catch a train to Machu Picchu from Cusco, although our group took it from Ollantaytambo. We think Cusco is a must if you are visiting Peru.

Marvelous Cuzco!. This city is very interesting, with ancient buildings, narrow streets, typical Andean markets, and the marvelous Plaza de Armas originally built by the Incas, and much more. Also, the surrounding areas are worth seeing such as Saqsayhuaman ruins and Ollantaytambo which, during the Inca period, was the royal estate of Emperor Pachacuti who conquered the region and built the town.Cuzco is a great treat for the Inca interested tourist

The other (hippier) walking tour. Ran into Marco (the guide) and the group while he was giving the tour. Marco was an enthusiastic and whimsical guide. He intertwined the history and the culture of the Inca people with practical titbits on where to eat and do your laundry. After a pretty healthy hike (esp. it was in the afternoon after we just arrived at this high altitude city) up to the San Cristobal church with a panoramic view of Cusco, we were offered to sample the on the spot made local Pisco Sour cocktail. Overall a great experience. They offer tours from Mon to Sat at 12:15pm meeting at the main square.
Great place to get a feel for Cusco. This is a must see. The Plaza, the Churches, the people. A great way to spend a day , learning about the culture and history of this wonderful city
An amazing place. If you going to do the Inca trail spend time in Cuzco. It is a beautiful town with lots of character and historic places to visit.
Cusco Historic Center. No words can describe the Historic Center. You are transported into the past. Walking tours are offered. I have not personally taken it but it could be interesting.

Lovel and lively. Beautiful architecture and history. Lovely and friendly people.
Taxis are kind of a hassle though.
p.s. almost everywhere off the Plaza de Armas is UPHILL!

Cusco. we spent 4 days in total here, the city is great, we stayed at a small cozy hostel Magico. Cheap and really nice place. We did a trip around the city, it was Free tours, they start every day from the main square, where Starbucks is. They showed some really great places, told us interesting stories and facts, you won't find in Internet, showed us how to make Pisco Sour.
Back in time. The historic district is a blend of Inca walls and Spanish colonial buildings and churches. Both were very interesting. Some very fine restaurants were located around the Plaza.

the best peruvian town. turistic but full of atmosphear, womderfull, not to be missed.just strolling around and take the area of this old town. where you can find lots of restaurants, café, wifi bar, really modern, but old at the same time
One of the great squares in the world. Cusco's main square is up there with Venice's, Rome's, Praghe's, Madrid's main squares. Just as beautiful. The difference is that it is even more alive!
Cusco Alive. Cusco was an interesting place and the people were beautiful. We did some sight seeing and visited the market.

Stunning cityscape!. I think everyone should see Cuzco's Plaza de Armes by night at least once in their lives - I dont know when Ive seen a more beautiful sight. Cuzco's downtown is also great in other ways, like it's small and easy to get around, so much to see, lots of great restuarants. i feel like as a tourist city Cuzco gets the balance right - good food (AND COFFEE!) are available and things are well set up, but without losing the character of the place. really a stunning city and I hope to return someday!!!!
Great place to relax. Loved the main square for people watching, and eating/drinking. Lots of other little squares too. Clean and dafe.

Must see. There are main two tours in Cusco: Sacred Valley and Historic Center.
I've done both but my favourite is Cusco's Historic Center. In this one, you have the opportunity to see the temples, learn about the Inca's engineering and see the city from above. Don't miss it!

just beautiful!!!. this is one of those places you will remember forever. it's a lovely place. the architecture, the mountains around it...try to spend time there and get to know cusco. don't visit it just thinking about machu pichu. cusco has a lot to offer

cuscocity.com tickets to Machu Picchu ruins. I attempted to order entry tickets to Machu Picchu on the government site www.machupicchu.gob.pe and found it was impossible. I spent days back and forth with my credit card company and bank to get this site to accept my verified by visa and could never get it to work, I read that everyone seems to have this problem. So I decided to pay a little extra and use www.cuscocity.com to order my tickets. There website seemed just fine and the payment went right through. They charged my visa on the 16th of July and immediately I got an e-mail verification back saying my order was in process. I waited and waited, and finally on the 13th of August (almost 1 month later) I got an email with a reservation number that was invalid (obviously not paid for) and a letter saying I could show this at the park (not true). I immediately tried to call cuscocity.com (number was no longer in service) and e-mailed them with the problem, requesting a valid number so I could print out my tickets on the official www.machupicchu.gob.pe website (the only way to verify these are valid). I got no response. A day later, after reading some very scary reviews of this company I e-mailed them again requesting valid ticket information must be sent to me no later than 14 August or I wanted my order cancelled and would dispute charges with visa and paypal. I received a very nasty e-mail back from Ed. However, by noon on the 14th of August I finally received an e-mail with the correct number and was able to print my tickets off the official site. So all's well that ends well, but it is a shame that a threat is the only thing that prompted some action and that I had to wait a month for something that shouldn't have taken more than 1 day. I wouldn't recommend or use this site again.

Beautiful city. It is so easy to walkaround Cusco city looking for handcrafts and places to see.You will find "Cusquenhas" carrying baby alpacas and wearing traditional clothes. They will ask you for money if you take a picture of them. However they are so cute that you will gladly give them a pair of soles (Peru currency) .

Wonderful - will go back. We all enjoyed our time in Cusco from our 19 year olds to my husband and I - the historic centre is safe and well preserved - with a plethora of interesting museums, charming streets and fantastic churches all steeped in pre -columbian or colonial history. From the local food market to the Inca Museum and the Qurikancha to the Cathedral all is interesting and the people were lovely.
Great at night. I loved the historic district, its like the Wild West. So much going on, so many differnet people. Everyone we encountered is happy you are in their city.
such a nice place. the city is so nice, and is not as contaminaded like Lima. we enjoyed walking in the streets ( the ones with light)

Definitely need to send time in Cusco's Plaza de Armas. This area is the heart of Cusco and is surrounded by historical buildings, restaurants, stores and more. Lots of people, so walk around, or simply sit on a bench and watch the world go by for a bit.
Really impressive Inca's know how. Cusco Historic center and the sites just above the historic center are great and give a good understanding of Inca's know how to build great walls/houses!

Peru Trek 4 Good - tour operator. Cusco, the sacred valley, the Inka trail and machu picchu were all spectacular and highly recommend! Peru Trek 4 Good, compared to other companies we witness along the way and previous trek experience, were disappointing. We had a reference from a friend as well as the high ratings on tripadvisor so perhaps it was just our trek. Our guide provided little information, the equipment was in poor condition, organization was not great...
A great city. One has to walk the whole of Cusco city to appreciate its beauty and its real historic value. The cobblestone streets are narrow and steep.

Beautiful!. The plaza is a must see in Cusco, and pretty much everywhere you want to go in town will lead you near or through the Plaza. I recommend doing some people watching, but beware that you will be pestered to buy things during the daytime. There are a lot of great restaurants either on the Plaza (Limo), or 1-block or so away. I've reviewed several in separate Cusco reviews.

Spent half a day enjoying the plaza. Just sitting on a bech and watching Cuzquenos and foreigners walk by, it is the heart and soul of the region. Other things to see are the Cathedral, La Compania district, do not miss the San Blas neighborhood great art and some really good paintings.

Walk there for free and enjoy. You should visit this plaza and its surrounds while in Cusco. Full of interesting buildings, cafes, tour operators, rail (inca rail and Peru rail) ticket providers, and even Starbucks & M'Donalds if you really need them....a great area to explore for hours. Do not buy any ticket to go there - we walked 10 min from our accommodation....and San Pedro market is only 5-10 min walk from here also.
It should be seen. It is excellent especially the historic square of the city. Inca ruins, churches and their histories are very interesting.

Deva Restaurant, Cusco. While recently staying in Cusco (May 2013) we were recommended to try Deva Restaurant. What a great experience. The local food was delicious and the service outstanding. Our waiter spent a lot of time with us, explaining local cooking techniques, showing us local produce and telling us stories about traditional beliefs involving food and ceremonies. We went there twice during our 4 day stay and had great experiences both times. Highly recommend.

Nice centre. The centre is nice but the tourist ticket is a rip off. We got the partial ticket for 70 soles which covers the sacred valley sight as the city centre ones did not seem worth it. Only one worth visiting is sechsayhaumen (spelt wrong!) and you can visit if free before 7am with no ticket!
Impressive city and allround view. Great historic buildings, fantastic mountain views and don't miss out on the night lights in the mountains surrounding this impressive city!
Organised half day tour. Picked up at hotel and taken by walking and bus to places of interest and up into the mountains. Excellent guide and interesting tour.

Full of History. This place is full of history. You can breath it in every street, wherever you turn, there is an incan wall, a colonial temple, a museum. I recommend taking a tour or hiring a guide to fully understand it.
Magnificent. Every corner, every street is full of living history. This is a place everybody should visit at least once in a lifetime.

excellent, but. the historic centre is beatuful, nice, clean, security is good, is safe to walk even at night, police is frendly, but the tour companies can reap u off the will charge a lot, like a taxi (I want to get around secret valley of the incas and when I ask the price was aprox $80 (they take advantege of the change currency) for one way, askig araound, find a local bus company, and taxis that get U to the near town in the valley for about $10 or taxi bus for 20 dollars, enjoy the arquitecture of cusco is amaizing, most of the hotels are near by, so the restaurant, to get to te museums and other churches buy the turistic tiket, that will get U in most of the historic places, but to get to the cathedral and local churches is extra special for non peruvian people, take the coca tea, really helps for the altitude of cusco. one of the best places I have been

Taking advantage of the Tourists. The historic centre itself is really nice, the plaza de Armas and surroundings well maintained, we also particularly enjoyed the many remnants of old Inca architecture with one of the highlights the twelve angled stone, used as inspiration for the logo of the ubiquitous Cusquena beer. However some locals keen to rip off the tourists - like taxi driver agreeing on 10 soles for a ride but not refusing to give change on a twenty 20 soles note, Alpaca foto ladies in authentic dress demanding as much as 10 soles per head for a couple of photos etc. Quite a contrast with Arequipa and Puno where the atmosphere is much friendlier.

Great Peru Experience with Escaped to Latin America. I planned a tour for five people to Peru via Escaped to Latin America and they did a great job of coordinating a trip to Lima, the Amazon, Cusco, and Machu Picchu. This was a highlight of my life. Everything was planned as requested and ran smoothly, so our time was never wasted. It was thrilling to travel the country by plane, train, boat, and van... and to eat great food and meet great people!Tim R-M

Cusco. Cusco is a great place to visit ,lots of interesting places to visit, many museums and churches but you need to purchase Boleto Turistico tickets. This saves you money so worth it.Be aware altitude sickness can be a big problem as Cusco is high in the Andes,, medication and oxygen can be bought at the chemists. If possible acclimatise in Lima or Arequipa before heading to Cusco. Cusco is a heritage site , full of Inca remains and history . We visited in June for Inti Raymi, festival of the sun, a live reenactment of Inca culture.Make sure you take warm clothes, it gets very cold at night and nowhere has heating.

City Tour. The tour was led by a guide. The guide was found by Ivan at the Terra Andina hotel. The tour was very interesting and the guide showed us some beautiful places in the city. The tour was very inexpensive.

Safe & charming with such potential. Cusco must have been breathtaking during its heyday and still you are able to find beautiful courtyards and wonderful historic buildings. Other than the Plaza de Armas which has been beautifully restored much of the city still is somewhat 'under-maintained' (which luckily does give you a very authentic feel) and could use some TLC. The pace is nice and slow and Cusco is a wonderful place to discover for a day or 2. There are plenty of interesting churches and historic buildings and a great market discover new fruits and other local delicacies. Also everything can be done on foot. Cusco is also a very nice base to discover the various Inca sites and sacred valley. All in all a highlight on any visit to Peru.
Wonderful views. Lots of history. Loved the shops, museums and churches. Don't be afraid to explore! (Didn't like the cold temps. at night)

Trip of a lifetime!. I was fortunate enough to be able to travel Peru recently and was amazed by everything I encountered. I traveled to Lima where I enlisted the services of Tika Trekking for my hike to Machu Picchu. It was among the most memorable vacations I have yet to have. I would recommend to anyone going, or thinking of going, to make plans.
Beautiful. We loved walking around the historic center and visiting the cathedrals. It is like being in another time. Such an interesting history and such beautiful buildings. Great shopping.
Cusco is Beautiful. The city of Cusco is both historic and beautiful. The cathedral is breathtaking, food is wonderful. I highly recommend.
Smells historic. Comparing to Lima's Plaza de Armas, the center is beautiful, and you can find everything you need there.

Cusco on our way to Machu. The city almost reminds me of an old timie ski resort, but filled with Peruvians and no snow. The architecture was amazing. Very european. There are LOTS of vendors trying to sell you stuff, but just ignore. They`re harmless. My husband and I took Diamox for altitude sickness days prior to the our Cusco trip when we were in Lima, and we did just fine. You do have to take it easy on your first day there as we did see MANY foreigners with oxygen masks at our hotel and half of them looked hung over. Getting to Cusco city center from the airport is relatively cheap. Probably around 20 soles. Don`t pay over 25. Once you get out of the airport, pass the people with the signs, you´ll be able to get a taxi. They say to only get the taxi with a radio sign on top....We did just fine with taxis with some sort of legit sign on top. We stayed at the Casa Andina Private collection in town (Excellent choice - highly recommended), and took it easy on the first day. Basically found the ministerio de cultura by our hotel near Av. Huascar; bought our machu entrance tickets. We ended up purchasing the package which included hiking up machu picchu mountain - $142 soles/ person. We purchased perurail tickets ahead of time in the states. Keep in mind when you go, don`t be surprised if they do a bimodal service where they have you take a bus from wanchaq station in cusco to panchar, then hook on the perurail there for the rest of your trip. We walked around the square, admired buildings, people watched, of course had a beer at the highest irish pub in the world, paddy´s pub, then took a NAP! Next day was machu picchu and prepare yourself to get to the station by 5:45am for the trip. MP will be in another review, but will worth the trip. We had one more day in Cusco after MP so we decided again to take it easy as MP mountain kicked our butts. Took a class at the chocolate museum. It was really really cool. for $70 soles /person, you get a two hour class where they teach you all about the origin of the cacao plant, and you go through almost the entire process of making your own chocolate which you get to keep. VERY worth it. The old city charm of Cusco definitely wins over Lima.

Starbucks on the Plaza. Cusco is a beautiful city. Lots to see just wandering around the streets. We never felt that it wasn't safe here even at night. Pedestrian beware though. The cars just don't stop for you! It was a treat to go to Starbucks in Cusco but their wifi was terrible and really, what else do you go for except the free wifi? The little alleys of San Blas and the marketplaces were clean and pretty. Except for the toll the altitude was taking on us I loved Cusco!

Cusco Inkas Empire!!!. If I want to visit Again Peru I would like to stay more days in Cusco city, because is very close city ,people are friendly. the history of this city is amazing I want to learn more things about the Inkas.Lucinda L.U.K.

Nice place to spend the day. We had an afternoon free from our tour and it gave us the opportunity just to walk and explore on our own. Churches, shops, restaurants, steps and park benches, everything you need to spend the day. The 17th century church on the northeast side is the one with the painting of The Las Supper, featuring guinea pig. Someone mentioned not being able to photograph inside so she didn't have photos to show her friends. When you pay for the tour they give you a recorded tour and when you turn it in there is a woman with a huge notebook full of postcards you can buy. I came home with a couple of dozen. This was a wonderful old church and am glad it had the extra guinea pig lure to bring me in or I might have missed it because our tour guide called it "expensive."

Main Catholic church. That is a must see sight. The portrait of the last supper with the visage of Pizzaro is stunning and having Cui on the table of the last supper is a great example of how the Inca artisans got bacck at the Christians for stamping out their entire culture.
A marvelous place yu have to see. I like everything, its a marvelous place with buildings of the Inca days mixed with buildings of the spanish tradition.A quiet place to walk and to dicover slowly.

Beautiful city. After a whirlwind tour of Peru in which it felt like we spent all of our time in a bus going from place to place, Cusco was a wonderful surprise. The historic center is lovely, and every day there were school groups practicing dance and parade routines for an upcoming event. We had so much fun in Cusco, but make sure to leave the main drag to experience the Mercado San Pedro! THAT is where you will truly see the essence of Cusco!

Excellent Excursion with BioAndean Expeditions. My girlfriend and I recently spent 2.5 weeks in Peru and we were desirous of taking a 5D/4N trek into the amazon jungle. We spent nearly a full day interviewing 8 different tour operators all across Cusco, with only a few blubs from a Lonely Planet book and a friend's recommendation from 4 years ago about an exceptional jungle guide named "Rider" to guide our search. The last tour operator with whom we spoke was BioAndean Expeditions, and coincidentally that exceptional jungle guide that our friend recommended to us turned out to be the owner of the company.What set BioAndean Expeditions apart from the other tour operators was their apparent honesty. They were very clear about pointing out the strengths & weaknesses of the various tour they offer (ie, which tours had the higher probability of seeing certain types of animals). Some other operators seemed to promise only the best outcomes for animal sightings (ie, Jaguar, tapir, capuchin monkey), whereas BioAndean specifically pointed out on a map where certain species were more or less likely to be seen. Besides their honesty, another thing that set BioAndean Expeditions apart from the other operators was that this was the first time speaking to an experienced jungle guide in the office; the other operators seem to only have sales people or bookkeepers available to answer questions about their tours, and who have clearly never led tour groups in the jungle. We booked a 5D/4N trip to Manu National Park, but the following week and within 24 hours of our departure BioAndean advised us that, despite being in the dry season, a sudden rain storm had damaged the main road leading into the park. In their words, "...the road may be cleared by tomorrow, but I'm hesitant to send you because if it's not open you could spend days stuck there, and instead of exploring the jungle you'd be worrying about how much time and money you've wasted." They offered to immediately refund our full deposit is cash, or setup a last-minute tour operated by a different company near Puerto Maldonado, an area of the amazon which hadn't experienced any rains. We let them setup the other tour in Puerto Maldonado, and we were glad we went, because it turned out to far exceed our expectations. Even though we didn't go on a tour operated by BioAndean Expeditions, I still appreciate their honesty and diligence setting up an alternative for us. I also do not write many TripAdvisor reviews, but I felt like going out of my way to write a review about BioAndean Expeditions. If you want a tour operator who will deal with you honestly, give them a try.

Amazing Place!. this place is awesome to check out, very colonial, rustic, cobble stone streets and gorgeous architecture dating from early inca times. Amazing atmosphere and beautiful sites to see! definitely a place to visit and check out!

Fun, lively spot. We spent an afternoon here, the day before heading to Machu Picchu. We happened to be in the main square on the first day of celebrations of the town's anniversary. The square was filled with adorable kindergarteners, singing and dancing in wonderful costumes! We had a delicious lunch at the Greens Restaurant, and shopped. We also visited the pre-Colombian museum, which was filled with amazing artifacts. The shop there featured beautiful and hand made items, and some of the profits go to local artisans.
Beautiful. Great place for shopping arts and crafts and have a nice homemade meal. With a lot of bars and restaurants. This is the trendy place to stay.

Too many vendors. Too many vendors disturbing you asking you to buy buy buy...when one leaves another comes...towards the end of my trip I was soo frustrated..I couldnt enjoy sitting there people watching with out interruption.

Wonderful, lively town. The historic centre is buzzing with people on their way to or from Machu Picchu. There are many restaurants and bars and places to see bands as well as dance the night away. Its a great place to meet like-minded travellers. Love it, and will definitely be back
cuzco city tour. valuable information, disliked the fact you can take pictures inside churches like in other important city of the world, can't show my friends about all the art and culture.
Fantastic!. Amazing experience, beautiful place. Dont miss the church and take a lot of pictures. I will recommend to visit the main square at night.

The heart of Cusco. Cusco's Plaza de Armas remember the spanish ones and, in this city, you find three churches and a lot of tourist, but good restaurants, plus come places to buy local stuff. While in Cusco, don't miss this square. It gets more beautiful at night

Must Visit and spend some time!. Many tourists visit Cusco as a stop-over to visit Machu Picchu - how sad!! Cusco is a beautiful, historic and most interesting city and deserves at least a four or five day visit (I could stay much longer). I recommend taking the double decker tour bus on the first day - to get oriented to the city. One can easily spend several days exploring the historic city center, The beautiful churches, interesting museums, the Plaza de Armas, the many cobbled street and wonderful small shops and restaurants of the San Blas Area (many artisan families have small shops here,) the San Pedro market and so on. Don't miss the Center for Traditional textiles if you are interested in higher quality weavings and supporting the artists that produce them. Buy a tourist ticket, and take a guided tour of the nearby ruins. Sacsayhuaman is a huge Inca complex on the edge of the city. If you have time visit the more distant ruins of Tipon, Pikillacta and Rumicolca (interesting day tour) and Pisac is a not to be missed day tour (for the great Inca ruins overlooking the town and for the much more touristy market). The Plaza de Armas is the main plaza is surrounded by beautiful buildings and is a wonderful place to sit and people watch. If you are lucky you might be there on a festival day when the square is the site of large parades, of military and of the townspeople from various indiginous communities, dressed in their unique clothing accompanied by various bands (military and indiginous). There are several peaceful plazas in the historic center.ideal for a rest and a coffee (or coca tea) during the explorations of the city. You can walk to pretty well all the historic center areas and we felt safe everywhere, but take the usual traveller precautions There is lots of tourist police presence.Peru is so much more than just Machu Picchu!
A breathe of fresh air. Peaceful Historic Center...leave your watch in your hotel, take your camera with you and just walk slowly. Get lost if you can, that's the best way to see the sights

Beautiful, fun and interesting!!!. I liked the cathedral the best, hands down, no doubt about it!!! Will never forget the inkan intepretation of "The Last Supper" and all the other beautiful paintings and statues inside. (will not spoil the surprise for you :) )
Not to be missed, the history of the Incan Empire will seem to come alive again!

The heart of a Great Empire - The soul of Peru. Q'osqo - Cusco -"Cuzco" was named by the Spaniards since they couldn't pronounce it well. Few years ago under pressure of the locals the "Z" was tanking out of Cuzco and replaced it with a "S" which it sounds closer to the real name.. CUSCO! - Cusco was the most sacred religious complex built by "Pachacutic" who's original name was Inka Yupanki second son of Viracocha whom won the battle against the Chancas neighboring predator tribe that it had placed eyes on the growing Inka territory. By Viracocha's time the Waris were assimilated already. Viracocha was getting old, didn't want to start a war nor even to defend his dear Q'osqo and run cowardly possibly to the Sanctuary of Machupicchu or Choquequiraou where he could hide and wait there to see for the outcome of the Chanca invasion... Inca Yupanki only 19 years old decide that he will defend the City and not let it fall into the hands of the enemies. As the history goes Inca Yupanki gather an army of the most capable man from his father's army and set to destroyed the Chancas. As the tale goes... by divine intervention where to believe that the stones became soldiers helped him won the battle, killed most of the Chancas (Abancay region) letting the few survivors scape to the near by mountains and some surrendered as well. Inka Yupanki then took all the spoils of this tribe went back to Cusco to present them to his father. Viracocha humiliated believing to be scorned by his son he did the same to him, his son enraged scolding his father named himself the new Inka ruler.It was a costume amongst Inka royalty in those days that only the CAPABLE, BRAVE and WISE will take or giving the maskaypacha (Crown - Tassel). The people will rightfully accept it or not. This time Inca Yupanqui in the eyes of his people was the chosen one. He reign lasted more than 60 years. It's said that he died at the age of 84 - 94?.Pedro the Cieza the Leon compares him to Alexander the Great.After wining the Chanca invasion changes arrived. He changed his name to PACHACUTEC which it means "The one that changes all". As his name describes, he change all (for the best) First of all made Cusco the religious center of one of the most grandiose Empire. He established and the most organized way of governing. Most surrounding tribes after seeing Pachacutic's success and how powerful the Inkas were getting, they voluntarily adjunct to the new growing kingdom.Tupac Yupanqui his brother a great worrier and Diplomat helped him to expand the Inka Empire very quick. Both were expert Diplomats and organizers. As the history goes the Tawantinsuyo Empire was won more by diplomacy then wars... Even though great bloody wars were fought Pachacutic had establish the rules. NO killing of woman (As he believed that woman were an extension of Mother Earth = Pachamama) nor children, neither destroying or killing for pleasure, not abusing or raping (or soldiers who did it will be killed on the spot) Not taking revenge. This according to him was going to be an Empire of people and without them there couldn't be an Empire. "We need them" was his words. And it was. An Empire of people, immensely rich, laborious, powerful and kind since reciprocity was a way of life. Still is amongst their direct descendents and in a way to the mestizos.Pachacutic believed that people was the best treasure ever.After his death the Empire was left on the hands of his brother Tupac Yupanqui followed by Wayna Capac his son continue to the expansion to how the Spaniards founded.When the Spaniards arrived Cieza expresses how easy and clear was for them to determine whether the place or land where they were belong to the Inkas or not.It is said that Cusco being the Religious center it become a wonder to it's own people and from the four corners of the Empire they will come in journey to visit. As the people passed each other on the road the ones who were entering Cusco will bow to the ones who will be leaving believing that in the soles of their sandals carry the dust of a such great City and blessing were exchanged with each other.The Sanctity of Cusco was very deep ingrain in the Inka Culture.To this day the indigenous people who still live up on the high planes of the Andes surrounding Cusco area still come dressed with their best attires the day of the Inty Rymi to salute and honor the cradle of one of the greatest civilizations that ever existed in the world. You can easily tell who is local and who has come from afar. Because of off what I say (wrote) I believe that Q'osqo it's a vassal of a deep positive energy. When you're there, you're certainly stepping right in the center of a Spiritual Sanctuary, think about how many of the Inka people from across great distances as you just did came here to carry with them this positive energy that emanates. I bow to you, give you my blessings and carry yours.
Well preserved historical monuments. Visiting the most important Colonial landmarks which in turn show so much of the pre-hispanic splendor, should be a must for each and every visitor.

So much history !!. What history !! - and that is not a question it is a fact. We allocated 2-3 hours to walk around and see the exhibits here but we were so entralled that we were there most of the day. The are some fantastic historical/archeological artefacts ranging from weapons, textiles, jewellry and so much more. Even the building housing the centre is a must see.
Lots to see. Different types of churches make interesting viewing. Three churches running into one with differing histories.

llama travel peru. LLAMA TRAVEL PERU 100% guarantees your trip for any day of the year! Departures are every day, we only need 2 people! travel departures from January to December 2010 Recommendations for a well organized trip, make your reservations well in advance "1,2,3 months" is recommended during the months of May, June, July and August, considered the high season for tourists to visit one of the seven modern wonders of the world Machu Picchu in Peru.

Visiting History. Visiting the historical center in Cusco was like a trip back in time. The square was lovely, surrounded by colonial Spanish churches, filled with benches and flowers. Being there was almost like taking a trip back thru time. It gave is the same feeling that visiting Bruges, Belgium did, only this was colonial Spanish and not Northern European.

Plenty to See - But Take A Guided Tour. There's history-a-plenty in Cusco, built as it is on the old Inca city, with later Spanish development. Best to take a guided tour which includes the outlying Inca sites to get a proper perspective. Choose a half-day one; whole day is overkill.

Beautiful Cusco. Cusco has several beautiful squares filled with churches and fountains that make exploring Cusco a must. Commercialism hasn't reached this city yet and the people of Cusco still sell their wares on the streets. Once you aclimatise then a walk around Cusco and exploring all those golden gilded churches is a must.

Gorgeous. But get used to the altitude before taking a long walk! Brilliant colonial architecture. Best museum is the one right next to Palacio Nazeraneas - not on the multi ticket but worth spending the money because it will blow you away. Marvellous artifacts beautifully presented.

Culture, culture and more culture. A fantastic setting at 3600 meters filled with cultural relics, wonderful architecture and an exotic people. Cuzco is in the foothills of Machupichu is just as impressive and aw inspiring. One of my favourite cities in the world.

great atmosphere. We only stayed in cusco for 2 days, 1 night. We wished we would have stayed at least 2 nights. The old centre has great character, is lively and has beautiful buildings. Ofcourse it is touristy but it still has it's character and local feel. We loved it! Stay at least 2 nights!(and try not to stay in agua calientes)
Colonial Spain. This town blends the beautiful Inca traditions with Colonial Spain. The historic centers have been beautifully maintained. The Cathedral is a GEM!

Charming tourist city in the Andes. Cusco is a charming tourist city that is the starting point for many Andean adventures. There are many Incan structures to explore, many shops selling the usual tourist stuff. Plenty of nice restaurants and hotels of varying quality.

Cusco, Peru. What any amazing, beautiful city. The historic center is a wonderful place to explore and felt safe! The citizens of Peru were friendly and so welcoming! I loved all the restaurants especially Greens! We stayed at the Novotel and the staff was wonderful and it was so conveniently located to the Plaza de Armas. Loved it!
It's just beautiful. It's full of tourist and stuff for tourist but on the same side it's just so beautiful... you can feel the magic of the city and the enrgy of the inkas... It's a must do
Lovely. Very beautiful, ancient, charming buildings,,, Good restaurantes, pretty squares... I just loved the Cocoa Museum, the Cocoa tea was so delicious!

"The city" to visit over and over again.. Walk in the middle of the Peruvian history is absolutely a dream......former Inca's Palaces, Spaniards houses and modern hotels......a great mix for a lovely city.

Website/phone here is for a tour company. Cuscocity.com is a private tour company. Do not confuse it with the actual city. Cusco is a great city, while the cuscocity.com, the tour company is a complete fraud with con artists. The company reps are all named Ed, Eduardo, Eddy, or Edward. Don't trust any of them. The promise of 48 hrs. tickets delivery never happened for our Machu Picchu tickets. Their excuses were: we went to the wrong hotel, the hotel said you were not guests there, the delivery man is stuck in traffic, or whatever lies Ed would make up to make you believe he is helping you. You would have better luck buying your train, bus,or tour tickets through the hotel/hostel you are staying at. The good reviews here are mostly for the city itself. Read the poor reviews here too. STAY AWAY FROM CUSCOCITY.COM.

A nice place. U pretty much are bound to walk by this a few times if u here for a few days and its really nice. Pretty busy so not s place to chillout at but ppl watching so on is really nice. Rest of reviews says the rest.

Great place of history mar by vendors. I enjoyed the amount of historical places in the historic center. Plenty of photo ops are in the plaza.Plenty of benches to sit and people watch.There are plenty of shopping, travel companies and dinning options in the area.Also easy to catch a taxi.The only thing that I hated was the number of vendors. Every few moments someone trying to sell something. While I understand that people are attempting to earn a living, it get tiresome saying "no thanks" every few moment.Non locals should be able to enjoy the historic center in peace
Cusco. Walking on the stoned streets and the city brings you to the ancient Inca culture. I visited some places around and really enjoyed my time. Food is just delicious!
Best touristic city in Southamerica. Sorry for making comparisons but you will agree by far if you had the chance to visit other places in South America.This city has it all to amaze you.

Cusco was Great. We spent a couple weeks in Cuzco. It was a great Hub for the Treks, Sacred Valley and Machu Picchu experiense. I highly recommend staying somewhere near the main Plaza de Armas. It was very safe and lots to do both day and night.

So beautiful... But mind the dog $h#T!!. Cusco is completely wirth wondering around; its Plaza is always full with people sharing a few moments, and the streets of San Blas are really typical. Most of all, the combination of Inka and colonial architecture makes this city unique.

Cuzco for ever. Cuzco has something you can not explain, you have to walk wonderful Cuzco and feel, enjoy, relax and dream ...Cuzco City is nice with lots of history, traditions, incredilbe Churches, and wondeful sky.. after you visit Cuzco you will have the sensation you travel to the pass, to history and if you have the chance to walk and meet a Chaman, a real Chaman...you will understand how incredible is this City.

Photo opportunity on every corner. You cant go wrong by starting your time in cusco here. They have even managed to slightly disguise the KFC, McDonalds and Starbucks. Its fairly safe to wonder around the cobbled streets. The odd pickpockets. If you get annoyed by all the offers for lunch and a massage then head to the market where you can pick up grilled trout for 2 soles. Good tourist information and ATM on the left side of the square (if facing the cathedral).

Relaxed, fun atmosphere. Cusco is a town where everyone seemed to be having a good time. Prior to arriving, I was worried about crimes against tourists; I arranged for a private tour of the historic area, as I was traveling solo. But once there, I felt very safe. I went out solo after dark to the Plaza de Armas feeling very comfortable (but alert). There streets are well lit, people are out tending to business or being tourists, and the police are everywhere in the tourist areas. The historical sites are well worth the visit. I like Cusco, and would like to return
Fantastic!. Cusco is a must see as a precursor to a visit to macchu Pichu. The atmosphere, the people, the food - all were exceptional.
Unesco Heritage City. A must see for its churches, cathedrals, markets and local color all around. Lots of interersting day trips to do from Cusco.

Loved it!. We loved Cusco and all it's historic streets and nearby attractions. We stayed for five days and could have easily spent much longer. I enjoyed the Cathedral, the cobblestone streets, the markets and the historic square. There are lots of good bars and restaurants to try out and an endless list of nearby ruins to visit. We explored Cusco on foot and really enjoyed it. I would love to return someday.
Very worth visiting!. The main square of Cusco with it's cathedral and golden statue is well worth visiting! It's one of the most beautiful city plazas that we've ever seen.

Very Expensive. It's a nice city and a must visit if you plan to go to Machu Picchu. Cathedral is good - you can climb up the tiny stairs in the cathedral and see the view of the Plaza from up there. Pretty good.But I liked Lima better. It's more of a real city. Cuzco is just a tourist city and you better a lot of USD. Outside of the Cuzco downtown area and the San Blas area, the cobble stone streets, there's nothing much. Local people only work in this area and they don't or maybe cannot afford to shop here. I only saw people who looked like tourists and everything here is catered to tourists. Even the restaurant was playing nba basket ball match at the TV in the Bar.If you plan to take the train to Machu Picchu, then it's a good area to stop by to get acclimatized to the altitude. Spend a day to get used to it.

Loved Cusco!. I had been before but my husband and teenage daughter were new to South America and Cusco offers just the right mix of the exotic and the different but with a relaxed, safe feel. Plenty to see and do (not to mention the shopping) with good restaurants and bars and good excursions close to the city. If time is short, skip the night in Lima and connect straight here. Top tip : we all took the prescription drug Diamox to counter the affects of altitude and none of us suffered so do talk to your GP - it could prevent nasty altitude sickness.

Great place. Cusco has lots of places to visit ,the cathedral is one of them, because when you are inside , you feel like the time has stopped . The atmosphere is amazing, the pictures and the saints transport you to ancient times.Besides this , don t forget to visit San Blas , just round the corner : ) it is a place where you can find beautiful souvenirs , clothes made of wool like sweaters and ponchos and other things that are really eye catching. You will be satisfied.
Magnificent. Brilliant blue skies, historic colonial architecture, and the Andes encircling all. The center for much activity in this historic city.

Nice but. I didn't like the city that much. I loved Arequipa for example.People are so used to American tourists that they don't tell you prices in soles, only dollars!!! Only place in Peru where it happened! Even the doctor who visited me when I got sick gave me the price in dollars! Seriously, I'm telling you I am not American and the thing that amazed me the most is that they don't even know the conversion!Apart from this, Cuzco is a city you visit in one - two days max. The most beautiful things to see and do are out of town, Pisac, Sacred Valley etc.
Misterious place. Cusco was a great place to visit! All the historical center is fantastic! Churches, houses, restaurants, even the cars buzzing all the time are understandable.
Well preserved. One of the most beautiful centro historicos I've seen, but it does get overwhelmed with tourists in high season. Still, if you're in Peru, it would be foolish not to visit.

Lots to see and do - if you like churches. Really beautiful City centre with churches and convents on every corner. The Spanish make a good job of wiping off the Inca, but you may be surprised - they are making a come back :-)

What makes Cusco a desirable and dreamed destination?. I guess among others is the historic center. very seldom you find such a combination of history, art, beautiful people and streets in such a small place. Is not Paris nor Rome but it has its charm and magic. I loved the narrow streets, the multitude of old churches and old art. Peru at its best is Cusco! Go for it!

Nice. Interesting architecture and conjunction of colours. The historic center has many museums to visit and also many restaurants where you can eat and rest before continuing your walk. However, be aware that many peruvians will try to sell you all sorts of things and they will be very persistent at times.

Viva el peru. My husband and I took a walk one evening to the square. It was amazing, we took photos bought little trinkets and listened to sound of everyone and everything. I can't wait to go back again.
A must. The Plaza de Armas is the heart of historic Cusco, but the further away you get, the less harassed by vendors you'll be.

wonderful city square. We loved the city square and the good restaurants in this city.The cathedral is very impressive and a must to see it inside.Don't buy a very expensive ticket for everything. We bought several tickets at the entrance and had a great time without spending a fortune.Go to the market and stroll around.

Beautiful city ..... This city is a must to visit. Lots of churches, shops, restaurants.. can you spot the Starbucks? Disappointed in their pizza, not as good as it looks. If this is your fist time in Cusco, do not overdo it the first day you arrive, relax, rest and take it slowly so you can get adjusted to the altitude!

Beautiful town. Very inexpensive. Definitely check out the main Cathedral in the Plaza de Armas. I didn't check out the other ones, but this one did not disappoint. And definitely use the headset (no charge, just some ID to hold for ransom).

One of the world's great ancient city centres.
