Cusco (or Cuzco) existed before the meteoric rise of the Incas in the late 15th century as a Killke settlement, but it was totally transformed when they rose to dominance in the southern Andes. Cuzco became the Inca capital, at which point the whole centre was rebuilt in what is amongst the world's finest masonry. The central square (Plaza de Armas) is the hinge point for the town, surrounded by endless gloomy Spanish architecture built on the remains of Inca buildings. The original architecture is more visible a block or two behind the square. The whole area is under World Heritage protection and is unspoiled...although if you look closely you will spot McDonalds, Starbucks and KFC in heavy disguise. There are cafes and bars in profusion all around, and a plethora of reasonably priced hostels in Calle Suecia and elsewhere towards the west (behind the tourist information). There are also a lot of souvenir sellers, but everything is overpriced so the smart money tends to go towards the market area towards the southwest. For some reason there are endless pizzerias around the square - not terribly Peruvian, although guinea pig and the like can also be found.

Sweet Travel Peru. I booked the Cusco Night Tour with Sweet Travel Peru and had a wonderful experience. I had very limited time in Cusco with only one afternoon and night to explore the city before flying to Arequipa. As a solo female traveler, I was concerned about safely exploring the city alone, especially at night. The tour guides (a married couple who also happen to be the owners of the company) helped me to make the most of my short stay in the city and their company eased my safety concerns. We stopped at a number of the main sites and even went to a cultural show with traditional dancing. I would absolutely recommend communicating with Sweet Travel Peru (sweettravelperu.com) while planning your trip to Peru. They always responded to my emails within a business day and helped me to organize a very rewarding, yet economical trip to Cusco. -Kim, February 2013

Great service and support from CuscoCity. We had a great time at Cusco and Macchu Picchu, primarily due to a great service and great help from Eduardo from CusciCity - he helped us in organizing all required tickets and documents. And when our train was forced to cancel the journey due to landslides, he organized new tickets and a hotel for us for free (!!!!) in only half an hour - fabulous!! Would strongly recommend to use their services!

Great relaxing place. Cusco I guess is used as the gateway to Machu Picchu and Lake Titicaca and allows you to acclimatise to the altitude. We found Cusco alive and fun, the Plaza De Armas was the focal point of the town and where it all happens. Restaurants, Travel agents, Tours, Coffee shops, Bars, Cathedrals, Museums and more....The locals will try and sell you there tourist wares, but you can politely say no if not interested.Great Place, love it.
Educational. Very interesting. You will be fascinated with the historical explanations. Visit the different museums around.

First class Historical Centre. This centre presents a strong historical perspective of the Cusco area and its historical significance. We found this an excellent starting point to understand all of the history and the depth of the archeological work around Cusco and on to Machu Picchu. You really begin to understand how wonderful the building works and the establishment of cities in these remote civilizations was.It is hard to appreciate how so much was achieved and its significance in the whole South american continent. Treasures to be preserved and valued. A most worthwhile visit.
What a wonderful city. To visit Cusco was really worth the travel. It is a lovely old city with a wonderful atmosphere. It is absolutely a must to visit.

A must see on any tour of Peru. So many historic and beautiful buildings, a beautiful wide open square with trees, gardens, etc. Buildings facing the square mostly have wooden carved balconies (Spanish/Moorish influence). Lots of character. Felt very safe here. Similar to Arequipa but bigger with more to see.

Nice surroundings. Its clean,nice arranged with the cathedrals arround.Many flowers,safe with many policemans arround.Alos most of the restaurants,souvenir shops,agencies are arround here.You can sit on bench and enjoy

Picturesque green squares. I really enjoyed walking round and taking in the beautiful churches and admiring the inca influences around the historic centre. Plaza des armas was especially beautiful with a good museum, and plenty of restaurants and plenty of souvenir shops (albeit overpriced). I managed to get a picture with ladies in traditional Peruvian dress holding a really cute baby llama.

Inca and Spanish Tumble over Each Other. There is nothing about Cusco to dislike--except the altitude. And one gets used to that. From the Plaza de Armas to side streets where building foundations are still Inca walls, to the excellent food, to the museums. Cusco is a feast for all the senses.
Fabulous colonial city on Inca roots. Wonderful vibe. Good shopping, though got a bit fed up being approached by people wanting to sell things on the street - but at least they are not too pushy.
A nice town. Cusco is really a nice town, we went there when there was a street dance a few days after Inti Raymi. Every region has a team who danced on the street during almost 2-hour parade.
Lovely city. Okay, it is crawling with tourists, but most of the main areas have been restored to show the city in all its glory.

Colonial Spain Built on Incan Ruins. The center of Cusco is a place worth staying a few days. Once the capital of the Incan empire, it is now a classic Spanish colonial city, built on the ruinas of the Incan structures that once were there. Most shops, churches, hotels and hostels are gathered around the number of public squares, all an easy walk from each other. Cusco is busy, the launching place for visits to Macchu Picchu, with the highest concentration of tourists. Hence, an abundance of shops to cater to tourists. The street vendors are plentiful and insistent. Try lunch or coffee in one of the second level restaurants. The view is great and the vendors usually don't venture upstairs.
First Inca Ruins. Marvelous museum and ruins. Make sure to get a good guide who understand the Ina background and history.

Cusco. Cusco is a huge tourist centre but does not really feel like it. Always lots of people (including hundreds of tourists) around but we never felt crowded, except during the Inti Raymi Festival, and we never felt any threat, even when the power went off and the streets were dark. So much to see and do and to experience that we kept as busy as we wanted to for the whole two weeks that we were there.

beautiful old city. It is a disgrace that the new Bishop of Cusco decided to charge such expensive entrance fees to churches that once were open to all.....The Catholic Church in Cusco is not lacking finances considering that owns a large portion of the historical building and that rents them out very handsomely(like the Hotel Monasterio...).
Fascinating but crowded with many people touting. Always something going on with lots too observe. Pick a post at the window of one of the 2nd floor restaurants and enjoy the scene.
Very interesting. Sights and sounds of Peru abound in the center. There are many churches and museums. The markets are particularly wonderful along with the flowers in the center plazas.
cobblestone calles. Just a fantastic setting with people enjoying it all hours. The streets/plazas are just divine as are the buildings in particular the cathedral and churches.

Beautiful. Its a magic place! Its amazing how the Incas worked the stone. The Cathedral is amazing. The Spaniards build over the inca construction, every street has somethin spectacular, just walk arround...

As a non-religious person , it's amazing to see the churches. They shear wealth on display at the churches is mind-boggling. It's hard to compare, even most European churches had not managed to acquire such wealth from its believers.
Easy. Cusco is not a big town and the historic centre is small, but it makes up for it in quality and the setting
Nice square. This is a large area in the center of the town, where the main cathedral is located. Their is a nice park and shops to explore.
its a very beautiful architecture with a lot of great stories. The center of the city is all renovated and it has great architecture, cobbled stones streets and a lot of different buildings to visit.

Spectacular. The center of the city is beautiful and very well kept, the ruins of Korikancha Temple are impressive , the church is on the inside incredible rich and jewelry work and paintings, a pitty not to be able to take pictures

Enjoyed the show. We really enjoyed the dancing and costumes at the historic center. It was a nice way to spend the evening. We walked from Hotel Monasterio to the historic center for the show and it was a nice walk in September.
World Class. Cusco is a gem of a place to visit. There are lots of things to do and the food there is great, hard to go wrong. Must sees are the San Pedro market and the chocolate museum.
A Very Lively And Busy Place. The area was full since they had a parade lined up on Sunday. There were uniformed soldiers, nurses students. I liked the architecture. People were friendly.

peruvacationtours.com. I do not have a great appreciation for Catholic cathedrals due to the churches part in the destruction of the new world. However, the 3 cathederals are amazing. The gold & silver, the spanish colonial are are impressive. The museums are very well done. They are worth going through.

Cusco - Very pretty and historic city. If you plan on visiting Machu Picchu, you will be going through Cusco which was the capital city of the incas and is a very pretty city with its 2 cathedrals in the main square and the Inca architected stones forming its foundation. You can take day trips from Cusco and visit nearby inca ruins as well.

Be Prepared. This is a nice place to sit, enjoy the views and people watch, but be prepared to be bombarded with sales people. In 10 minutes time, my wife and I were approached by 14 people that wanted to sell us something.

Plenty to see and do. Very easy to spend all day wandering around taking in the sights, sounds and smells. Far too many hawkers and beggars, but then this is a big tourist area. Plenty of 'must do' things in the city and surrounding area. Visit San Pedro market or the artisans market at the bottom of Avenida del Sol to avoid getting ripped off for souvenirs

Marvels of the Inca and colonial times. Cusco offers a great deal to see in a relatively compact space, from the remains of the outstanding construction techniques of the Inca era to the more ornate, if less resilient, Spanish colonial architecture. We even caught the weekly Sunday parade in the Plaza de Armas to give a flavour of Cusco life.

Beautifull. The city of Cusco is so well preserved, it is an amazing city! The square with TWO churches is great and also the musea are impressive...such a good city to stay before AND after your trip to Machu Picchu!
Pretty. Colonnial Style architecture, food is amazing in Cuzco and Lima. People is also very helpful and nice.

Stay and look here too. So many people go to Cusco and go straight to Urumbamba or Machu Picchu, but we spent a very pleasant day in Cusco itself. The cathedral was nice and we really enjoyed the Pre Columbian Art Museum.
Beautiful squares and Cathedral. There were several squares around Cusco, all very pretty. We also went to the Cathedral and Mercado San Pedro.
Beautiful. The Plaza de Independencia, cathedral and churches are very nice. Be prepared to walk up and down hills!
Turning a page of history. I thoroughly enjoy walking in the streets of this amazing town. Streets which still vibrate with the energy of the Incas, and reverberate with the invasion of the Spanish.

My Favorite Walking City of the Americas. I love this city. Little has changed since my first visit in 1973. The city has grown up to the edge of the valley, but the city's center is unchanged. Magnificent churches with art that tells the history of the city. Origional inca streets and walls. And fresh air. Bargain in the shops. Shopping here is so much fun. Try the peruvian restaurants. Try the Aussie Bar. There is so much to do here. But remember, the altitude here is higher than Machu Picchu. A trip here is timeless.
Nice walkable square. There are lots of restaurants in this area. The church is interesting but very much like others. You need a guide to really appreciate the area.

try some "cuy"!. Red buildings, towers of churches and the famous Incas walls create the unique and beautiful place. You can walk the streets for hours and discover new things. When you feel tired you can try some local specialities, like "grilled cuy" (guinea pig) or "cusquena" a very good bear, popular in all the country, still in Cusco it tastes best (I recommend the dark one)

Lovely old city to wander around in. Decided against an organised tour and just wandered around by ourselves exploring the alleyways and enjoying the sights and sounds of Cusco. There was a lot going on and it was a pleasant way to relax and soak in the atmosphere. We enjoyed coffee in one of the small cafes on the Calle Marquez before visiting the central market. There is a wide range of restaurants to fit all pockets and we found everyone to be very friendly and helfpul. It felt very safe. The altitude does take it out of you so take your time.

Cuzco Center. Beautiful colonial city. We visited the cathedral and so many magnificent churches. The San Francisco museum was excellent. Very safe to walk, even late at night. People are very nice. Good restaurants too.

Historical charm. Cusco is a beautiful city in the Sacred Valley full of ancient buildings and lots of historical charm. The main square is vibrant with numerous small curiosity shops, great restaurants and good cafes and bars.
A lot to see and discover. Cusco Historic Center is a unique gem. I would recommend to take at least 3 days to visit its wonderful churches.

Unexpected beauty. Flying into Cusco is a thrilling site. Just when you think there will be no where to land a jet with all the mountains around, a bowl of a city opens up and you fly down into the city.
worth the walk around. cuzco is small and easy to walk around, which is just as well because you'll have less energy at this altitude

an interesting city to explore. We enjoyed walking around the streets and visiting the catherdral and some churches.The city retains its Andean atmosphere. Inca architecture can still be seen though the centre is now filled with Spanish squares and arches. The effects of earthquakes can be seen in the structures. From the Plaza de Armas (Main Square) we took an open top bus tour of the city .(Looks like a scaled down version of a red London Bus) and we found this a fun trip and informative. Its an inexpensive trip, lasts about one hour twenty mins and takes you around the city and up to the inca military site at Sacsayhuaman overlooking Cusco. Lots of good restaurants to choose from providing a variety of cuisine . (We were very surprised to see McD's and KFC !! ).
Amazing. It was a surprise for me to see how "cosmopolitan" this city can be.People around the world is there, the acitude is the best.
Pretty, But .... Beautiful buildings, but noisy, congested, crazy as Hell drivers, sometimes dirty. It does not compare to the smaller serene Antigua Guatemala.
The Navel of the World. 500 years of history in the architecture and museums. Alsway felt safe walking around, even late at night.

Enchanted city. Cuzco is one of the most beautiful cities in Peru, and its center is beautiful! it is very well preserved, with stoned floors and amazing architecture. It is a pity that it has become so "touristish" that can be annoying. In most hotels you have to pay in dollars and the food is very expensive and not nice. For the local tourist it is just to expensive to visit it. Tourism has without a doubt helped the economy of the city, however it has its down side as well.

Like stepping back into time. The Cusco city center is very beautiful and the combination of Inca sites with colonial mansions on top is very unique. We also really loved San Blas and the central market

so much to see and do. Loved just walking around exploring the streets and plazas. Drink plenty of coca tea to help with the headaches. Colourful costumes, Inca stones, cafes, craft shops. Look for the fairtrade shop and the traditional crafts centre.

Inca and Spanish civilisation. If you like history, and particularly south america history, Cusco Historic Center is a place where you must go. Both culture are mixed and the city still have all the heritage of the old days of colonization. The places and churches are in very good shape. The people of Cusco is very friendly and the average prices at Peru is very good.

A Charming city. The feeling been there is something you have to experience, it's close to so many historical sites, at the back you'll see the beautiful glaciers, visit the cathedral enjoy the arquitecture.

best place to be . seen and been seen. just go up an enjoy the view, almost all the restaurants in the area surrending the plaza de armas , have a second floor and a balcony.. and for god's sake dont eat at burger king, mc Donalds bembos or startbucks leave that for the locals 9they done know what are they doing!
Looks like an european city. Very nice place. City clean, organized and very safe, with many entertainment options. Many historical buildings everywere.

Beautiful and lively. Cusco historic center is an intriguing and stunningly beautiful place. Full of interesting Inca and colonial buidings, its location in the highlands of Peru surrounded by mountains is just amazing. The preservation of the area has been successful and apart from the unobtrusive Starbucks, MacDonalds and KFC, the Irish pubs and the trinket stores it still feels that you have stepped back in time. We thought it was one of the most beautiful cities we have ever been to.
So authentic.. We were really surprised at the wonderful condition of all the historical sites and how many original buildings there are. Loved it!

a good tour guide. You need a really good tour guide who can explain the myths and reality about this ancient city. I suggest Edgard Mendivil, who lectures at the local university and loves his subject.

beautiful but vendor infested. The city centre is beautiful and well worth the visit - I especially liked the walk up to st.Blas. It did however have this feeling of deja vue somewhere in Europe for me, not quite as exotic and unique as some other places in Peru. But on the other hand - it definitely was better kept and orderly than many other places. It also has street vendors that are clingier than anywhere else in Peru - you could not stop or sit down for a minute without one of them targeting you. They also would just not go away after a clear no, but hang on and keep pestering you. So stepping outside the centre was sometimes relief. Still central enough, but more down to earth was plaza San Francisco and area beyond it - on Sunday the local people where gathering there for entertainment that was quite interesting to observe.
Love Cusco. It is such a beautiful city. The center square is one of the picturesque in the world. The cathedral is beautiful and the restaurants and action in the square at night is a lot of fun.

Cobblestone streets and terracotta rooves. The centre of cusco is a masterpiece! The main square is surrounded by breathtaking building and the garden is immaculately maintained. It is an extremely picturesque spot and great for wandering fairly safely. An annoyance is the abundance of people trying to sell things in the street. Normally a firm 'no' will stop the hassling, but it the constant bombardment is quite frustrating when trying to take in the lovely setting.
I fell in love with Cusco. Amazing city with lots to see and do and within easy reach of many Inca ruin sites. Absolutely fascinating place. I cannot wait to go back.

Short trip to Machu Picchu. Vistadome train is clean with comfortable leather seats and complimentary service of a snack and drink. It's only 1-1/2 hours from the Sacred Valley, so sit back, relax and take pictures as you wander the canyon on the train! All trains are always on time also and you need passport to board.
Wonderful walks!. This is a charming city with a fascinating history dating back to pre-Inca times. Lots to see and do.

You cannot miss this scenary. Love the Cusco Historic center, it is the best way to get involved with the Inca culture, the arquitecture, the silver jewlery, please cannot miss all that. We found a smal MacDonald to supply any american need...love it!!!!

So much to see!. We loved the Historic Center, with its small shops, cathedrals, Inca buildings, Colonial churches, etc etc etc. And the restaurants around the plaza were all so very good! Peruvian food from the region is simply exquisite, and I would love to come back just to keep trying those delicious dishes!We walked around the main square at night and felt safe all the time. And during the day, it's so nice to just sit on the benches surrouding the plaza to enjoy the sights.

did not lost on fastinating athmosphere. I have been in Cusco 19 years ago and it is still a very charming and very energizing city, it is still the 'ombligo' of Peru and enjoyable city, there is so much to see in this old town with the Inca and Spanish culture mixed both and going to the Sacred Valley and doing tours around Cusco.It is a place for everybody, it can be explored easely walking around.
Lots to do around. You can find great restaurants, clubs, supermarket, pharmacy, money exchange, and more. Main meeting point in case you get lost, it is very easy to access.

Fascinating, fascinatng city. Looks a little like San Fran with the hills (no bay) and a little like an European ci.. Altitude sickness commonly happens. My youngest son got sick the first day we were is Cusco with a headache and stomach ache (common signs of altitude sickness.) Adjust by going to Sacred Valley first or get a room in a hotel with oxygenated rooms.

Very good information. A fantstic array of information and relics, the guides are so informative and speak good english. You can also watch a video of how the incas lived. The building is clean, bright and wonderful painting of places in the area. You would need another suitcase to bring home all the copies of things you see.
Loved Cusco. We spend two days in Cusco and I regret we didn't stay longer. The historic center is very interesting, except for Machu Picchu this was the best site in Peru.
No war scars. it was lovely walking and driving through such an old city with no new buildings as the old was preserved

Frustratingly touristy -- don't spend more than 1 day here. I had high expectations for Cuzco after reading online reviews and guidebooks where people talked about getting out of Lima as fast as possible and heading for the calm, beautiful city of Cuzco. Yes, Cuzco is an attractive city, and it looks magnificent from high atop the hills. But Cuzco itself is THE most touristy place I've ever been in my life.There's nothing authentic or genuine about Cuzco -- it's about as real as Las Vegas. Every storefront is either an over-priced restaurant catering to tourists, an over-priced tour company or an over-priced souvenir shop. Where are all the businesses and restaurants that must have existed 10 or 20 years ago that made this place so popular? At least when you got a touristy place like Prague or Paris or London, there's a mix of shops catering to tourists but also real shops that real locals visit. That doesn't exist in the center of Cuzco. I have no clue where the locals shop or eat, but it must be in the outlying districts.Sure, the facades of the old, long-standing buildings look cool, but when you have a Starbucks inside that building, it takes away the authenticity of what probably made Cuzco great before big businesses took it over.Really the worst part about central Cuzco is the unrelenting onslaught of touts that beg for your business. You can't walk five feet without someone jumping in front of you to sell you something or get you to come into their restaurant. We had one guy literally run full speed across the square just to show us his menu. We also had a young girl trying to sell knick knacks sit on a bench with us and not leave, persistently bugging us to buy stuff; when we said "no gracias" she aggressively responded "si gracias" and shove things at us to buy. That's right, you can't even sit on a bench for a few moments without touts harassing you. It's frustrating and suffocating. I get it, they're poorer and know that tourists have money to spend, but it's such a turnoff.Then you've got to worry about the people who charge you for services you didn't ask for. As we were walking down a street, a guy pointed out the famous 12-cut stone we were looking for. He asked a few questions like "do you know why it has 12 stones?" and he would provide answers. After a quick picture, we were starting to walk away when he jumped in front of us and said, "aren't you going to pay me for my services?" The guy told us a couple of facts we didn't ask for, but he was helpful enough, so I handed him a 1 sole tip. He looked at me insulted and stamped away. I took a 6-hour tour of the city for 15 soles, I think 1 sole for 3 minutes of his time that I didn't ask for is more than fair.We really regret staying in Cuzco for three days. You can see everything the city has to offer in a full day tour that takes you to the Cathedral, Coricancha and ruins outside of town. Even a few hours in San Blas is nice, much calmer and quieter. But the lack of authenticity and the bombardment of touts really put a damper on our experience. We had much more fun in Arequipa and Puno and the people were much nicer and genuinely friendly.I'm honestly shocked by all the positive reviews of this place because when we talked to other visitors (mainly Europeans), they were just as putoff but Cuzco as we were.I'd hate to see what the center of Cuzco will become in 10 years, but I wouldn't be surprised if it's overrun with KFC's and Chase banks and probably another Starbucks across the square.

Tips on Cusco tours. Three of the tours we (father, 60 and daughter, 30 - both in good health) have experienced:1. City tour: we got to see the cathedral (1,5 hour visit), the Coricancha Temple of the Sun (1 hour visit), Sacsahuaman, Kenko, Puca-Pucara and Tambomachay. All tours start at the cathedral and take all afternoon. If you are interested in seeing al these places and learning about the details, a guided trip is the best option. To our opinion the cathedral visit was to long and detailed, Kenko/Puca-Pucara and Tambomachay are ok but would prefer Moray, Picay and Salinas over it. (booked though the Hotel Rumi Punku)2. Mountainbike tour Moray and Salinas: Definitely places to visit, not as touristy as the one´s located at 1. and to our opinion more interesting. Tour is beautiful but quite tough for those that are not used to biking/ get scared easliy. The main part of the trip is steep or rocky. But: you get the best views, go through towns and countryside that is not invaded by tourism yet. (booked throught the Hotel Rumi Punku)3. Sacred valley: We did a roundtrip one day trek from and to Ollantaytambo that was part of a 3 day tour (including Machu Picchu) booked via CAT (located in the avenida Sol). You climb from 2800 m up to 4000 and get breathtaking views of the sacred valley. Perfect for those who have not been able to get tickets for the Inca Trail or prefer to do just a one day trek. The company was very focused on safety and provided the best box lunch ever!
Cuzco center. The city is full with history and we enjoyed the information we got from the center in English.
Beautiful plaza. Historic buildind set amoung quaint shops, restaurants, and hotels.
A lot of places to visit. Walk..walk... and walk... every corner have something to say... Do not forget to see the 12 corners stones... the big market.. etc...

Very Historical. Beautiful museums and churches. Take a map with you.
If you attend a mass you do not have to pay to enter the churches.
Informative. Especdially good for people like us who do not know a lot about the history and culture of Peru.
world's most beautiful city!. you juste have to go there, stay, look around and feel the special ambiance and heart beat of this city. Unique in the world!
Worth the walk. This is a good way to see the Inca architecture and how the Spanish reused it.

Best city center in Peru. Cusco is beautiful and its historic center is magnificent. The mix of Inca and colonial buildings is really inspiring. So many things to see you need several days, not counting the sacred valley tour and machu picchu

Good base for exploration. Some interesting sites (Hatunmiroc, the cathedral, Sacsayhuaman) and a convenient place to stay while exploring the Sacred Valley, but I agree with other reviewers -- we got pretty jaded after having so many people come after us to sell us postcards, paintings, massages, etc. Even the kids come after you for shoe shines (I'm not sure how they were planning on shining my Gore-tex hiking boots...). Other than that, Cuzco is worthwhile to visit for its amazing history and architecture.
nice but .... if you make the tour is nice to see but i had more exxpectations though they paid of visiting and enjoying cusco city in general from food to museum to artists street...
Great place to wander. Cusco is a great place to wander and people watch. The amount of people badgering you to buy does get a bit annoying, even waiting to pounce outside hotel doors!
What a city. When you are in the midle of this city it is not difficult to image how it was more than 500 years ago. Absolutely worth a visit.
Interesting sites. Worth seeing but lots of vendors selling postcards, paintings, trinkets etc. This distracts form the experience.
Cusco is great. The only problem is the people offering you everything constantly. That's anoying.
hmm...ok. when you buy the multi sites pass, this is included. the dancing show could have been better. we went in june and it was freezing in the little auditorium!!
interesting. it,s a must!gives you an in sight how the people lived, their culture &their craftmanship from pottery to weaving !from stone work to metal work in weapons & jewelry. another must,

Very nice to walk around. Historic center was very nice, everything around it was not. But if you stay within the ceter you will have a fabulous time. Many good restaurants and bars and if you need a good coffee, there is always a Starbucks.
Historic center. well worth a visit, helps to provide a background to the sights of Cusco and the sacred valley
Interesting stroll. Interstong centre even if a lot of people try to sell you souvenirs continuously
Nice but touristy. Nice old buildings, unfortunately the Spanish desptroyed much of the original Inca structures. Loads of tourists and hence tourist prices.
Very nice. If tou're coming from Bolivia it will be a small paradise of organization and beautifulnes
Interesting architecture. Just fun to walk around and see the various buildings and the people in different native costumes.

Fantastic city center!. We spent a couple of days in Cusco before going to Machu Picchu Inca Trail and we had a great time! We decided to walk all over the historic center instead of doing another 1-day city tour that most of the operators suggest; and we didn't regret it! The historic center has a surpise in every corner! Beautiful buildings, nice cobbled streets, great plazas with beautiful plants. Municipality of Cusco seems to be doing a very good job!It's a special place and they have preserved it very well indeed!

A wonderful historic town centre. We just lived wandering the streets of the historic centre of Cusco with its Occassional Inca walls, cobbled streets, great churches, markets and innumerable small interesting shops. Cusco is not just a stop on the way to Machi Picchu but a fantastic destination in its own right.
cathedral. Very good audio guide for the cathedral .... Really worth it
Cute. So beautiful....everything is so special....totaly worth.
charming city. I loved walking around, people watching, taking in the busy streets. It's a lot of fun.

By all means, stay in the center!. Cusco is a sprawling, virtually third-world city of 350,000 people. It can take an hour by car to get across town. Except for the historic core area, it is an unlovely (to be kind) city. To enjoy it the most, pick a hotel in the center near the Plaza de Armas or in San Blas. Anything farther afield will yield long walks/rides through unpleasant, perhaps dangerous, surroundings. The core, on the other hand, is lively and attractive, with some of the best food I have ever experienced in a town this size. At 11,000 feet, altitude sickness can be a MAJOR issue.
Loved to know about the Incas. It was great to know about the history and cultural background of the Incas

A city for at least a weak vacation. Markets, real art, surrounding, great food with good prices. Nice people. Skip the folklore dance center - it simply a shame, I am sure that there are way more serious dancers than this place offer in Cusco.
City Center. It was a nice place to walk around in. The Plaza de Armas is a great place to bring a book and relax while taking in the crowd.
Nice relaxing place. I liked all the streets upwards, looks of the people, very colourful clothes. Cheap shoppig.
A walkers paradise. I spent time everyday walking around the historic centre of Cusco
Fascinating. The Colonial Cusco tour is well worth it, starting at the convent across the road from the Libertador Hotel and finishing in the high countryside amidst spectacular Inca ruins.

nice city tour in cusco. we booked this tour with a small company around the main square in Cusco i paid 60 soles for a sharing tour included bus, guide and buffet luch. i tried to book this tour from abroad and some companies wanted to charge me 80 dollars for the same standard of service that i had, so this tour you can book it once you arrive to cusco, do not waste your money doing it from abroad.

Still Beautiful - Bit of a Tourist Trap. Lots to see in Cusco - and many many photo ops. However, the town is a bit of a tourist trap and you won't be able to see much without fighting the throngs of massage hawkers, trinket salespeople, tchotchke shops and restaurant traffickers. This was a little disappointing, but there are a few quiet plazas here and there to sit and enjoy the commotion around you and, if you're an early riser, you can briefly feel like you have the town to yourself. Then the hustle and bustle starts all over...
So much to see and experience. Loved Cusco! Friendly, safe, lots to see and do. Recommend quite a few days to see the place and experience Cusco.

A constrast. Constant badgering to buy- they are persistent- they will even expect cash for a photo.Each Sunday in the square they have a parade (around 9.30)-colourful, interesting and worth seeing. Get the balcony on the first floor Starbucks store for the best views

Cusco is a very interesting city in the sky. I loved my visit to the historic center. Cusco is a fascinating city and a major site for the Inca ruins. The shopping and dining were great and the historic buildings very interesting.

Really a place to stay. I believe this city is one of the most beutiful cities in the world, Cusco is high but for sure, stay here is a must!!!!! Walk around the inca streets, take a drink in any main square balcony or just see the people passing is one of the most relaxing experiences!!

The square with everything. Beautiful, colorful buildings with unique wooden balconies all around the arcaded square. Fabulous churches, great fountain, lots of couples and character, shops and restaurants with balconies. The heart of it all.

Street peddlers. There are many very good artists who are university students. They are generally pleasant to deal with. There is an old woman named Sabine who sells handmade sweaters. They are most likely a combination of acrylic and alpaca, but they are handmade. She is very sweet. Then there are a few that you just have to be almost hostile with to get them away.
spend time in cuzco. i didn't know it was that beautiful, we were there for only 3 days, i would have liked to stay for a week at least
City of the Incas. lovely to walk around and just soak up the atmosphere
A good prequel to the main act - Machu Picchu. Suggest that you walk Cusco before you go to Machu Picchu. It is interesting and a good sampler before the main event.
Impressive churches. Worth visiting, especially on samana santa (the week before Easter). No pictures allowed inside churches. Save with special ticket for religious buildings (3 churches + museum).

Cuzco on foot. We decided not to take our programmed tour (too rushed) and instead wander through the streets of Cuzco. Lots to see and explore, one day was not enough. It felt safe and people are friendly.

Too many tourists!. I know Cusco is the most visited spot in Peru, but it sort of bugs me that in the historic center, all you can find are overpriced restaurants, money changers, tour agencies and annoying women trying to sell you a massage. The parks are the nice spots to hang out and people watch but the farther out you go, the more authentic it gets. Depends on what you like I guess. The buildings are nice with nice balconies and blue doors, but look hard to find the hidden gems and you'll be happier.
Wonderful city!. Beautiful quiet central square. Could spend months here.
Like stepping back in time.. Business signs are hidden out of the way. Old buildings well maintained. Town is clean. Hardly any trash on streets.
Beautiful plaza. I've got some fabulous pictures of this beautiful plaza to share. The locals are very friendly.

Tourist-full but impressive. The valley setting is impressive, and the square at the center is lovely and bustling. The main old cathedral is astounding, and just seeing the old Inca walls around the city is cool. Many tourists, though, and many stores and restaurants catering to them, with buskers out front which gets old fast.
LOVE it. Liked it so much I decided to live here 6 years ago.. have any questions?.. just ask me
Love the archeological displays. What a nice experience. I loved that it wasn't crowded. Maybe we went at the right time of day.

Picturesque and fascinating city center. The historic core of Cusco is as fascinating as it is beautiful. You can pretty much feel the diverse history of the city and everywhere you notice the mixture of inca and spanish elements creating a unique experience. The many churches are also worth a visit as well as a simple stroll through the tiny streets of the town. The people are very friendly and attentive towards travellers. Definitely worth a longer visit!

Walk around to setp back in time. The central old town is a very compact area with many well preserved old buildings and streets....day and night, you will, however, be the target of large numbers of street vendors (many are young children) trying to sell you everything imaginable. They are very persistent and will trail you for blocks, you can't blame them, their family's livelihood for the day might depend on their making a sale of some souvenir or service to you...but be prepared. Its useful if you know some other language than Spanish or English, they give up more quickly.

Historic and Beautiful for a large city. Prepare yourself for the altitude of 11,000 ft. Moderate your food intake and excercise. Stay hydrated by drinking lots of water. The local tea made from Coca leaves and supplied free at the Libertador Hotel where we stayed helped.
really beautiful. even being the result of the destruction of the Inca's Capital by Spanish Conquerors, Cuzco is a very beautiful and well maintained city.

Lively and historic!. Although it was a little too busy for our tastes at times, it was so worth to experience Cusco's historic centre, and take in the atmosphere of culture and history. Well worth it!
The hub. Loved walking the Plazas and the cobbled and narrow streets. Very interesting to see the architecture of the building s and shop.
Awfull traffic, the city hall has to improve it inmediately.. Traffic is awfull, non organized and there are all kinds of taxis which are non uniform and some of them are old and cramped.

Incredible city and countryside.. As you walk the cobbled streets, be sure you stop in at the Incan Museum to view the collection and view artisans crafting beautiful textiles. Don't miss the Cathedral of Santo Domingo.
Cobbled streets are the stars. Cobbled streets are the stars of the center of Cusco. It has a beutiful colonial style with colored balconies.
Amazing to see Cusco's layers. Take the time to just walk around the city and marvel at how the different eras built upon each other. Look for the different pictographs the Incas left on the walls.

One of the oldest centers in South America. Cusco city center is one of the older in South America and full of history, amazing views and coblestone streets. The city center is located in a valley giving way to mountains on 3 sides. On the far end one can see the Ausangate Mountain rising up to almost 6500 meters. The city is a unique combination of Inca masonry and Spanish colonial buildings. Typical for Cusco are the colonial buildings built on top of Inca foundations. The city center boosts several churches and cathedrals as well as beautiful squares.
